ResponsesInList.Title: Before you post...
ResponsesInList.Text: Useful Reading Wiki Wiki FAQ Wiki settings Using Wiki Please! Don't reply to this topic - it's for information only. Start a new topic with your question

ResponsesInList.Title: Pictures not visible
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, my students report that when they use pictures in their WIKI entries, others cannot see them (and so can't I), but they themselves can. I also have the impression that two pictures mysteriously appeared in another entry than the one they were intended for. Is that a known issue at the moment? Also, I have noticed that pictures that were visible just a week ago have disappeared now. Maybe someone can help me with that issue? Cheers, Elena

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pictures not visible
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Elena, Could you give us some more information about the wiki settings? Is this a collaborative or individual wiki Are you using groups? and if using groups which type (Visible or Seperate) The problem with the images showing only for the user maybe a setting.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pictures not visible
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, thanks for your response and sorry for the late reply, I was away for a few days. Anyway... this is a collaborative wiki, not using groups. I think, we did not change any of the default settings, just added the headings, so that the students could follow the links and write their assigned wiki entries. Do you have any specific setting in mind that could cause a sudden loss of visible pictures?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pictures not visible
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a theory about what happened here... Maybe each student's uploaded pictures tried to use the same name (e.g., "image (1)") and either overwrote each other or did not upload because the wiki thought that the picture file was already there. I have no idea why it worked in the very beginning and suddenly images disappeared, but it might explain, why they weren't able to upload new ones.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pictures not visible

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pictures not visible

I tried with both editors (ATTO and TinyMCE) and using the same image which which correctly append (#) at the end of each same file to distinguish images with same names. Because when I manually delete the files the and clear the cache the images disappear. Plus if a user could upload an image it's available to veiw for them if they do not clear their cache however the image will not be available to other users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Teacher can't see students' pages unless he's in a group
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have had this problem for a while, and I just want to report it here. Unless of course it's some bad configuration... When I choose group mode for a wiki, I cannot see my students' productions unless I enrol myself in a group, too. Should this be the case? I think it's confusing for teachers, they might not realize that there are any pages, thinking students had not done anything. Thank you , Ulrike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Teacher can't see students' pages unless he's in a group
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ulrike, I understand how this could be confusing! The group mode in Wikis often requires teachers to enroll themselves into groups to view individual student contributions within those groups. This setting is meant to simulate the group environment from the teacher's perspective but can indeed lead to misunderstandings. You might want to check the settings under Group Settings in the course admin panel. There may be an option to view all groups at once without needing to join them. If not, perhaps enabling "Separate groups" and granting teacher permissions for group-wide visibility could be a workaround. Hope this helps! Let me know if you find a different solution! BR ðŸ¤”

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Teacher can't see students' pages unless he's in a group
ResponsesInList.Text: To be able to view all groups, you need to have the 'Access all groups' permission . So, that is how to control this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Student can't see Collaborative Wiki - Visible Group
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodle community, I have an issue for some students in a course and the WIKI activity, I tried looking through the documentation but couldn't find an answer. The goal of the WIKI activity : The teacher created several WIKI activities . The goal of this activity is to have different groups creating WIKI pages about their group subject. Each group creates their WIKI page and then the students from other groups should be able to see the pages created by their peers. The issue (?) : Students from groups who have not created a page in anothers person WIKI can't see the WIKI. They have a prompt asking them to create a page, before they can see the WIKI. Our expectation : We expected that the students could see the WIKI without having to create a page in the WIKI they are visiting. Now the question is, did we miss something in our settings ? Can we have the students see the WIKIs without having to contribute to them ? I am adding a picture with our settings. If I have missed something in the documentation, please let me know. Wishing you a good day.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student can't see Collaborative Wiki - Visible Group
ResponsesInList.Text: Update, after going through the documentation in english I found this : https://docs.moodle.org/405/en/Wiki_FAQ Quote : I've set my wiki to groups but they can't see the first page If you set your wiki to groups and want to create the first page for each group, remember to select each group and make the page individually: End Quote Now my question is : Why do I want to create the first page for each group on a Wiki for a specific group ? Can't I have each group be able to see the WIKI created by a group without having to create a blank page ? Our expectation remain the same as in my previous post. Is this something that could be improved in the future ? Or is this on purpose ? Purpose which I am not understanding. If anyone has an idea or explanation, feel free to share it. My conclusion is that our expectation cannot be met with the WIKI activity, for now.

ResponsesInList.Title: No TOC
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I created a wiki following the video tutorial on the documentation page ( https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/Wiki_activity ). It's still pretty embrionary but this activity would be perfect for the course I am creating. However, there's no TOC and I don't understand why. The FAQ only says "This is automatically created if you use the appropriate headings in the toolbar of any of the wiki formats.", and I am not really sure what it means. What headings? What toolbars? Where is all that? The image attached is what I am seeing. The pages all have child pages linked to them. Shouldn't there be a TOC on the left ? Thanks in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No TOC
ResponsesInList.Text: What is means is, to create an automatic table of contents on a wiki page, you need to use heading outline levels on the page. These are the heading3/4/5 elements available in Tiny or Atto, or h3/h4/h5 html elements. (Format > Block in Tiny) For example, formatting the headings below as heading 3 (sorry for the kindergarten editing skills lol) results in: The table of contents was automagically created for me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No TOC
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks! It's really clear, my bad.

ResponsesInList.Text: If this is on your own site, is Cron running? Deleteing courses and modules is done by a background process ( Cron ) and you'll end up with issues like this if it's not running.

ResponsesInList.Title: Unexpected interaction between Wiki and groups
ResponsesInList.Text: I do realise that this is in the documentation, but I recently discovered that there is a confusing interaction between the "Individual" Wiki and the group set-up on a Moodle page. It's not immediately obvious that, when a Wiki is set up on a course that has groups enabled (either Separate Groups or Visible Groups), the default setting of the Wiki also inherits the groups setting, and once students have created content under the Groups setting, converting to a true individual Wiki makes all of that content unavailable. I know it might not be possible to change this in the system, but I think a clearer description in the documentation of how these settings interact would be helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I want to change the CSS for all wikis on my site but nothing else. This Post helped me change the style of the view.php tab. This CSS works for one single page: `.cmid-3547 h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` This works for all wikis: `#page-mod-wiki-view h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` But it only affects the veiw.php-tab. When I edit a page it looks different. How can I change the edit.php-tab as well? I tried this: `#page-mod-wiki-view, #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` Unfortunately this changed the menu and other elements as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it just the h3 size you want to change? What version of Moodle are you using?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I use Moodle 3.11.12 and the Boost Theme. I don't like how the Wiki looks in Boost and want it to look more like Wikipedia. So these are all my changes so far: `.cmid-3547 h3 {` `font-weight: 400;` `font-size: 1.8em;` `margin-bottom: 0.5em;` `border-bottom: 1px solid #b2b2b2;` `padding-bottom: 3px;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 .wiki_headingtitle h3 {` `font-weight: normal;` `border-bottom: none;` `padding-bottom: 0;` `margin-bottom: 0;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 h4 {` `font-weight: 300;` `font-size: 1.5em;` `margin-bottom: 0.25em;` `border-bottom: 1px solid #b2b2b2;` `padding-bottom: 3px;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 h5 {` `font-weight: 600;` `font-size: 1.2em;` `margin-bottom: 0.25em;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 img {` `max-width: 100%;` `height: auto;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 code {` `font-size: 100%;` `}`

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: If you inspect the page, you will see html code similar to body id="page-mod-wiki-edit" class=" etc You need to replace the id with a # and the class with a . so the selector is #page-mod-wiki-edit for the edit page and #page-mod-wiki-view for the view page any changes to CSS will affect everything on that page so you need to be more specific. You have specified a particular wiki, .cmid-3547 - so changes will only affect that one wiki and not all wikis on your Moodle. but . cmid-3547 h3 will affect all h3 tags on the page. If you only want to target the elements on the edit page, eg. h3 tags, then use #page-mod-wiki-edit.cmid-3547 #region-main h3 {

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank a lot. I found the mistake in my original code. WRONG: #page-mod-wiki-view, #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;} Correct: #page-mod-wiki-view h3 , #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;} That's why it was styling all elements on the page. Here is my complete Custom CSS for the Wiki Activity: https://github.com/margomius/moodle-wiki-custom-css

ResponsesInList.Title: HTML elements added using HTML editor are removed
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi everyone! We are using the wiki activity extensively in our site due to its collaboration and version history features. However, the page editing experience is a pain for many of our users, especially ones who are experienced with HTML and would like to add more advanced styling to their pages. We have noticed that wiki pages in HTML format don't accept various HTML elements added using the editor (from HTML/code view button). For example, we would like to use the HTML tags
and to embed collapsible blocks of long text or pictures ("accordion")Â  that can be easily shown/hidden in order not to impair the page appearance. See: https://www.w3schools.com/tags/tag_details.asp These tags work perfectly in standard moodle pages and other activities. They are also displayed properly in the HTML editor when editing the wiki page. However, as soon as the wiki page is saved, the tags are completely stripped. Plain text and simple tags like

and

remain. It looks like the wiki doesn't recognize the tags at all, or there is a list of allowed elements where they are not included. The same behavior can be reproduced with Atto, TinyMCE and Plain text area editors. All our wikis use HTML format. Can anyone please advise how I can enable the use of these tags, or at least hint at what functionality may be responsible for stripping them from wiki pages? We use Moodle version 3.10.1+ (Build: 20210226) with the default Boost theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification of new comments
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John, The instructions I created do work now. I get notifications of new comments in Wikis. It's a bit tricky, but it works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification of new comments
ResponsesInList.Text: I wrote these instructions for myself yesterday, and to share, once they work. Being notified of a new comment in a wiki. Go to Administration => Reports => Event monitoring rules Click "add a new rule" Fill in the form and Save changes. To be notified of the events you have created rules for, click on Event monitoring page, at the bottom of the page. Select a course from the drop down menu. At the bottom of this page you will see your events that you have not subscribed to. Choose the modules that your rule applies to from the drop down list on the right. If you choose "All instances" all events of that module in that course will trigger a notification. When the event occurs in the chosen place, you will get a notification in the usual way, i.e. your bell icon at the top right will light up. I created comments in several wikis that I created notifications for and didn't get any notification.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification of new comments
ResponsesInList.Text: Yesterday I created these instructions for myself, and to share, once they work. They are not working at the moment. Being notified of a new comment in a wiki. Go to Administration => Reports => Event monitoring rules Click "add a new rule" Fill in the form and Save changes. A title you'll see in the list of rules Choose Wiki from area to monitor Choose Comment created from Event Write a description if you wish Choose how many of these events need to occur before you are notified Choose how long after the events take place before you are notified Edit the notification if you wish, but keep the default fields. Save changes To be notified of the events you have created rules for, click on Event monitoring page, at the bottom of the page. "Select a course" from the drop down menu. At the bottom of this page you will see your events that you can apply to the chosen course. Choose the wikis that your rule applies to from the drop down list on the right. If you choose "All instances" all new comments on all wikis will trigger a notification. When the event occurs in the chosen place, you will get a notification in the usual way, i.e. your notification bell at the top right will light up. In your Profile, choose Notification preferences. Make sure the check box â€œDisable notificationâ€ is empty. At the bottom of this page, Event notifications => Notification of rule subscriptions. Turn this on. -------- I have followed my steps, created comments in the assigned wikis. No notifications. The only notification I get is that I have created a new rule. Unlike other notifications, it does not have anything clickable in it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: All wiki images and files disappeared in Moodle 3.7.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, I temporarily solved the issue by re-uploading all image files and attachments in the "Files" tab. Regardless of the user that originally uploaded the single files, all links inside wiki pages started working normally again. Strangely, though, the file uploader popped up an alert, asking me if I wanted to overwrite old files and images as if they were still present in the wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Styles on the wiki page
ResponsesInList.Text:
I to am not a styling expert but have noticed that the Table of Contents (TOC) Content for a wiki is built from the different heading styles. It appears that the there are two different heading styles used on the page based on the size of the text. So typically
the small styles would appear as a sub-topic under the larger styles. So I would expect your TOC to look more like more like this: 1. Teaching Writing <h3> 2. Why teach writing
<h3> 2.1 A common approach to writing
<h4> 3. Learning to write
<h3> All the text the same size with smaller headers indented. So Mary is right it's probably related to that ticket to have it fixed. Sorry this is probably not the explanation you wanted, but once the coding is fixed then your site will need to update the code.Â  Then All Will Good

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Styles on the wiki page

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Styles on the wiki page

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Styles on the wiki page
ResponsesInList.Text: The code. Many thanks James

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Styles on the wiki page
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi James - after looking at your code, I'm fairly sure that your problem is caused by the issue Mary that highlighted above . Your h5 tags are different. One is < h5 >About listening< /h5 > and the other is < h5 style="text-align: left;" dir="ltr" >Activities for teaching listening< /h5 > Ignore the spaces inside the tags - they're just there so that Moodle doesn't try to interpret my typing as valid HTML. So the second one is not a "clean" tag, as described in the Tracker report . You could prove (or discount) the theory by editing the second h5 tag to be just < h5 > - it should then render the TOC properly. If it does - it's the same bug (so please vote for that issue to be fixed). If it doesn't render as you expect, it's something
else.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Styles on the wiki page

ResponsesInList.Title: How to transfer Wiki with content between courses?
ResponsesInList.Text: I want to copy a wiki to a different course. I tried with backup and restore, yet the restored wiki was completely empty except the description text field. Is this a bug or a feature?

ResponsesInList.Title: How to transfer Wiki with content between courses?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Martin, I guess that's a feature. Same will happen with a Forum, Glossary or Database activity. This has to do with the fact that the content in these activities is generally created by your participants, making this 'user data'. If you backup/restored the activity or course without the enrolled users, the user data will not be incorporated in the backup file. You can, though, anonymize the user data, and then create the backup file as a workaround.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Wondering....
ResponsesInList.Text: When you work with a collaborative wiki in Moodle you have to consider a few things: What is the content you want to add in your wiki? In case you want to use some advanced features like some embeded activites, you will need to write a filter to do so. For instance, you can't embed H5P activities without a filter. How many people will edit the wiki at the same time. With the Moodle wiki only one person can edit a certain page at the same time. When working with students - who sometimes forget to save their work, this might cause problems, as other students will not be able to edit the same page. Choose the name of the main wiki page carefully, as you can't change it afterwards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 2.0 wiki and templated first pages
ResponsesInList.Text: OK,Â  Ulrike,Â  back to the nitty gritty - lol.... erfurtwiki is what the default wiki in Moodle is based on through Moodle 1.9.x. nWiki is the basis for the wiki in Moodle 2+ The process you describeÂ  "should" work, and the fact that you produced a bit of a page suggests that the content of your page caused a problem.Â  The process is a bit tricky because of the play between wiki markup format and html format,Â  and the wiki moves back and forth because the activity provides an html editor..... If you want,Â  please feel free to upload your text file and we can look at it.Â  It will help a bit for you to become familiar with wiki markup, because that is going to probably be the format least likely to get chewed up in importation. I think the wiki still explains some of the markup if you click on the right little yellow help circle. You don't need to save it as a .txt file,Â  you just need to save the file as an ascii text file.Â  Text editing on a MS WIndows machine can be confusing because you may not get a pure ascii text file,Â  which causes all kinds of grief.Â  WIndows uses the txt extension for "text" files,Â  but offers a number of different flavors that can be used with that extension. At some point I documented some tools and techniques one can use to manage such things.Â  Have you looked in docs.moodle.org for additional info on wiki formatting? AHhh,Â  I see a number of the links are broken etc. I did find this discussion: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=8501

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 2.0 wiki and templated first pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi SÃ©verin, There is a way to work around the lack of templates being built in to the wiki if you have the Sharing Cart installed. Make sure the settings for Sharing Cart at Site Administration > Plugins > Blocks > Sharing Cart, has a check mark by Wiki so that you can include user data. Create a sample wiki fixed up with whatever you want included in it forÂ  your "template." Copy it into the Sharing Cart and Select Yes when it asks, 'Do you want to include user data in a copy of this activity?' Now, anytime you want to start a wiki that includes your "template" just click the Copy to Course button for your wiki in the Sharing Cart block and drop it into the topic section of your choice. Everything and all the pages you put into the original "template" version will be in the new wiki. I've tested both collaborative and individual wiki's and they both worked. Works easiest if you are NOT using groups. For individual wiki's, if you want the first page to already be formatted then you WILL have to make the first page for EACH student, before you add it to the Sharing Cart. Note: If you modify the original "template" and then replace the one in the Sharing Cart, you may have to clear the cache first or your changes might not show up. I learned it was easiest to force the data to be updated by using a version number in the wiki activity name. HTH , AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedding YouTube Video in Wiki activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, Reading through this thread, this appears to be a pretty vexed issue that has not yet gone away! It certainly appears to be the case that in Moodle 2.0(.1) YouTube videos are handled differently inside a wiki to the way they are handled in a course topic or similar general location. In a course topic the whole object/embed content (or even the iframe) copied from youtube's embed panel can be pasted into the html editor, saved and displayed as a video. This object takes its size and settings from the copied code, and so even 3D glasses options will work INSIDE moodle without the need to link out. Of course, you cannot paste such content in at all if object/embed code is specifically outlawed in... Admin -> Security -> Site PoliciesÂ Â Â  'Allow EMBED and OBJECT tags' = No unless also in the same site policies 'Enable trusted content' = Yes, AND the user's role settings say their content will be trusted! More strictly, you can paste it in, but you find it remove or deactivated. But aside from these permissions issues, this embedding method of getting youtube content into a topic works a treat! In the wiki, however, we do not seem to be playing by the same rules! This may well be forced onto the situation by the notion of the wiki being a collaborative activity (generally speaking), so if you can't 'trust' the content from one user, how can you trust the content from another! If this is the view taken, which seems likely, then object/embed & iframe entries pose a security risk (or at least the risk of unacceptable content), and these get removed even if you are a trusted being! So what about using other possible routes? Yes, you can enable the Multimedia plugin filter for youtube videos and that works consistantly inside and outside a wiki. As we know, this means that if you enter some text, highlight it, click the hyperlink button, and then paste in the url of the video. Such as:Â  youtube.com/watch?v=0GcLW0g_c1s. Note however, that this url needs to be take from youtube's ' share ' panel, not the 'embed panel' because they are quite different. The 'share' version works with the filter, whereas the embed version youtube.com/embed/0GcLW0g_c1s does not! This is simply because the filter is looking for ?v= in the url, and in the latter version it isn't gong to find it! [note I've had to cut the http etc to stop this link linking!!!] So for moodle to behave consistantly we need to be consistant too. And there is obviously room for confusion here. There is also a method involving the use of a [youtube] tag each side of the url, as explained here: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Multimedia_plugins#YouTube_Link_Filter but I'm still not clear as to how that is different from simply using the media filter described above. However, the multimedia filter may solve one problem, but it creates another. Elsewhere it has been explained that you can change the size of the display in some types of media by trailing it with d=400x300 (or similar), but the youtube instance of the filter strips these out . in fact it strips out all the content after the ? except the v=#### video reference. This means that using the multimedia filter to give youtube content results in a loss of control of the size of the video in the wiki, and leaves out all the options (such as the colour of your 3D glasses)! So we appear to have away to go on this as yet. Regards, John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedding YouTube Video in Wiki activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: The default embedding code provided by YouTube is now with the iframe tag, not the object or embed tag. The iframe tag to embed videos works in a label or page in Moodle, but not in the wiki. After following the above suggestions from John, I embedded a YouTube video using the object tag. For example: <object data=" " type="application/x-shockwave-flash" height="400" width="600"><param name="allowScriptAccess" value="never" /><param name="allowNetworking" value="internal" /><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" /></object> Then it worked for me To learn more about these tags, see http://www.w3schools.com/html/html_youtube.asp

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedding YouTube Video in Wiki activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Having thought about this a bit more, I think Franco's solution above may work but will have unintended consequences (such as switching off filtering you want left on). So I have set about finding a fix for the underlying problems. Firstly, not being able to supply dimensions to the youtube filter the way you can to Quicktime or Flash video. This only really requires a few changes to the file /filter/mediaplugin/filter.php We find the line if (!empty($CFG->filter_mediaplugin_enable_youtube)) { and make changes as highlighted (copy and paste, but only in a proper HTML editor, eg Smultron, Fraise, Ultraedit) if (!empty($CFG->filter_mediaplugin_enable_youtube)) { //see MDL-23903 for description of recent changes to this regex //$search = '/<a.*?href="([^<]*)youtube.com\/watch\?v=([^"]*)"[^>]*>(.*?)<\/a>/is'; $search = '/<a[^>]*href="([^<]*?)youtube.com\/watch\?v=([^&"]*)(&d=([\d]{1,3}%?)x([\d]{1,3}%?))?"[^>]*>(.*?)<\/a>/is'; $newtext = preg_replace_callback($search, 'filter_mediaplugin_youtube_callback', $newtext); $search = '/<a[^>]*href="([^<]*)youtube.com\/v\/([^"\?]*)(\?d=([\d]{1,3}%?)x([\d]{1,3}%?))?"[^>]*>(.*?)<\/a>/is'; $newtext = preg_replace_callback($search, 'filter_mediaplugin_youtube_callback', $newtext); } Then we find the callback function filter_mediaplugin_youtube_callback and make these changes... function filter_mediaplugin_youtube_callback($link, $autostart=false) { $site = addslashes_js($link[1]); $url = addslashes_js($link[2]); $info = addslashes_js(strip_tags($link[3]));//strip out html tags as they won't work in the title attribute if (empty($link[4]) or empty($link[5])) { $size = 'width="425" height="344"'; } else { $size = 'width="'.$link[4].'" height="'.$link[5].'"'; } return '<object title="'.$info.'" class="mediaplugin mediaplugin_youtube" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" data="'.$site.'youtube.com/v/'.$url.'&fs=1&rel=0" '.$size.' >'. '<param name="movie" value="'.$site.'youtube.com/v/'.$url.'&fs=1&rel=0" />'. '<param name="FlashVars" value="playerMode=embedded" />'. '<param name="wmode" value="transparent" />'. '<param name="allowFullScreen" value="true" />'. '</object>'; } This should allow dimensions to but put in either in the form http:// www .youtube.com/watch?v=6RFuRY7azgA &d=450x300 or http:// www .youtube.com/v/6RFuRY7azgA ?d=450x300 Note thank this depends entirely on the url you get from 'share' in youtube! Finally we can also get Moodle to do the work on putting in an iframe that users are generally blocked from (along with object and embed). My reasoning here is that it must be safe for moodle to do in the say way as it embeds to object safely for you! Here we add an extra trap in the filtering process inside the same braces as before (top of this post) $search = '/<a[^>]*href="([^<]*)youtube.com\/embed\/([^"\?]*)(\?d=([\d]{1,3}%?)x([\d]{1,3}%?))?"[^>]*>(.*?)<\/a>/is'; $newtext = preg_replace_callback($search, 'filter_mediaplugin_youtube_embed_callback', $newtext); Note this adds a NEW function call so them we add a new callback function (below the current youtube one) /** * Change links to embedding Youtube content into iframe Youtube videos */ function filter_mediaplugin_youtube_embed_callback($link, $autostart=false) { $site = addslashes_js($link[1]); $url = addslashes_js($link[2]); $info = addslashes_js(strip_tags($link[3]));//strip out html tags as they won't work in the title attribute if (empty($link[4]) or empty($link[5])) { $size = 'width="640" height="390"'; } else { $size = 'width="'.$link[4].'" height="'.$link[5].'"'; } return '<iframe title="YouTube video player" class="youtube-player" type="text/html" '. 'src="'.$site.'youtube.com/embed/'.$url.'" '. 'frameborder="0" '.$size.'>'. '</iframe>'; } And THIS allows you to use the youtube embed content, BUT WITHOUT THE IFRAME STUFF ARROUND IT. Like so: http:// www .youtube.com/embed/6RFuRY7azgA And add dimensions, like so: http:// www .youtube.com/embed/6RFuRY7azgA?d=640x390 I've tested this moderately well though only on Firefox . Thats all for now. John [note: I have inserted a couple of spaces in urls to stop them linking! - there must be a better way?]

ResponsesInList.Title: Uploaded Images Dissappearing From Wiki after several hours
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone. I have set an assessment task for my students in a Moodle 2.0 wiki and we have the bizzarre problem that images uploaded and inserted into posts are dissappearing after several hours. When a user uploads an image and/or video to the wiki moodle server said image is assigned a location on the server (eg. http://moodle.uni/draftfile.php/8707/user/ draft /705008760/activboard300_20090625112013.jpg) such that the image can be displayed in the users post. After an undefined period of time that asset is no longer linkable and will no longer display in the post. If you put in the address for the asset directly you will get a page with "Sorry, the requested file could not be found" (e.g. The link above). When you look at a wiki post where this has happened there will be no images in the post and/or a broken image icon (depends on how the browser handles it), but going into edit clearly shows the img tags and references to the missing image. Please note that a 10min test is unlikely to make this issue apparent as there appears to be some undefined period of time, or unknown trigger before the uploaded assets become dead. Create a wiki post with some uploaded images and leave a day and the issue may become apparent, or maybe there is a trigger such that the more images others upload the quicker your assets are dropped from the server. I can only speculate, but hopefully someone expert in the moodle wiki can resolve. Please advise ASAP. Best wishes, Matt Bower

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploaded Images Dissappearing From Wiki after several hours
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I don't know anything about Moodle 2 wiki. That said, I do know a bit about the file API, and draft file URLs should not be used except while you are editing content (such as a wiki page). Once the content has been saved, the version of the image that displays to users when not editing should have 'pluginfile.php' not 'draftfile.php'. So if, when you use the html editor to add an image to a wiki page, after you save the page, the image on the resulting page still has the URL 'draftfile.php', then imo this is almost certainly a bug in the wiki which (after making sure it still occures in the latest release version, 2.0.2 or whatever) you should report in Moodle Tracker . I believe the draft file areas, which are (when it's working) used only temporarily while editing, are deleted periodically in cron, which is probably what's causing your problem. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Students can't edit
ResponsesInList.Text: Timo, there must be something wrong in your site wide settings because default settings of course wikis should allow all students to edit wiki. In settings of each wiki the wiki mode determines whether everyone can edit the wiki - a collaborative wiki - or whether everyone has their own wiki which only they can edit - an individual wiki . Front page is a special case because nobody is in student role by default there but you said students can't edit your course wiki... Editing roles is not at all necessary unless if you have a very good reason to change default settings. Or are you trying to allow GUESTS to edit wiki??? (override global settings in some course)

ResponsesInList.Title: Unable to create a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I am running into a strange error that I don't think is Moodle-related, but my-site related. I can't figure it out though and any help would be greatly appreciated! Below is some general information on my Moodle: I'm running Moodle 2.8.7+ (compiled 2 days ago). All modules and functionality in Moodle is correct (I can add, delete, use, etc everything). The exception is using anything related to the Wiki module. As soon as I create a Wiki, it gives me the " Invalid course module ID" error. If I create another module (for example, a book) this works flawlessly. However it refuses to run the Wiki module I created. Things I've already tried: I've got the same Moodle running on my MAMP installation and I was able to create a Wiki there. Oddly enough! I've made a backup of the working Wiki on my MAMP and tried to restore to me server . No luck. I've checked the MySQL database and all entries are correctly made into mdl_wiki. Both the MAMP and the production site have identical entries into mdl_wiki, so I do not understand the issue. I am, quite frankly, completely stuck on how to solve this. The problem also existed on Moodle 2.8.7, hence the upgrade to 2.8.7+, which didn't fix the situation. Thanks everyone for reading this post and any help would be greatly appreciated, since I'm eager to begin building some Wiki's!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to create a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I've fixed the issue by changing maximum allowed connections on the My SQL server side.Â Apparently the Wiki module is quite intense in this area, which caused a number of strange errors to appear.

ResponsesInList.Title: More Wiki Weirdness
ResponsesInList.Text: As I work on my recently-upgraded server , I'm seeing more weirdness with the 2.9 wiki module. For example, after editing a page and creating three headings, formatted as "Heading (large)" which I presumed would be a Level 1 heading, I get a Table of Contents like this: Table of contents 1.1.1. Identity Management Principles 1.1.2. Authentication Techniques 1.1.3. Authorization and Access Control To me, that looks as though those are level 3 headings (which I'd thought would be "Heading (small)". Sure enough, editing the raw HTML shows that "Heading (large)" is actually <h3>, not <h1>, and editing it to correct the levels in the raw HTML gives me much bigger headings, with "[Edit]" buttons to the right, and a much more useful table of contents at the top: Table of contents 1. Identity Management Principles [edit] 2. Authentication Techniques [edit] 3. Authorization and Access Control [edit] 3.1. Mandatory Access Control 3.2. Discretionary Access Control I'm using the Atto HTML editor. Is there any way to get it to behave better, or should I switch to TinyMCE? Or am I missing something? --- Les

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: More Wiki Weirdness
ResponsesInList.Text: I've now found the other threads about this, at https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=310805 and https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=270112 , and can confirm that Bruno Manzoni's patch in the latter thread basically fixes the problem. It doesn't put in "[edit]" links against the <h3> - <h5> headings in the ToC or the wiki page, but that's something I can live without. This gets the Atto editor working "correctly" with the wiki; TinyMCE users just have to remember that a Level 3 heading is the top level in a wiki page (a convention I'd adopted previously anyway - <h1> and <h2> are used in the main course page. If I get time I'll investigate this further, but it's been years since I looked at the PHP internals of Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
I don't know if this should be reported as a bug. Here's what I just discovered after a teacher reported that an embeded (with Multimedia filter) YouTube video was displayed twice in a wiki. If you use the URL as the link text, it will be converted to a hyperlink in the wiki, causing a double link. Like this: ```text

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4uipnBkj-4

``` You must replace the text to fix it:

some texte

Using Moodle 2.6.2

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it the same problem discussed in here: A <nofilter> tag in the forum? https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=218330 ? The solution I found is linked to the last post in that thread.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Similar answer to the one fromÂ Visvanath Have you tried turning off the autolink filter for the wiki? Â Should be doable from Administration block -> Wiki administration -> Filters Ensure you turn off the filter "Convert URLs into links and images". Otherwise, when editing the wiki page with the TinyMCE editor on, select the link and click the "No auto link" icon. Hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I got around this by entering something other than the URL as the text of the link. In html, your href should look something like this (with "video" being variable, as long as it isn't the url of the youtube video): href="https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU">video Not like this: href="https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU"> https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU ;

ResponsesInList.Title: Creating a wiki.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, would someone mind going through the steps of creating a wiki using the sandbox demo? I am using a moodle site called ZSchool that has a wiki but it comes up with an error - "Create page permission needed" - and I cannot find any information about this error anywhere. I managed to recreate the issue in the sandbox but I do not understand what the problem is. If you are familiar with Moodle, would you mind setting up a wiki in the sandbox demo and seeing if this problem is occurring for you? If it is not then please post here the procedure for setting it up without this problem. Thank you so much for your help. Bye, Adam.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Adam, The error means that the role that the user has does not have the mod/wiki:createpage capability. The capability is allowed for the default roles of manager, teacher, non-editing teacher and student. Is the wiki is on the front page of your site? If so, you'll need to allow this permission for the role of authenticated user on frontpage. Please see the documentation Permissions for more details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Helen, thank you, I think I understand. Yes, the wiki is on the front page. I am working in the Sandbox Demo to figure these things out. I cannot find much information in the Permissions documentation about frontpage and either the Sandbox Demo is outdated, or the wording of the documentation is slightly wrong because some of the instructions do not match up. However, whilst looking through the list of Administration options I found under Site Administration > Front page > Front page settings - an option for 'Default frontpage role'. It was set to Authenticated user on front page (frontpage) by default and I changed it to Student (student) . The other option is Guest (guest) .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Adam, Good to hear that you are making use of the sandbox demo to figure things out. The site uses the latest stable version of Moodle, so if anything doesn't work, it means the documentation needs improving or you have discovered a bug. In this case, it seems the documentation needed improving, and so I added a section 'Front page permissions' to Permissions . Please shout if anything is unclear. However, it seems you found an alternative solution, namely changing the default front page role. Well done!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki.

Front page wikis are still inaccessible in the Sandbox, by default it seems to me, unless I am missing something - which is highly likely. Bye, Adam.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki.
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Adam for your feedback and no need to apologise for anything. Please keep posting your questions. I tried going to the sandbox demo and following the instructions and realised that as well as needing to allow the capability to create new wiki pages, other wiki capabilities needed to be allowed too. Sorry for the confusion. Thus I realised that your solution of changing the default front page role to student was a lot simpler! I have edited the Permissions documentation to remove the confusing bit, and your solution is mentioned in Front page FAQ as an answer to 'How do I enable logged-in users to participate in front page activities ?'.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Helen, thank you so much for your help. I really appreciate it. Please do not apologise for the confusion. It is a complex system, constantly developing. I understand that there are going to be problems with documentation. Based on your knowledge of Moodle, can you foresee any problems arising from changing the frontpage setting in this way? I am going to post another question about Glossary terms being linked to on Wiki pages. If you happen to be able to help on that then please do. All the best, Adam.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: setting default front page role to student
ResponsesInList.Text: Can you foresee any problems arising from changing the frontpage setting (changing default front page role to student) in this way? That's a good question! You're maybe wondering what the point is of an 'Authenticated user on frontpage' role? In general with roles and permissions, for maximum peace of mind, you should only allow capabilities for things you want users to be able to do. Most sites don't have front-page activities for logged in users to participate in (activities are are only in courses, where users have the role of student or teacher), thus the 'Authenticated user on frontpage' role is sufficient. I can't imagine you having any problems with the front page role set to student if you check carefully what you want users to be able to do or not do. For example, if you have a standard forum on the front page, do you want everyone to be able to start discussions there or post replies?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: setting default front page role to student
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Helen, that is good to know, thank you. Just having trouble with the "anyone on this site" publishing option on blogs now. I will post something here when I have a coherent question. Bye, Adam.

ResponsesInList.Title: Uploaded pictures not saving consistantly in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I am having issues with Moodle 2.6 and Wikis. Uploaded images are just not consistently sticking. Students insert an image (images) in the page of their Wiki. Students are blaming each other for deleting their pictures. Using a Wiki has been a complete disaster as the reason for using a wiki is to foster collaboration. Instead, I have several angry students and parents. After viewing the Wiki forum it seems this is an issue that is affecting more than just me. Has there been any resolution to this issue? I really want to continue using Wikis, but if there is no resolution, my principal wants them to be removed from the class. I have looked at two or three Moodle trackers, but they all seem to get closed since the issue cannot be reproduced. I'm not sure if I should open up a new one or not. Fingers crossed someone out there can let me know what I can do to resolve this. Thanks!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Uploaded pictures not saving consistantly in Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Same here! Yes, please do start a new Tracker issue, I have excellent descriptions of the problem to add, and I was contemplating the same thing. We're running 2.6.2 and we've had this problem for over a year: the reports last fall that cmoore added were us, too. It's difficult to reproduce because it happens when there is a class all working in a wiki at the same time, but not when only one or two people are editing a wiki. This means it _looks_ fine when one or two staff test it out, but when students are getting close to deadlines they have their image links break and freak out and come banging on our doors. We're considering testing out OU Wiki as an alternative but we would far rather use the regular wiki if this bug can be chased down. Here's a roundup of the relevant links for the infamous draftfile.php bug . https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=170655 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=185839 And this Moodle Tracker issue: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-26782 ...on which you'll see us reporting the problem last fall around this time. We don't think it was ever fixed in 2.4. We're certainly still having it. John, please do open up a new tracker issue, I'll both add to it and encourage others who have had the problem to speak up. It's a leading source of frustration about our install right now, and we have faculty with a long history of wiki projects under our previous CMS and we need to find them a solution that behaves at deadline time. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Individual wiki where students can view one another's
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello I have done extensive research and testing, but I can't seem to figure this out.Â  I would like to create a wiki where each student in the course has his own set of pages within the wiki, and where each student can see the other students' wikis.Â  My research has resulted in conflicting facts.Â  This page essentially makes it seem like it's not possible to do this.Â  However, I've found other posts ( here and here ) that indicate that indicate that if I create it as an individual wiki, and set the group mode to "Visible Groups" then: " Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can
edit. Students can view the wikis of all other students in the course. " which is what I would like to do. I tried this second method, creating it as an individual wiki with a group mode of Visible Groups, However, the student is able to create content once on his first page, and then has no more ability to edit his wiki.Â  The edit tab isn't there at the top.Â  He sees a drop-down menu for the other students' wikis, and can see them, but he has no edit ability on his own wiki.Â  The teacher can edit all wikis. Any advice or insight one can provide would be most appreciated. Thanks Joe Amatrucola Moodle 2.6.1+ (Build: 20140131)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual wiki where students can view one another's
ResponsesInList.Text: You have set the wiki Â to visible group mode but are your students in the groups (in Course administration>Users>Groups) ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual wiki where students can view one another's
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks.Â  No, they are not in groups.Â  In my scenario, what groups would I create and who would be in those groups?Â  I would like each student to have his own wiki, so that only the student and teacher can edit the wiki, but every student can see the wiki.Â  Does that mean I need to create a group for each student, and then add just one member to each group?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual wiki where students can view one another's
ResponsesInList.Text: I think if you are going to use visible group mode for your wiki then yes, you would need to put your students into groups so they can edit their wikis; otherwise they can just see but not edit. (You could try on the sandbox site demo. moodle.net )

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual wiki where students can view one another's

ResponsesInList.Title: ouwiki templates and images

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki templates and images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carl, I'm the lead developer for ouwiki so I can probably shed some light on your issue. What version of the plugin and Moodle are you using? The most recent version of the plugin for your specific Moodle version should be used to ensure you have all bug fixes etc. These can be downloaded from https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_ouwiki - note for ouwiki you should raise questions there or issues on the github project , not on this forum as it's not monitored. If you're having problems with template images you should check they are in the template zip file (assuming the template is a zip file, if it's just xml you are using a version of the plugin that doesn't support images in templates).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki templates and images
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm using Moodle 2.7 so I'm guessing thats the issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: ouwiki templates and images
ResponsesInList.Text: Changing the reg expression near line 215 of entirewiki.php from '#<img.*?src="https://moodle.org/pluginfile.php/193/mod_forum/post/1160402/(.*?)".*?/>#' to '#<img.*?src="https://moodle.org/pluginfile.php/193/mod_forum/post/1160402/(.*?)".*?>#' (i.e. removing the closing slash) seems to have solved the problem in Moodle 2.7. For some reason img tags had closing "/" in 2.6 but not in 2.7. Maybe this is a 2.7 bug?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restoring WIki
ResponsesInList.Text: Backup function of standard wiki has a bug that all of attached filesÂ in the wiki are not backed up rightly. Your trouble is not equal with above trouble, but if your wiki contents has any attachment (for example, as image), you will encounter above trobule too. Let you see https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=227237 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restoring WIki
ResponsesInList.Text: Francois, The backup/restore file will not include all the data from a Wiki, even with the include user data turned on in the backup. Even duplicating the Wiki in a course or importing from other courses will not include the old pages. What I do when I have pages that I want in the new wiki, I copy the html out of the old wiki for each page.Â  I then set up the pages and copy the html into each page.Â  When I have an instructor that uses the same Wiki in each new reiteration of their course, I save those html files in a hidden folder at the bottom of their course so they are easy to find. Paula

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restoring WIki
ResponsesInList.Text: Paula wrote: > The backup/restore file will not include all the data from a Wiki, even with the include user data turned on in the backup. This is right. Francois: If you can turn on "Include enrolled users" etc..., let's try cheking backup file (*.mbz). (Backup)Â  Initial settings Check boxÂ : Include enrolled users [x] : default ( Download and check the backup file) After backing up the wiki data, you download the backup file (*.mbz). Next, you change extension of the file from *.mbz to *.zip, then you can browse file list of theÂ backup file. / activities /wiki????/wiki. xml : this file is data of all wiki pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restoring WIki
ResponsesInList.Text: (Just to note that a regular teacher can't choose to include enrolled users; you have to have that permission , such as admin)

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all - I'm teaching university students and would like them to be able to collaborate in summarizing the content of the lecture so that eventually, they have a resource to prepare for when exam time comes. Would you recommend using a wiki for each lesson , or a book and have each lesson as a chapter? (of course I can use a wiki for entire class or a book for each lesson but that sounds less appealing) Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David Wiki would be a better choice because every student can manage to edit one wiki but book is a resource, which a student can't add or edit. Resources only have read permission a student can't interact with it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: At one level, Sakshi is right, but at another, the response does not really answer the question. There is also the idea that data requires its own structure, it demands it essentially. What are you presenting? Static knowledge, googleable content? Informative opinion? Dynamic information? Peer interaction? Wiki or Book, what about forum? Your response also needs to take heed of what you are trying to accomplish in the course - not just the learning outcomes, but the processes involved along the way. That should determine what tools you use. I am currently developing alternate responses to these questions and finding a set of solutions, not just one size fits all. Essentially, Moodle does one job, another tool does another job that Moodle is not designed to do. Seems to be working so far... but we shall see. So let your information and your processes define how you respond to each circumstance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks to both of you. I want students to be able to contribute their knowledge and basically use wiki as a replacement to their lecture notes. Ideally, at the end of the course, they would be able to print it out and use it as reference. For future courses, I'm still debating if I should give them access to the previous semester material and have them enhance it, or develop it from scratch. A book as you mentioned is more structured, but I definitely want students to own it so seems like I will go with a wiki. I would be interested to see your solution Colin, perhaps you can share.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs. Book
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps that might be possible David, but for the moment, I am not sure the other tools I am using are not all available outside Australia. Most are, but some are local products - you may have equivalents though. One of the tools is called DayMap, from a Melbourne company. Essentialy an SMS, it also has a small LMS module that is more or less a credible wiki and not a lot else. I am not sure that they will be selling internationally yet but I imagine it won't be long. I am developing a solution that meets our local laws regarding storage of data, as well as promoting positive learning outcomes. It also uses MS-Sharepoint which we are turning into a local repository - so not a lot is going to be stored externally. Moodle is, hopefully, going to be used for resources and online testing, If they can get Mahara up in that environment, then that will be for eportfolio and social networking with other common open source tools for more specific purposes - Wordpress for one. All locally stored and we can develop them to suit our need. One snag, Sharepoint 2013 is not being co-operative right now so the whole strategy could be brought undone by it. As I said, we shall see.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki Comments Order Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, We are experiencing a problem with the order of comments in the Moodle Wiki tool. I've done extensive searching in the forums here and in the Moodle issue tracker, but haven't been able to find anyone else describing the same problem (my apologies if I overlooked something). We are currently running Moodle 2.2.4 and the Wiki is set up to use Separate Groups. What are we are finding is that comments are not always posted in chronological order. It seems to be triggered by editing a comment, though this does not immediately re-order the comments. The edited comment is generally date-stamped correctly with the updated date and time, and is placed at the bottom of the comments. However, subsequent new comments are often inserted somewhere in the middle of the comment thread. To date, in testing, we have not been able to determine a pattern for the misplacements. All new and edited comments appear to be correctly date-stamped. Has anyone else experienced this problem? Thanks, Trevar

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marek, What you describe is intentional. To make a copy including pages, you need to create a backup of the wiki activity including enrolled users, which teachers are not generally allowed to do. Please see the documentation Course backup and Backup of user data for more details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files
ResponsesInList.Text: Awww - I did such a lot of work on my wiki, I was hoping to copy it and not to have to reconstruct it As I have already updated my course and done so much other work on my new course I do not want to start again from a back-up. So sad. Carol

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files
ResponsesInList.Text: Carol, You may need your administrator to do the backup and restore if you do not have the rights to included all the user data. But, as Helen says, it is entirely possible to use this method to make a complete copy of your course, with its wiki, and all the entries in it. You would not then need to 'start again' without the wiki content. Regards, John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks John but my wiki is a small part of my course. Having already updated everything else it would have been great to copy my wiki over. I had Â to rebuild the whole exercise for my students which just made a lot of extra, what seemed to be unnecessary work. best wishes carol

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carol, You're right, that would be a lot of unnecessary work. But Backup and Restore does offer hope here too! You can backup your entire doner course (or selected parts of it) and restore it into a recipient course without having to overwrite all the recipient's existing content. Now this needs care, and I wouldn't attempt any such thing without first making a full backup of the recipient ! What is more I would do the whole job TWICE, creating a new almost identical copy of the recipient (with only the short and long names changed a bit) and this course hidden from students. We'll call this our dummy recipient. Then go back into your donor course and back it up, or at least those parts you want to transfer. Now download the backup file and go into dummy recipient and upload the file into its backup files area. Now restore this file from within the course and select "Merge the backup course into this course" and when offered "Keep current roles and assignments". Now check everything , but especially User enrolments in the course, your wiki content, and any other content that ought to still remain, e.g. Forum posts etc. Only if you are completely happy with the result should you then try this on the recipient course, and even then, not without knowing where you put that original backup file. Regards, John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki copy does not contain any pages or files
ResponsesInList.Text: I understand this limitation, but it can be a problem. While I would usually want to reset a forum discussion for a new term, there are many circumstances in which I can imagine wanting to keep the entries in a wiki (or database or glossary, for that matter). At minimum, I can see wanting to be able to keep the instructor posts in these activities . I think it would be worthwhile to consider making the "user data" import permission more granular.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable display of table of contents in a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Maurits, Disabling this wont help fix the error but it will hide it away. I'm not a Wiki expert, but if you go into: /mod/wiki/parser/markups/wikimarkup.php and search for protected function generate_header , then a few lines below that you have: if ($level < 4) { If you change this to: if ($level < 1) { ...the Table of Contents will disappear from ALL wikis. It should come back if you reverse the changes. Regards, Â John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki links do not turn blue, they vanish into plain text when they exist
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ted, Does this mean that all your links in all blocks turn back to grey text after you have visited them? If that were the case your theming could be better!Â I'm not a Wiki expect but it sounds to me as if the css theme settings for links aren't doing you any favours. If the colour (color) setting for a:visited is the same as your ordinary text then they will certainly turn to plain text after the page is defined. If you are using Chrome browser then you can right-click (or CTRL-click) one such link and choose Inspect element to see what the settings are. You should also be able to change the colour temporarily here to see what effect that has. Similar things are available in in Firefox if you have Firebug installed as an add-on. To make permanent changes you need to edit the css. But if you do that in the theme's style.css you may affect all links. You can also work with the wiki's style.css in /mod/wiki/style.css. You should not open this file in a word processer such as Word, but in a text editor or a special css editor (a text editor will do fine). Start by saving a spare copy of this file (in case of disasters). Find the entry that begins: a.wiki_newentry and replace it with: .text_to_html a:link { color:purple !important; } a.wiki_newentry:link { color:deeppink !important; font-style: italic; } a.wiki_newentry:visited { color:turquoise !important; } Save the file and refresh the page. Do you get strange colours now? This should allow you to narrow down what you want. But note, you may also have to go into the Admin settings -->Theme settings and switch on Designer mode, otherwise you may not see the changes. This is one of many good reasons for not doing this on a live site, it will slow the site down. Hope this helps a bit. --John

ResponsesInList.Title: Simultaneous editing occurs in wiki with overwriting of data as result
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, We have discovered that the edit protection in the wiki of Moodle 2 is not watertight. Normally, if a (student) user tries to edit a (collaborative) wiki page that is being edited by another user, they would see an error message: " Someone is editing this page right now. Try to edit it in a few minutes. " However, experience has shown that nonetheless it is sometime possible for users to edit a wiki page simultaneously with as a result that the data of the user who saves first is overwritten by the one who saves last. Our tests have so far identified three possible scenarios: An interruption in the Internet connection. If a user, for instance using an unstable wireless connection, suffers a short interruption in his connection, another user can open the editing mode of the same page, provided they click at the right moment. A mix up with open browser windows or tabs If a user leaves the wiki in editing mode in one browser tab then opens another with which he/she also surfs to the wiki and then gets the view mode, another user can open editing mode for the same page even though the first user still has it open. Using the back button If a user edits and saves a wiki page, the pages becomes editable by another user, but the first user can use the back button of his/her browser to reurn to editing mode without encountering the error message. We wonder if anyone else has noticed these and other cases where the edit protection fails? And also if anyone has suggestions for improvements, apart from instructions to students for proper use of the tool. We use Moodle 2.3.2+ Rgrds, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Title: Is it possible for a teacher to protect a Wiki page temporarily to keep people from changing it.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Would you know if it is possible to temporarily protect a page in WIKI? That would help teacher of our organization. I do not seem to see any option, neither in the standard Moodle Wiki nor in the OU Wiki. Thanks Imbu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible for a teacher to protect a Wiki page temporarily to keep people from changing it.
ResponsesInList.Text: You can, of course, turn off access to the entire wiki (it will still be available to the teacher), but I don't think you could just freeze one page. I'm pretty sure that an open page is uneditable by any other user, so you could just leave it open somewhere...a crude approach, surely. Otherwise, you can, of course, simply depend on the ability of a wiki to revert to an earlier version to protect existing content. Modifying roles associated with the wiki could also remove editing capabilities for the whole wiki. That's all I've got...good luck!

ResponsesInList.Title: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, the wiki module is listed as possibly being replaced by OU Wiki at some point in the future in the Roadmap . The question I would ask here is why was this not done in the transition from v1.9 to v2.0? I know I am being unfair, the amount of excellent work done by a lot of people, (none by me), should not be so casually dismissed, but as a fan of wikis, I am actually appalled that the Moodle wiki is so.. so... dowdy.Â  It was poor in v1.9, and did not fare any better in v 2.0. I understand there was a substantial debate around a new wiki for v2 but really, the end result is disappointing.Â I know the perception has always been that MoodleWikis should be course specific, but I would ask why? This may have been desireable a few years ago, but is it still so? For me, Moodle wikis can work at two levels, one is site wide, much the same as Forums and Docs do here, (but with a single login). The other is at a course level. Most educational institutions, and businesses for that matter, could well use a tool with that kind of flexibility. Wikis can be specific, and general, and as a place for all sorts of information. We are now well used to using Wikipedia as a source, but what if a school, for example, had the opportunity to develop a school wide Moodlewiki? What if a class of students had the ability to develop a single wiki for an ancient History class, and their teacher could use that as a fully annotated and referenced demonstration of student learning. Better still, could the teacher then not allow continued development of that wiki at a site level?Â  Over time, it could become an incredibly valuable resource for a school. Is this not what wikis should be? Rather than OU Wiki, why not use MediaWiki as Moodle Docs does? Why not fully integrate MediaWiki as a part of Moodle. Any comments or suggestions are most welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree, I'd like to have wiki content that can persist beyond a student's course enrollment. We also see a value in being able to selectively publish some content for public viewing (i.e. viewing by users not enrolled in our institution).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: That is not a use that I had actually thought about Elizabeth, but is a great suggestion. That would be a very useful tool in a lot of different contexts. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: It would be great to have stronger MediaWiki integration with Moodle. My Â team uses both extensively. There are some education-focused extensions and initiatives related to MediaWiki, but nothing even close to Moodle. The current wiki plugins for Moodle are far to limiting.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree Nathan, the current wiki module is far too limiting. The idea of Moodle is flexibility, and there is, of course, strong argument that Wikis should relate to courses, as activities , but the broader picture is overlooked in that context . Flexibility should not always mean just within Moodle. The other important thing too is that there needs to be a single login policy. That does not happen in Moodle.org, and I do not understand why? It is likely if there is a embedding of mediaWiki into Moodle that the login process will be taken care of. Currently, in our circumstance, our students log into their computers/network, then to the internet, then to Moodle, then to a wiki (if we had one). Now, to me that is just putting barriers in place. (I know that there is a couple of programs that will change this, like iChain, but that assumes all network techs have a high skill set and that is not always the case.)

ResponsesInList.Title: wiki - Missing from disk!
ResponsesInList.Text: I just upgraded from 1.9 to 2.3 even upgraded php I have wiki in mod folder /mod/wikdisplaying Missing from disk! How can i fix it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki - Missing from disk!
ResponsesInList.Text: No such Mod in either v1.9.x or 2.x.x... Can you login? Can you get to the Settings menu? From there, you should be able to get the Site Administration menu, then go to Site administration > Plugins > Activity modules > Manage Activities There should be anything that is remotely connected to this "wikdisplaying" appearing on the list of plugins. If it is there, then there should be a delete option, if so, delete it. You may need to go to the folders in your server and delete it from there as well. Usually this sort of thing is a hangover of a third party pluging that has not been properly cleaned out from the previous version. you may also need to go to the database via phpMyAdmin and look in the database for any table that relates to that mod and delete that as well. That should clean it out.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Nwiki and Creole parsers in Moodle 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary and Mark, Nwiki format is the Mediawiki-like markup language used in the contributed Nwiki module. Creole is a common wiki markup language used in other wikis such as TiddlyWiki and MoinMoin (see Creole format for syntax examples). Mark, as far as I know, it's not possible in the Moodle UI to disable these wiki formats site-wide.

Please see attached screenshot for the debugging stack trace information for errors thrown by OU Wiki for Moodle 2 version 2012030700. This error appears to have started after I successfully performed a weekly upgrade to Moodle 2.2.2+ (Build: 20120329) from the previous week's 2.2.2+ build. (I've been running Moodle 2.2.2+ on a VPS with Linux CentOS and MySQL .) I had OU Wiki for Moodle 2 version 2011112900 installed at the time (which had been functioning without any problems previously), so I uninstalled that older version (after backing up and then deleting the few OU Wiki instances I had already created). (During the uninstalling process, I did notice that simply clicking the Delete button from the Manage Activities page did remove OU Wiki from the list of installed modules. However, when I manually inspected my database, I found the 8 mod_ouwiki tables still in the database. The tables were empty but had not been dropped from the database. I manually dropped the empty mdl_ouwiki tables from the database. I also manually deleted the mod/ouwiki directory. Seemed like a clean uninstall at that point.) Then I uploaded and installed the latest version 2012030700 found at https://github.com/moodleou/moodle-mod_ouwiki . Installation was successful and I could create a new OU Wiki instance in a test course without problem. However, when I attempt to create a new Start Page by saving a bit of simple text content, I get exactly the same database write error with version 2012030700 as I did with the older version 2011112900. Is anyone else experiencing this problem? I will also post a bug report at https://github.com/moodleou/moodle-mod_ouwiki as the README doc directs.

ResponsesInList.Title: Editing a Wiki as a Guest
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings all, I hope you can help me. I am using Moodle 2.2 and can not seem to get guests to be able to edit a wiki. I have tried altering some of the wiki permission settings but that doesn't work. I have also read in the Feedback module forum that it will not allow guests to complete a survey in the Feedback module. Is there any way around this? It is really important to us to be able to have guests being able to edit wikis and complete Feedback surveys. Kind Regards, Marcel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Editing a Wiki as a Guest
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. Guests can complete feedback surveys on the front page if you follow the appropriate settings - http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Feedback_FAQ However, guests can't edit wikis. There are certain things that the guest role does not allow and wiki editing is one - see the documentation here http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Guest_role The workaround is to make a real account -call it "visitor"; let your guests know the password and let them edit using that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some Students Unable to See WIki Pages | Moodle 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is the documentation on Moodle 2 wikis http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Wiki_module Basically if there is a wiki that is read only by a student then it wouldn't be in the spirit of a wiki - so you would use, say a "book" for instance (the contributed book module) or just some "pages". I think in older versions of the wiki there was a "teacher" wiki that did this -but not now.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some Students Unable to See WIki Pages | Moodle 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: FranÃ§ois, you should be able to create a read-only wiki by changing the permissions and removing the student role from mod/wiki:editpage and mod/wiki:createpage . As Mary says, if you only want the teacher to edit it, then a page resource or book would be easier, but if you want students to contribute to the wiki and then later archive it, then changing permissions is the way to go.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some Students Unable to See WIki Pages | Moodle 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: AT LAST! - I think I've found the solution. To stop others having to go through what I did (making three large wikis that all had to be rebuilt from scratch), here is an instant guide which should help... Thanks to Mary the Moodle Fairy. Simple Instructions for Understanding Wikis in Moodle 2.0+ The 'spirit' of a wiki is to allow anyone to contribute to it. However wikis can be made which are editable only by an individual (e.g. teacher) but viewable by all . The key is that one has to use a collaborative wiki to do this. Being able to do this negates the Moodle 'book' module from what I can see. Read on... In Moodle 1.9, settings for Wikis were different. There used to be three wiki types: Teacher or Trainer Groups Student (Individual student or trainee). Things changed from Moodle 2.0 which offers only two types of wiki: Individual Collaborative. Confusion can arise from the help box in Moodle 2.0+, which pops up when the user asks for information about the difference between an individual and a collaborative wiki viz : The culprit is the statement in relation to the individual wiki: 'everyone has their own wiki which only they can edit'. What the box does not tell you (which in my view it should), is that INDIVIDUAL WIKIS CAN ONLY BE VIEWED BY THE INDIVIDUAL AND THE TEACHER ALONE. If the teacher makes an individual wiki, students will not be able to see it . The words 'individual' and 'collaborative' refer to who can view the wiki, not who can edit it! So: if you want to make a wiki which is viewable by all, but editable only by an individual (i.e. the teacher), you need to make a COLLABORATIVE wiki ...then edit the permissions section for that collaborative wiki as described in the summary table below. Student only, to see and contribute to wiki individually Teacher only to contribute to wiki, but viewable by students as well. Teacher and students to be able to see and contribute to wiki When you first set your wiki up, make it an Individual wiki. Set groups as required. Set up a Collaborative wiki (otherwise students won't be able to see it), but then remove student permission to edit after you have set up the wiki . Do this by clicking on the wiki and then going to: Settings>Wiki administration>Permissions and removing the 'Student' role from 'Create new wiki pages' row. Set up a Collaborative wiki with groups as required. Summary Collaborative wikis don't have to be collaborative, and you might want this. Don't use an individual wiki unless you want to be the only person who can see it. It would be great in the future if it was possible to change an individual wiki into a collaborative one (and vice versa ) after the wiki had been made. One thing that still confuses me i s that in Settings>Wiki administration>Permissions , 'Create new wiki pages' exists, but not 'Edit wiki page'. I hope I've got all this right. - Open to comments.
