ResponsesInList.Title: Standard version 2 Wiki doesn't seem to understand groups and groupings
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Is anyone else having problems with groups and the standard Wiki module in Moodle version 2? I'd like to be able to set up a wiki on a version 2 moodle system in which, "there is one wiki per group, students can change the wiki of their own group only, and they can view the wikis for all groups." When using moodle 1.9 and the standard issue Wiki I often set up a wiki so that small groups of students could collaboratively edit their own group wiki, and view the wikis of other groups (see the yellow cell in the table below). This does not seem to be possible in version 2. Either students are able to edit both their own group's and other groups' wikis, OR they can only edit their own group's wiki and not even see other groups' wikis. The settings for a 1.9 wiki to make this group collaboration possible were (also see yellow cell in the table below): Type: groups Group mode: visible Grouping : Grouping-A (this setting not necessary, but useful in courses with lots of groups) The Wiki settings in version 2 are different. These settings; Wiki mode: Collaborative Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A result in a wiki in which students can edit their own group's wiki AND those of other groups. I was hoping that these settings would emulate the 1.9 version described above (and in the yellow cell below). These settings: Wiki mode: Individual Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A Available for group members only: checked result in a wiki in which students cannot edit a group wiki (to be expected) but can edit their own wiki. They can also see the wikis of other students. The strange thing about these settings is that even with the "Available for group members only" checked, students can see a menu of all students and groups in the course, not just the groups in the relevant grouping. I have tried other combinations of settings, but none get the result I want and used to be able to get in 1.9. i.e. "one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups". This is a bug, surely? For your reference, here are the Wiki types available in 1.9, copied from the help files of a 1.9 system: Wiki types (in 1.9) There are three wiki types: Teacher, Groups, Student. In addition, like any activity, the wiki has the Moodle group modes: "No Groups" "Separate Groups" and "Visible Groups". This leads to the following matrix of nine possibilities: No Groups Separate Groups Visible Groups Teacher There is only one wiki which only the teacher can edit. Students can view the contents. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wiki of their group only. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis for all groups. Groups There is only one wiki. The teacher and all students can view and edit this wiki. There is one wiki per group. Students can view and edit the wiki of their own group only. There is one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups. Student Every student has their own wiki which only they and their teacher can view and edit. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of other students in their group. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of all other students in the course. Unless the group mode has been forced by the course settings, it can be set with the groups icons on the course home page after the wiki has been created. So how can this group wiki feature be emulated in version 2? _______________________ Environment: Moodle 2.0.2+ (Build: 20110413) php 5.3.3 MySQL 5.5.9

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing groups = loss of content?
ResponsesInList.Text: This just happened to me and I think it's pretty significant.Â  It's quite common to customize groupings for individual projects within a course and to want to preserve work done by these ad hoc groups at least until the end of the course.Â  We use groups a lot to separate sections of students, so the teacher can have a single Moodle class for Algebra I, for example, and still keep the period 1 and period 2 students separate.Â  Within these class groups, it would be convenient to be able to have groups within groups, as well, so that you could dynamically group students within a class.Â  So I would propose two features, groups within groups (allowing students to be in multiple groups, with the activity respecting these groupings), and work not being lost when the groupings change. I think the ideal would be to allow students to be separated into groups and then choosing the groups that will be used for that activity.Â  That way, you could have different groupings of students and then the activity for which you created the custom groupings would respect only the groups that were assigned to it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing groups = loss of content?
ResponsesInList.Text: Same thing happened to me today too I created new groups andÂ deleted the old groups and all content gone from the wiki. Is there no way to retrieve the wiki from the database so at least we can grade the previous project? Or some way to go back in time like a restore point?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing groups = loss of content?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jacqueline, As far as I know, the only way you can go back in time is if the teacher or the admin have made and stored frequent backups. As a teacher, I do this every week or before I make significant changes. Then I can always restore the backup either on my local computer or on a copy on the online server . (I'm also a course creator in my category so I can do this.) As for groups, I learnt the hard way not to delete them too. Now, I put the students in Groups Red, Yellow, Blue and Green for Task One, and East, West, North, South for Task Two, and so on. If there's another way of avoiding the problem, I'd like to know too. "Groups within Groups" exist - you have to get your Admin to turn "Groupings" on and explore what it says in the Docs. Cheers, Glenys

ResponsesInList.Title: how to delete Wiki pages in Wiki 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I cannot figure out how to delete wiki pages in wiki module 2.0 In Moodle 1.9.+ it was possible to delete them. Can anyone help? Gisela

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to delete Wiki pages in Wiki 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have the same problem. Is there any possibility to delete a page manually within the moodledata in some *.php or any database ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to delete Wiki pages in Wiki 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, you can go into you Moodle database and remove wiki pages manually, but you will also want to remove the content and links. It can get very messy if you are not careful. I would recommend just removing all content from a page you want to get rid of except a Do Not Use warning, and then wait until they give us a delete page button or tab. If you must though, the page will be in the mdl_wiki_pages table and the content will be in the mdl_wiki_versions table. The versions table will have an entry for each version of the page listed on the History tab. The mdl_wiki_links table will also have an entry for every link that will take you to the page you are wanting to delete. You will need to make sure the entry for the page is the one you really want to delete because if you are like me, I have a lot of wiki's and many have pages with the same name. To help make sure you delete the right contents, you can write yourself a message on that wiki page, then look for it in mdl_wiki_versions. When you find it, make note of the pageid because you will need to look through the whole mdl_wiki_version table and delete ALL the entries that have the same pageid. If you look at the History for the page you will know how many you should find. Once you have those taken care of you then need to go look at the mdl_wiki_links table. Refresh your browser then look for any topageid that now has a zero entry. The frompageid entry should correspond to the one that had a link to the page you are deleting. Look through the whole table because if you linked to the deleted page from more than one page, there will be others to find and delete. The two times I have wanted to do this, I made a sample wiki to play around with first so I would not risk messing up a wiki I was actually using. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to delete Wiki pages in Wiki 2.0

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upgrade from 1.9.10+ to 2.0 fail
ResponsesInList.Text: Jose - It is strange that it would not work but I suspect that there was something different about the nwiki table structure. Normally the old tables are renamed to {name}_old and then the new tables are created and the data is brought over. It appears that the field subwikiid is not in the wiki_pages table which is of concern. I am not familiar with the nwiki names and structures but I suspect that it is because they were using a different table name. Could you provide the table structures of the wiki tables? Also I believe there was a similar issue filed in the tracker that you may want to follow up on and watch. Peace - Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upgrade from 1.9.10+ to 2.0 fail
ResponsesInList.Text: Upgrade from 1.9.12 to 2.0.3 also fails for much the same reasons! We have just done a trial upgrade of our 3.5 million record Moodle installation (with an entire copy of the database and half a terabyte of files), and it all went swimmingly well with just a couple of correctable errors (like missing files) until it got to the Wiki! Even then the process ran smoothly up until 'Migrating old pages to new pages' and 'Migrating old history to new history' , both of which were full of errors namely exceptions thrown with very little information given! Error writing to database * line 162 of /mod/wiki/db/upgrade.php: call to debugging() * line 526 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to xmldb_wiki_upgrade() ... Error writing to database * line 326 of /mod/wiki/db/upgradelib.php: call to debugging() * line 175 of /mod/wiki/db/upgrade.php: call to wiki_upgrade_migrate_versions() ... I have some clues to offer, I think that the test to avoid duplicate entries in /mod/wiki/db/upgrade.php at line 157 doesn't do what it is meant to... try { if (!$DB->record_exists('wiki_pages', array('subwikiid'=>$record->id, 'userid'=>$record->userid, 'title'=>$record->pagename))) { $DB->insert_record('wiki_pages', $page); } } catch (dml_exception $e) { // catch possible insert exception debugging($e->getMessage()); continue; } and so the upgrade attempts to insert a record where it should not! It is notable that both lots of errors are thrown from the same place in the code, which is pretty surprising to me at least, since they are generated from quite different functions. I feel that things might have gone a little more easily if the Wiki team had chosen to rename mdl_wiki to mdl_wiki_old and run the upgrade by migrating this across to a new mdl_wiki table. It seems that its all a bit like trying to eat three Shreaded Wheat - but that one may not translate well! Possibly, we may next try to explore getting rather fuller debug info! Regards, John

ResponsesInList.Title: Create a Wiki with Groups (Step by Step Instructions)
ResponsesInList.Text: When I first started using Moodle years ago the forums were very helpful to me. Now that I consider myself somewhat skilled in some of the aspects of this powerful teaching tool, I like to share my knowledge whenever I can. If anyone is struggling (like I did) on how to create a wiki with groups, I hope this step by step tutorial helps. Create a Wiki with Groups (Subject: American War Battles) Create Groups 1. On the course page select â€œGroupsâ€ under â€œAdministrationâ€. 2. On the groups page click the â€œCreate groupâ€ button. 3. Fill in the following info for this group: Â· Group name: civil Â· Group description: Civil War Group Project Â· Enrollment key: civil Â· Click the â€œSave changesâ€ button. 4. On the group page, make sure the civil group is selected and click the â€œAdd/remove usersâ€ button. 5. Add users to the civil group (move them from the right box to the left box by clicking the â€œAddâ€ button). When finished, click the â€œBack to groupsâ€ button. 6. Repeat steps 2-5 to create three additional groups (vietnam, world1, world2). Make sure to make the appropriate changes to Group description, and Enrollment key. Note: Enrollment key is optional. 7. Return to course page. Create the Wiki Turn editing on. Click the drop-down menu for â€œAdd an Activityâ€. Select â€œWikiâ€. On the â€œAdd a Wikiâ€ page fill in the following: Name: American War Battles Summary: American War Battles Group Project Type: Groups Print Wiki name on every page: Yes (optional) HTML mode: HTML only Allow Binary Files: Yes Disable CamelCase linking: Yes Group Mode: Visible Groups Visible: Show Grade Category: Uncategorized Click the â€œSave and return to courseâ€ button. On the course page click on the Wiki link. This is where you need to stop for a moment and get yourself oriented. Most likely you are on the â€œGroups wiki for civilâ€ page in the â€œAmerican War Battles Wiki (since this was the first group you created). If so, you are ready to begin created your Civil War page Wiki. If you would prefer to start with another war, simply click the drop-down on the top-right of the page labeled â€œOther Wikis:â€ and choose the wiki group you want to start with. On the lower portion of the page you should see a bold header: Edit this page â€˜American War Battlesâ€™. ( I chose to start with the civil group so I will begin editing for the Civil War). Type the following: [The Battle of Shiloh] [The Battle of Gettysburg] [The Battle of New Orleans] Click the â€œSaveâ€ button On the top-right of the page choose the world1 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War I. On the top-right of the page choose the world2 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War II. On the top-right of the page choose the vietnam group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from the Vietnam War. Now the Wiki is ready for students to work in! Student Access to Wiki Go to course page. Click on the â€œAmerican War Battlesâ€ Wiki. Select your group from the top-right drop-down menu. Click the ? to the right of the battle you want to begin working on. Get to work! Note: Students will only be able to edit within their group. Because the Group Mode was set to â€œVisible Groupsâ€ by the teacher, students will be able to view every groups work but will only be able to edit their own.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki log lost cmid, please vote MDL-29425
ResponsesInList.Text: In Moodle2.1, If you check the activity report in the course, you will find that all wiki's log is disappeared. I tracked this problem, and found out that when add_to_log function is called in wiki module, it don't add course module id to the log, If your course has more than one wiki, you will not be able to distinguish these logs. I submitted MDL-29425 to solve this problem. If you has the same problem, please vote.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with "copy & paste"  in Wikis with Mozilla
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a major problem we encountered, especially since our institution is only officially supporting mozilla flavor browsers.Â  There is a workaround that can be added to each individual user's mozilla profile that will allow your particular moodle to have "privileged" scripts, but it involves editing a file most people don't even know exist.Â  What we did here was to create a default file with those privileges and give users instructions on how to download and copy the profile file to their profile folder.Â  This solves the copy/paste error you are describing with the HTML editor site wide.

(i.e. can not support attachments).Â  It also does not seem to include the one feature that I know our users (students and faculty) really want - the ability to subscribe to a page - which dfwiki had.Â  Where can I go to read up on differences between wiki2 and ou wiki?Â  And is there a current roadmap for enhancements of wiki2?Â  I am still a bit confused about where Moodle is heading with regards to wikis (which I think are fundamental tools if you are trying to teach in a social constructive environment.) Many of our faculty go to external appliations (like pbworks) for their wikis now - we would prefer if they kept their learning activities inside our LMS as much as possible so our users have a more consistent experience.

ResponsesInList.Title: Links in NWiki automatic table of contents not working

When looking at the source code of a wiki page, I see no corresponding anchors at the actual headings. A related problem is that I cannot make anchors manually. I would like to make simple footnotes: I put a link somewhere in the text, which should lead the reader to the bottom of the page, where a corresponding footnote is situated. The link points toward the anchor #blah, and the footnote is situated inside a HTML li tag with id="blah". However, when I click the link in the text, nothing happens, although the anchor is appended to the URL seen in my browser (this happens both in Firefox , IE and Opera). Have anyone else got code that has working anchors? Or can you see what I do wrong just from what I've described? If you need more information about my Moodle installation, the wiki page, or my code - please ask

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Links in NWiki automatic table of contents not working
ResponsesInList.Text: A solution was found in a newer thread: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=172852#p757880 In short: If one goes to Site administration -> Security -> Site policies, turning of the HTML Purifier , the id="" and name="" tags should work as intended. This also fixes the problem with the table of content links not working, since these also use HTML anchors.

ResponsesInList.Title: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I had tested ou wiki 2.5 on moodle 1.9.10+ and found some problems. When I added new section toÂ page or create a new page,if I typed some chinese characters as the section name or page name ,for example "æ ¡åœ’"or "ç ”ç©¶",after clicking the buttons "add" andÂ "save changes",all the content is lost in this page,what's wrong? Does this module "OU wiki " agree with unicode character? Any one can give me suggestions? Thank you very much. Jing-dong wang

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I also got this in private message and replied to it, however just to clarify, my understanding (& experience here after a quick test) is that in general, OU wiki does work correctly with Chinese characters and any other unicode characters. If anybody else has insight into this, please let me know. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: å›žæ‡‰: Re: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sam, Thank you for your reply. I had recorded a video file of operational steps like your message. Please click this addresss and watch the attached video file. The test is on moodle 1.9.11+ with mysql ,and 2.5 ouwiki. When I had added a new section name,all of the content is blank,and no error messages are found. This phenomenon is found only for some chinese characters,like "æ ¡åœ’" or "ç ”ç©¶". What's wrong? Thank you for your help. Jing-Dong Wang

ResponsesInList.Title: å›žæ‡‰: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Maybe the function "str_replace" can't be used for two-byte character(chinese,japanese....). The function "mb_eregi_replace" is more proper for two-byte character. Jing-Dong Wang

ResponsesInList.Title: å›žæ‡‰: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi sam, I have found a solution for this problem. I have modified the function "ouwiki_format_xhtml_a_bit"Â  in ouwiki.php. At line 2399,the original code is $content=preg_replace('/\s+/'," ",$content); and replaced by the new code $content=preg_replace('/[\r\n\s]+/u'," ",$content); the parameter u is for multibyte character . Thank you very much for your help Jing-Dong Wang

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: å›žæ‡‰: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you. I don't understand why this solved the problem for you because this regular expression only works with ASCII characters which are not altered in UTF-8. (Also as noted, the problem doesn't occur for me including using the same strings.) However it is good that it's solved it. One possibility is that the version of the underlying 'preg' library is different on our different systems and this somehow means that it requires the /u flag on yours, but not on mine. Strange. Oh well. --sam

ResponsesInList.Text: On your settings page set allow binary files to yes. This enables the attachments tab Students can the tab to upload files, which can be either an attachment to a page or displayed on the page by inserting a link on the page i.e. [internal://image_name.jpg]

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Picture Problems!!! Help please
ResponsesInList.Text: Sir, can you please tell me how can i resize the image. I have tried [internal://image.jpg | 100px] but it didnt work for me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki as a resource
ResponsesInList.Text: We are experiencing difficulties with the reuse of wikis by teachers... Some of our teachers use the wiki module as a resource instead of an activity. I mean, they are the only ones to produce information for the wiki in order to deliver it to their students (and sometimes to other teachers). And it is true that creating and editing information in a wiki is much easier than doing it on a set of linked webpages (and using the 1.9 fab html editor ;) ). The problem here is about reusing the wiki. They are not able to import it and they are not able to backup/restore because they do not have permission to create new user records. Did anyone experience the same problem? Do you have any solution, workarounds...? Thank you in advance. Cheers, susana

ResponsesInList.Title: how to add wiki category pages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, i am trying to add categories and sub categories to my Moodle 2 wiki. i've followed the instructions found here: http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Category#Creating_a_category_page and here: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Help:Editing#Categories_links as explained added a Category:categoryname but the whole thing just appears as a link like this - Category:categoryname which leads to a new page with identical name. what am i doing wrong here? cheers!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to add wiki category pages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Same question here - any help?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to add wiki category pages?
ResponsesInList.Text: The help files you refer to are help files for the Mediawiki based documentation system used by moodle.org to document moodle. This documentation wiki system is different from the wiki system used inside moodle itself. See the FAQ here for an explanation of the difference. I'm not an expert onÂ  Moodle's internal wiki system, but a cursory search suggests to me that it does not yet have a tagging or categorisation feature.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to add wiki category pages?
ResponsesInList.Text: OK, to correct my previous post. I have since discovered that moodle 2.0 has 'tags' for internal moodle based wikis. Tags in this context play a similar role to 'Categories' in Mediawiki based wikis like Wikipedia. See moodle docs here: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Tags for more info on 'Tags' and how they have a similar role to 'Categories' in moodle. I discovered the existence of this 'tags' feature for wikis playing around in the sandpit/sandbox (demo) site for moodle 2.0 over here: http://demo.moodle.net .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to add wiki category pages?
ResponsesInList.Text: thanks very much Dennis, i'll check it out

ResponsesInList.Title: C++?
ResponsesInList.Text: How can I prevent the question mark from appearing after writing 'C++' in a wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Insert doc or pdf in wiki page?
ResponsesInList.Text: I've been exploring the new html wiki quite a bit, and I find it surprising that I can insert "moodle media" and pictures, but I can't simply insert a pdf file or office document. Â Am I missing something? I'd like to keep everything centrally located in the wiki - so users don't have to go to a separate folder or repository to access handouts.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Insert doc or pdf in wiki page?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you use the link icon and then click on the icon to the right of the Link URL box, that will take you to the file picker where you can upload or browse forÂ  a pdf document - that should do the trick.

ResponsesInList.Title: how to add images and files to wiki 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: How can I add/ upload a grphics file in a moodle 2.0 wiki? I use the NWiki format. Clicking on the image icon in the wiki page edit mode results in the piece of code: alt - so where can I upload a image.jpg file and link it with that Image in my wiki? Thanks! Gisela

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to add images and files to wiki 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Very good point Gisela! I can't figure out how to add images either and so have created an issue in the Moodle Tracker for it - MDL-26392 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Editing Toolbars
ResponsesInList.Text: How anyone noticed the editing toolbars do not show up in wikis on macs?Â  PC's are fine.Â  Anything I am missing?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Editing Toolbars
ResponsesInList.Text: In 1.9 it's probably because you are using Safari and the editing toolbars don't work in Safari - if you switch to Firefox you will probably get them.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Editing Toolbars
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunatley, I do not believe that to be the problem, as the edit toolbar is not showing up on this Mac on either Firefox or Safari. Might the problem have something to do with the amount of people accessing the wiki? Half of the class reports being able to see the edit button and the other half has been having problems pretty consistently.

ResponsesInList.Title: Develop 5 FAQs
ResponsesInList.Text: 1)Q. Can an 18-year-old student excuse his/her own absences? A. yes 2)Q. can an 18-year-old student leave the school campus at his/her discretion? A. yes, but only with a valid excuse. 3)Q. Do parents and legal guardians retain their educational rights if the 18-year-old student still lives in their house? Who ultimately makes the final decisons? A. No, Even though the student may still live with the parents or legal guardians and is claimed as a dependent, parents or legal guardians only have access to records, but can no longer make any decisons for the students. 4)Q. If an 18-year-old student needs to be transported to the hospital for further medical treatment and is denying treatment, can that student make the final determination or should his/her parent be contacted? A. Since the student is now considered an adult, he/she has the right to make the decision to refuse treatment. 5)Q. Can parents or legal guardians have access to their child's student records even after the child turns 18 years of age or becomes an emancipated minor? A. As long as the parents or legal guardians claim the child as a dependent on their federal income taxes, they retain the right to access their child's student records.

How exciting you know!!! If you need someone to do test stuff, feel free to include me. I have dozens of NWiki pages which contain images, links and tables across several courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: In collaborative wiki, with separate groups, teacher cannot view the group wikis
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all. I have the following problem in Moodle 2.0. In collaborative wiki, teacher cannot view separate group wikis. Tried with last versions of Explorer, Firefox , Opera, Chrome: nope. Tried with or without teacher first writing his page: nope. Tried creating wiki in different courses: nope. Could someone try to reproduce the issue? Thanks Marcello

ResponsesInList.Title: Delete selected versions of a page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, How can I delete selected versions of a page in a wiki? I mean if I did a mistake and I want to delete version 12, ie. If I go to clean pages in administration I haven't got the number of versions to keep or to delete I'm using Moodle 1.9.10 and Nwiki. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle with MediaWiki and Facebook
ResponsesInList.Text: First of all, I am new to moodle.org, and I really like the look and feel of the site. Some questions I have: I was looking for a way to integrate Moodle and MediaWiki, and I learned that Moodle Docs uses MediaWiki ; how can I achieve the same installation? Is it possible toÂ use Facebook Connect with the above setup? Thanks. ---- Testing: $$x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}$$

ResponsesInList.Title: Help a newbie to Moodle sort out a wiki!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone. I am rather new to Moodle, and was hoping someone here could point me in the right direction. 1) Basically, I teach English literature, and I was hoping to set up a wiki in which I could save 4-5 different passages of text from a novel, in order that 4-5 groups within the class could work on each text seperately, annotate their text, save for future reference, and present to the class. At present, all I seem able to do is copy and paste a passage into the editing box on the front page of the wiki. I really want links to other pages with these passages saved in them, so that students can navigate their way around these passages and read the comments left by the other groups within the class. 2) Also, is it possible that students annotate around the text, rather than simply modify the text itself. I was hoping they could insert comments, like in Microsoft word, so the passage itself remains unchanged but the comments around it build up and up. At present, all I seem able to do is change the text in the editing box itself, rather than insert comments. 3) Is it also possible that other students can see these comments, and see who has written them? These wikis seem really great in terms of collaborative learning, but I really need some help understanding the tool. Thoroughly apprciate any help, because I have no idea! Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help a newbie to Moodle sort out a wiki!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there - here is the documentation on setting up a wiki - hope this helps!! http://docs.moodle.org/en/wiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help a newbie to Moodle sort out a wiki!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary. Thanks, but it doesn't really explain what I need. It just discusses setting up a wiki page, but not about how to add comments etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help a newbie to Moodle sort out a wiki!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Matthew. Welcome. If you follow the links at the bottom of the page Mary suggested you get to a Moodle e-book http://docs.moodle.org/en/Using_Moodle_book . Worth downloading and a read through. To get to your points: a) you need to make new pages. When you are editing a wiki you need to put new pages/page titles into square brackets. So [page 2] will save and, when viewed again, take the reader to page two where it can be edited. b) AFAIK you can't so a MS Word thing in a Wiki. However, you do get a page history to show what has changed. This can be even more useful in learning terms because you can see how people have responded to what (and you can ask them why!). c) Yes - they see and can edit everything you do. It might be worth making a copy of your basic wiki before you make it live - some students seem to delight in removing page links etc. Hope this helps. Stick with Moodle - it has heaps of possibilities but does have a learning curve.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help a newbie to Moodle sort out a wiki!
ResponsesInList.Text: Wow, Paul, thanks. So in terms of inserting comments in order to annotate a literary text (make notes around the edges), there is no way of doing this as far as you are aware? Do you know of any other web-based applications I could use with Moodle to do this? It's really important that students are able to see other students' opinions and insertions of comments. That's the crucial bit. Last questions I promise!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help a newbie to Moodle sort out a wiki!
ResponsesInList.Text: Never apologise for asking questions on Moodle (how do you think I learned?!). I'm not aware of text-based options but why does it have to be text? There's an application (can't say I've used it myself but others have and said it's good) is Voicethread. Here's a Moodle link to same. Just having re-read their website I can see it allows text messages as well as voice so it might be an all-round option. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm using Moodle 1.9, and since a couple of days, the wiki is horrible slow with saving modifications. I have already cleaned up orphan pages and deleted old versions - still slow. I have created a new wiki in this course - it's as slow as the other one. I have created a wiki in another course (an almost empty one) - it's perfectly quick! The course is not especially big (just 12 topics). Can you help me? Thanks, Gerhilde

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: Last year I had a horrible time when I started creating new wikis on a server under which I had never run wikis, but ran many simultaneous users. The problem got much worse as we created more wikis and more wiki pages. The entire course was slow, not just the wiki. For us, it turned out the problem was the auto-linking feature (eg, you type in "junkpage" on a wiki page and it links to a course or wiki page with this name) . For a site with a lot of pages, it was a very annoying feature so we disabled this. Once disabled, the site was back up to speed. Don't know of this could work for you, but I thought I would share...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the hint, Eric! Unfortunately I didn't find a way how to turn off the auto-linking feature. There is only the 'disable CamelCase linking' at the wiki-settings, which does not help at all. I also couldn't find a right place in the Adminstration menu.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a feature that must be changed by the server administrator, and can be found under Modules->Filters->Mange Filters There are several auto-linking options and I disabled all of these. I do not know which of these was the primary offender, and I do not remember a specific "wiki auto-linking" option when I originally made my changes. When I originally made this change, I did so because I could not selectively override the inclusion of the auto-links. For example, I might have had a non-visible wiki page that I called "test", and every time the word "test" showed up on any other page it created a link to this page. The feature saved me little time over manually creating the links, and too often sent students on the way to irrelevant pages. Once I disabled auto-linking, it was like I had a new server. My server had performed well under very heavy simultaneous user loads before for exams and file downloading, and it was always a mystery to me why it totally buckled with this wiki-based course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried it (there even is a special 'wiki auto-linking' filter), I disabled all filters, but it didn't help at all Saving a change lasts more than 2 minutes, whereas the rest performs ok!!!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: Try a different browers. We are also running into the same problem and have told our students to switch browsers. We normally use Firefox 3, but for Wikis we often need to use IE 7. The problem seems to occur most when our bandwidth is topped out and, even though most other surfing just seems a little slower, the wikis tend to tank.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: You are right. IE has no problem at all. What's amazing is, that Firefix didn't have any problems as well until 2 weeks ago. Thank you very much!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: If your problems were only in the saving, then you have different issues than my course site, and likely do not need the changes I suggested. In my case, the server that could set up 60 simultaneous exams in a minute was taking 1.5 minutes to load a simple html page (2 paragraphs, no images, maybe a link or two). As nearly as I can recall, we ran into severe problems when we had around 400 pages spread over 20 wikis and 12 groups . Once I shut down the auto-linking, the same simple html page loaded in a fraction of a second, and the number of wiki pages had no impact on any aspect of site performance. At the end of the term the course had close to 6000 wiki pages with no performance degradation. Was it the algorithm for the auto-link searches that quit working well with so many pages, or a clash between auto-linking and groups, or...? I have no idea. I'm happy you don't have to deactivate a capability that may be one of your Moodle favorites, but I'm sorry I could not be more help. Cheers, Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone. the pageI am running a Moodle site with several large wikis and it is taking a painfully long time to save an edit (like 1.5 minutes per save). I have turned off autolinking and tried a couple of browsers (Mac Firefox and Mac Google Chrome). None of this has helped. As well, it doesn't even load any page after saving - it just shows a blank page (even though mod/wiki/view.php?id=2556&page=Topic+2&thankyou=1 is called) Are there any other ideas out there? Does it have something to do with the database tables growing so large? Please advise - this is urgent for me. All the best, Matt

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki is soooo slow! (Moodle 1.9)
ResponsesInList.Text: Try running the index test in Admin>Miscelleneous>XMLDB editor I found with Wiki's and DB's that if the indexes aren't set up correctly everything grinds to a halt.

ResponsesInList.Title: Make Wiki available to multiple courses / students?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, it's my first post here so please be gentle! I'd like to make a Wiki available across several courses. For example, I've created the following music technology courses Beginners Cubase music production software Intermediate Cubase music production software Advanced Cubase music production software I'd like to create a single Wiki, entitled something like 'Cubase learning resources Wiki', and make it available to students on all three of the courses. To further complicate things (I may be getting ahead of myself here!) I'd like to create courses for other music production software packages, but have a Wiki related to general music production techniques available to all students To try to explain it in a simpler way, I'm looking to set up a structure so that... Students on courses A1, A2, A3 can all access Wiki A Students on courses B1, B2, B3 can all access Wiki B All students on all courses can access Wiki C Is this possible? Thanks in advance for any assistance you can offer!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Make Wiki available to multiple courses / students?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. I will be gentle with you Though it's not straightforward The simplest way would be to make three courses, A* B* and C* (or whatever) and put your relevant wikis in them. Then enrol students in the A courses into course A*, students in the three B courses into B* and all the students into the C course. YOu can also do this by using metacourses (take a look in the MoodleDocs ) You can also do this by making only one extra course and using Groupings -but I will stop now!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Make Wiki available to multiple courses / students?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the quick response Mary! From what you're describing and from my brief scan of the Metacourse documentation (please correct me if I'm wrong!), I can have a 'parent' course with several 'children'. That sounds like a neat solution, but I'll have to do some more reading! I'd be very appreciative if anyone could suggest any other method(s), such as through Groupings. From what I understand of Groupings, it may be a more flexible approach Again, thanks in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Make Wiki available to multiple courses / students?
ResponsesInList.Text: Well you could set up one course as a metacourse and have all your A and B course students enrolled in it as child courses. Then you set up your 3 wikis and use groupings to allocate the three wikis to the relevant groups/groupings of students. All this does is reduce the number of extra courses though; I can't see how you can have your three wikis in another way other than having them in a separate course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I'm asking for the community wisdom here. Last years Xavier de Pedro and I have been doing some research about howto grade a Wiki activity, but as I am refining the Wiki 2.x reporting and grading tools I would like to access to the community wisdom. When you have students involved in a wiki-based activity and you browse the wiki, what are the basic questions you need to answer in order to get jour job done ( your job meaning: facilitate learning and assest the students work). While I'm designing the wiki 2.x analysis, reporting and grading features that's what I have in mind. - What's going on the wiki ? -> number of pages, how many times are the pages being edited, what kind of edits are happening (minor, major contributions) - - what's going on around the wiki -> number of views per page, wich pages, wich students, when is this happening - what' does the wiki feels like -> what are students saying about the pages (comments) and what do they think about it -> ratings , are pages evolving (do ratings improve as new edits are happening =) About a student - at what pages is a student looking at? frequency ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your work on this. First, I would like to have an email notification or subscription option so that I can track real-time activity on any wiki page. Otherwise I can't have adequate supervision. Second, It would be great if contributions were compiled under a tab in the profile section, so I could print out a copy of their wiki writing. Similar to seeing all their blogs at once, it would be great if that were available for wiki work. Third, the plans you have are great---very helpful. We have a Wiki Wednesday project where students can add research to several ongoing wiki projects. Fourth, would it be possible for a report to be generated on the number of wiki contributions made per student over a selected period of time (one semester)? This plus the opportunity to print out their work would be a great combination since I need both for an e-portfolio. Again, many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: +1 for Judy's sentiments about being able to view a student's contributions in one page - this is a question I've been asked many times about the 1.9 wiki, namely "how can I tell how much a student has contributed to the wiki across all pages". In my travels this is probably the most common improvement request with the wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ouff.. The user's contribution is a tricky thing to get right. In the forum is really easy, you just display the forum entries, and even those are out of its context (ouch!) the teacher can figure out what the student has been up to. But the wiki is a different beast. I could display an aggregated list of the text additions of the student (what you get on the diff window as brand new text (++)) and you could get some information here. But this would mean to just encourage the addition of new lines, and sometimes critical reading and careful modification of others lines can be a just as valuable contribution. Any ideas (or examples) of how to deal with it ? Thanks ! L.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is really exciting wiki enterprise. I agree with the sentiments outlined by colleagues, the quality vs quantity issue is allows important. In the first instance I would welcome a summary. Time logged in. Views (How many and average count between edits) / New pages / Page edits (self vs peers). Views: 23 - 8 hrs 23 mins. New pages created: 3 Page Edits: 6, Peer edits 4 Finally how to address the quality. This I am afraid is the educators duty but I would like to be able to grade on the two key contributions of self / peer edits. For two years 2004-6 we ran a 16-19year full time sports course through a wiki. Students readily made updates and keep their ownÂ individual pages. We also had wiki gardeners who casual made improvements to layout / spelling and some prolific authors. Once involved the students took a lot of pride in their wiki. We also had a few students who learnt alot from just reading and 'listening' to the heartbeat of the wiki. Time spent logged in is therefore, IMHO , important. I hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kristian, the time logged in is again a tricky issue. If we can assume all the students will wok on a javascript enabled browser (so, no accessibility problems) we could track the time logged in. And even in that case it would mean nothing. since most browsers use tabs (I often use the clickweel for click when browsing wikis, so all pages I visited are on one tab or other... then I have to clean the mess). Resuming : tracking time logged in on a web based wiki involves to many sources of noise that... better not to keep it. We can trace the number of views and edits and use timeframes to have more accurate averages. You introduce an interesting issue wich is the need to grade more than one aspect of the wiki activity. This has to be enabled somehow. Anyway the main idea is: Things happen in the wiki: stuends edit, view, restore pages, tag, comment and even rate pages in peer review... Then the teacher needs accurate reports to grade each competence and work done. Please keep the comments coming, its being really inetersting and useful. L.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... user contributions
ResponsesInList.Text: Regarding user contributions, perhaps it could be done as in MediaWiki with a history and diff link for each page edited. As the Moodle 2.0 release is very soon now, perhaps it could be added to the 2.1 to-do list.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... user contributions

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: At our school ourÂ  Moodle is called My Subjects. We've had it going since late 2004. Now most subjects use it to deliver their course material at least. Some subjects eg Drama use a Forum activity as part of their asessment. A good idea is to find others (in your school or environment) who want to try things and start with them. One of our librarians makes research pathways, and together the librarians have experimented with book quizzes. Our Year 6 teachers use the database to gather information for a Mathematics assignment, and another to allow students to present themselves as a fictional historical character. Also we are using the Datbase to get in assignments that we want other students to comment on, eg their games made in Flash, or PowerPoints on Body Sytems that can be used by other students for revision. Slowly slowly we are getting people to be more adventurous. We tried using a Wiki as a Reflective Journal/ diary but setting it up as student/No groups so that only they and the teachers could see it made it hard to view the wikis by class group. So we went back to using the text assignment rather that the plain Journal because the assignment module allows you to e-nag them if it isn't done. And strangely I often use the forum where I might have thought of using a wiki. But would beingÂ able to have a course in wiki formatÂ mean that the students could appear to have their own 'web pages' inside our My Subjects? That would be useful!! Is there some doco? Thanks, Sally

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would love to see an option to have a stand-alone wiki that is independent of any course. For example, to have a FAQ/Help wiki that could be accessible by anyone on the site without having to register for a course before being able to access the wiki. Pretty please.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?

Which is exactly the issue I have a problem with, that I don't want to force students to enrol just to access and edit the wiki. The solution that I came up with was to create the wiki on the front page with all registered users automatically enroled.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: There are 2 things I would find really helpful. One has already been mentioned but I'll list it again: RSS feed or other way to notify participants of updates to the wiki Updates highlighted or otherwise made more noticeable on the wiki page (so you don't have to search through the updates to see what's been changed) These are both features of googlewave. If you are not familiar with googlewave, it is google's new e-mail/wiki endeavor - it basically combines the power of e-mail and wiki. It is currently in its test phase. I have been trying to get teachers to use googlewave because it does have these features, but they don't like the idea of having so many different things to sign into (which I can understand). If the wiki in Moodle could do these two tasks, it would be fantastic!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Evaluating Wiki activities... what are your needs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much for your work on this and thanks for asking for feedback. We are using ouWiki, which is a big improvement over the default Wiki, but has one nearly unworkable flaw -- it is not possible to delete an existing page (or at least, I am unaware of any way to do so). So-presently, that's what I think of first in terms of improvements. I second the wish for RSS feeds for updates. A clean index in the manner of media wiki would be nice, as would support of a wide range of media types. Students don't rate one another's contributions, so that is not of much interest. Good luck!

ResponsesInList.Title: Since upgrading, texts link automatically to wikis
ResponsesInList.Text: Hallo, Since upgrading, a text which corresponds to the name of a wiki page, automatically links to the wiki... This is ennoying, because I can't (and don't want to) control how students call their wiki pages... I think this is good for glossary articles (it will usually be relevant) but not at all for wikis: usually, it won't be relevant at all (exemple: every time the word "notes" appears, it links to a wiki page called "NOTES", every time that the word "table" appears, it links to a wiki page called "TABLE").... Do you know how to avoid this auto-linking ? Thank you....! Ulrike

ResponsesInList.Title: precision
ResponsesInList.Text: Maybe this was not really clear: the links are EVERYWHERE, not only inside wikis.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: precision
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ulrike It sounds like words are linking to resources (not just the wiki) in courses. If this is the case and you don't want this check the Resource Names Auto-linking filter via Site â–º Administration â–º Modules â–º Filters â–º Manage filters If you're not the administrator of the site, check with that person. If this autolinking needs to be set at the site level you can use the 'prevent autolinking' button ( ) on the html editor to prevent this behaviour. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: precision
ResponsesInList.Text: Hallo Teresa, Thanks a lot for your answer ! I just checked it, and it's turned off; besides, the auto-linging is anywhere (in labels, for example). Would you have any other idea ? Should I turn off wiki-page auto-linking ?? Thank you...! Ulrike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: precision
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ulrike yes, I would suggest turning off Wiki Page Auto-linking and checking to see what happens. we have all of these Auto-linking options enabled and just teach our staff to prevent auto-linking using the icon on the html toolbar where required. Most staff like the auto-linking! Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: precision
ResponsesInList.Text: Hallo Teresa thanks a lot for helping me ! I thought that filter was necessary for wikis to work, but I turned it off, and everything is still working fine ! Auto-linking is a nice option, I agree - it's just that in my case, I couldn't decide anything (this happened after upgrading; before the texts didn't link and so I had never used the icon to avoid it - I hadn't even seen it :D). Thanks again ! Ulrike

ResponsesInList.Title: How to Start a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I just signed up and want to start a wiki for people who teach ESL 4. Previously, I was a member of a workshop that used the Moodle wiki. The instructions say to "click the "turn editing on" button. I believe I also read that I could find it after clicking on "administration." However, I can't find the page where I can click on "administration" or "turn editing on." Please help. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Start a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, Just about every editing command in Moodle needs you to turn the editing on. Log in to a course and look at the top right of the page. Next to your name should be a button "turn editing on". That means you will be able to add and edit resources and activities .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Start a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard. Just checking -when you say you "just signed up" - you don't mean that you are wanting to start a wiki on this site do you? This isn't for using Moodle with your classes/colleagues; this is for discussing and downloaing Moodle and that is why you don't see the administration or turn editing on links.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Start a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Whoops! Where do I need to go on the Moodle site to start a wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Start a Wiki

Although I've already started a Wiki page on my grad course for my students to keep a list of course-related resources ... But it is not, in my opinion, user friendly. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Start a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Bonnie and Richard, This forum I'm replying to you on, is part of Moodle.org where the users and creators of Moodle discuss and solve problems. It's not a Moodle site (platform, course) that you and your fellow teachers can control yourselves in your school/institution/university/... You need to have some technical knowledge to download and set up a copy of Moodle in your workplace. Once set up by a technical person, an ordinary teacher in their own Moodle course can usually work out (with some help from all the tutorials provided by Mary Cooch and others) how to add resources and (a little more difficult) activities such as forums, wikis, glossaries, chats and so on. I managed it and I'm just an English teacher. Cheers, Glenys

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Start a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Glenys, Thanks for your concern....However, my university already has Moodle in the workplace (I'm an online instructor at a major university; although I am only in my third month of this new endeavor ). I therefore, am a Moodle user . Maybe I posted my query on the wrong thread. I do believe I worked out my 'wiki' problems. It appears that the 'wiki' is self-contained in Moodle. At least that is how it looks on my course page. Students have been editing my wiki as well as creating their own. Now my next monumental problem is trying to figure out how my students can upload their assignments so that all other students can view (download) the assignments, then comment/reflect/evaluate on the assignments and give advice and brainstorm. ResponsesInList.Text: Bonnie: if you want your students to upload their assignments so everyone else can see them and comment on them then the simplest method to do this is to use a forum,

ResponsesInList.Title: searching ONLY current wiki version
ResponsesInList.Text: consider this scenario in wiki search: the search feature in wiki module searches inÂ all versions of the wiki , but,Â the search result displays only a link to the latest wiki version (current wiki) only , after the search process,Â when the user clicks on the result link (wiki link) it would display the current version only and the user may get confused because the current version may not contain the word he was searching for, but when the user navigates to history tab, and goes through old versions of the wiki, he will find the word he was searching for in one (or maybe more) old versions of the wiki (and of course the word will not be highlitedÂ for this case so the user would search for it manually). so for this scenario, the result must display links for old versions of the wiki if these versions contain the search word. so I thinkÂ the search wiki feature is unreasonable if this scenario happens (and it really happened with me), is there a way to search for wordsÂ ONLY inÂ the current version of wiki and then display the link for this wiki? should I change something in this line of code: if (! isset ( $_REQUEST [ "content" ]) && ( $dquery [ "version" ] = @ $_REQUEST [ "version" ])) { $dquery [ "forced_version" ] = $dquery [ "version" ]; } this line is on mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php file .. thank you so much in advance. P.S. moodle version 1.9.9

ResponsesInList.Title: Unable to see images uploaded by students
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a very strange problem. If a teacher uploads and inserts an image into wiki page, everything works as it should. The image is visible to all users, no matter which browser they use. A student can also upload /insert an image with no problem. But if she uses Internet Explorer (6, 7 or 8) to view the wiki page, the image (uploaded by her or other student) is not visible. If she uses Firefox , Chrome, Opera the image is visible. The Moodle in question runs on Windows server with IIS . Just as curiosity: on Linux/ Apache server everything works without problem. The CamelCase is disabled Does anyone have any idea?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to see images uploaded by students
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, I guess I found a solution for this problem. In the case of using [internal://image.png] for linking image in Wiki the IIS server sends the reply to browser's image request with status 302 in the header. Since there is no Locaton field in the header IE doesn't display the image as it wants to redirect. Other browsers apparently ignore the status 302 since there is no Location field and the image (which they actually expect from the server) is in the body of the reply. In the same scenario Apache sends the reply with status 200. The setting to change, in order to get things working is enable cgi.nph and set it to 1: from php.ini ; if cgi.nph is enabled it will force cgi to always sent Status: 200 with ; every request. cgi.nph = 1 Additional information: nph stands for non parsing headers. In our particular situation it would allow CGI to print Status: 200 header, which is normally skipped as it is not needed in most situations. Source link. With cgi.nph = 0, no status header is output unless you invoke header(), and then only if your status code isn't 200. With cgi.nph = 1, a status header is always output, defaulting to 200 if header() is not invoked. Source link. Should I create a bug report for this or there is nothing to change in Moodle code?

ResponsesInList.Title: NWiki: create wiki , student and grous out of a template: documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: This is an old request for wikis. To be able to create a wiki (simple, groups or students ) starting with a wiki template (a set of pages exported). The version that Pigui is going to release (due yesterday ) includes this feature. This is the documentation that the developer: Esther Galimany has prepared. In our documentation site that we will eventually move to moodle docs (anyway is written in mediawiki markup ) I copy and paste. Wiki template TABLE OF CONTENTS: 1. How to create a template 1.1. Step 1: create content 1.2. Step 2: create template 1.3. Step 3: choose options template 1.4. Step 4: confirmation template 2. How to create a new wiki with template 2.1. Step 1: adding a new Wiki 2.2. Step 2: choose folder wikitemplate 2.3. Step 3: choose template How to create a template Step 1: create content Create wiki and insert the content, the name of wiki isn't important because, when you import the template in a new wiki, you can choose the real name of wiki. For example: Step 2: create template Choose the option Create template in the block Wiki-Administration Tools Step 3: choose options template Choose the options of the template into a form. You can choose that all pages or only some pages will be added to template. You can choose if you want historic, blocks configuration, votes and synonymous too. And name of wiki template, the destination is fixed. Step 4: confirmation template Confirmation that the template has been created succesfully. Press continue and return to view of wiki. when you want you can use the template in a new wiki, in the moment of creation the wiki. How to create a new wiki with template Step 1: adding a new Wiki Into the form to creation or adding a new wiki, after the name, summary and firts page name you see the next parameter in the form: Content from template . Under this there ara a button to choose the concret template with a popup menu. Step 2: choose folder wikitemplate Into the popup menu choose the folder wikitemplate Step 3: choose template Into the folder wikitemplate, choose the folder of course that contains the template, and click in the word Choose the concret template that you want. IMPORTANT! if you wiki are wiki with groups, the template will be replicated automatically for every group. Step 4: finish the creation wiki when you are finished the creation wiki, press Save Changes, and your wiki will be contain the content of your template. If is wiki with groups every group have a wiki content of template. But every group have your wiki. That's it. comming up more new features for the future moodle wiki Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Evolution and support for Wiki 2.x
ResponsesInList.Text: Wiki 2.x is on Moodle 2.0. Jordi Piguillem (Pigui) and I will be working on its evolution, support and maintenance. Future developments, features, documentation and other things will be organized in the tracker under the Wiki 2.x component and usually assigned to my user ( http://tracker.moodle.org/secure/ViewProfile.jspa?name=granludo ). Now I'm getting the house in order, but soon the tracker will show up very much the current Wiki 2.x roadmap and priorities. So this forum and the tracker will be the way to report bugs, issues, and request features. Please let's use the "tag" Wiki 2.x because we happen to have a bunch of wikis.

ResponsesInList.Title: New Wiki in Moodle 2.0 Beta ... and a big todo list
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, as our dear knight in shinny armor point out, the new wiki is on Moodle 2.0 http://git.moodle.org/gw?p=moodle.git;a=commit;h=00710f4cc17c9519c02dd2c4a7fa7c1dd8545dbf Yay! OK, New wiki is in. Now there's a lot of work to do. Due to quality and process matters, the new wiki comes in with significant parts disabled or pending to be completed. So now comes the real challenge. We have a new wiki we can improve and maintain, so we can make it a great learning tool. So, the current todolist: - NWiki migration. New wiki does not migrate from nwiki at this moment. I'm commited to make this migration happen before summer. My best option is to publish a pre-update migration script that will convert NWiki tables into old wiki tables, so the standard New Wiki can migrate it without changing its code.

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I have OUwiki open in a seperate window?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using ouwiki for teaching grammer and want it to open in a seperate window so that it easily accessable for reference. I tried making a wiki then using copying the html link using add a resource --link to file or web page using the wiki link went back and hid the original wiki then using the link tried opening it as a seperate webpage. but i get sorry this is hidden. any suggestions for getting OUwiki to open in a seperate window appreciated alister

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I have OUwiki open in a seperate window?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alister I think the problem may be that you hid the original wiki. Instead of doing that move it to an unseen (not a hidden) topic. To do this, say your course normally has 12 topics and the OUWiki and the Resource Link you created are all in Topic 12. In the course settings change the number of topics to 13. Move your OU wiki to Topic 13, but don't hide it nor Topic 13. (Leave the resource link in Topic 12) Now go back to course settings and change the number of topics back to 12. Topic 13 still exists and is still available (not hidden), as are all the items it holds - including the OUWiki. But you can access them only if you know the link to those resources. With most resources you can just use its link but OUWiki doesn't give an option to open in a new page, so this is why you need the resource link you created (and left in Topic 12) which does have the option to open in a new page. Make sure the resource link is defined to open in a new page. Clicking on the resource link in Topic 12 will open the OUWiki (contained in the unseen Topic 13) in a new window. You can use this trick with any resource, allowing you more freedom to layout the format of your Moodle pages to look more like a normal web page (rather than one line per resource). You can also link across to other courses (if the users are also enrolled in them, or if those courses have guest access) and also to resources held in the front page course which is public. This is very useful. What I haven't been able to figure out is how to bring up a wiki (or any resource) without the Moodle header so it can be made to sit in an iframe in another Moodle resource such as a web page or label. This would allow you to embed the wiki beside a video, for example, or beside a quiz. Regards, Mike Smith, Brisbane, Australia

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I have OUwiki open in a seperate window?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mike, I will try the methods you have outlined here. Hopefully I can create a course with guest access to hold the wiki and then link to the wiki accross courses without the problem of students not being able to see images etc. I assume I can just make the course itself not visable so it doesn't appear on the list of available courses. Or will the course itself have to be visable? Must try this out I want one central wiki available to all as a grammar reference. finding a way to open a resource without a moodle header is something I want too. this would be very useful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I have OUwiki open in a seperate window
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alister, It's an interesting idea. You could create you wiki course that has guest access or you could simply enroll everyone into the student role, or other roles depending on whether you want them to have edit/delete/add privileges. If you want the course to be available but not be visible in the Courses Area that seems to be a bit trickier. Other moodlers may have better ideas, but I can only suggest that you set the site-wide property "courses visible in hidden categories" and then make a hidden category for all your resource-only courses. However this may upset other things in your moodle, for example other teachers relying on this property to hide their courses. You also need administrator privileges to do this. A better solution might be to let anyone see the course and enter it, but use the same trick to put everything inside into unseen (not hidden) topics. That way you can put an explanatory introduction into topic zero and direct people back to where they should go. Another possibility is instead of allowing guest access to the wiki, play with the authenticated user role and over-ride permissions. Guest access allows anyone even without an account, whilst authenticated user limits access to people having accounts on your system (i.e. your students). To make use of this, you give guest access to the course (but put the wiki into an unseen topic). Then in the wiki settings go to Override Permissions and set the View Wiki property to Prevent for the Guest roles, and then for the Authenticated User role set the properties as you wish (e.g. view but not edit, or comment only etc). Override Permissions are an incredibly powerful way to fine-tune what people can and cannot do, as you will see. However it can quickly get complicated as it all works in a heirarchy in moodle. You need to carefully test with dummy accounts in those roles to see if it all works as you intend. Also, I often forget what overrides have been set for resources so I advise you to be careful and document what you do so you can remember it months later. By the way, do you actually want people to edit your wiki and be able to add pages, or just add their comments? Just adding comments is probably best unless you're using the wiki as a collaborative learning tool - a learning project in itself. Finally, if you're doing an English grammar wiki then a giant in the field is Ruth Vilmi. See her blog here: http://www.writeit.fi/ruth/writeit-resources-grammar/ Regards, Mike

ResponsesInList.Text: Uh-oh! Soapbox time...... [Steve, this is not ad hominem so please don't take it that way......] While there are obviously continuing issues with nWiki, and I don't think anyone thinks that open software should intentionally anger users of COTS, I always have to respond to such arguments by asking the proponent why they think that it is appropriate for open software to go out of its way to support entities insistent on using commercial software created by vendors determined to eschew not only standards but the very concept of open software..... <rant> There is a great solution for those who are committed to COTS, and it is called BlackBoard! Now don't get me wrong, I think trying to make software as open as possible is WONDERFUL.... but am I going to abandon MathML (a W3C standard) simply because IE and Safari can't do it? Unlikely..... If the Enterprise has decided to it imprison its participants technologically, that is the Enterprise's choice, and it is as simple to add an alternative browser to an image as it is to roll the image out in the first place. Frankly I'd like to see a published article that suggests that instruction to National Health employees had to be terminated because the government would not provide those employees either with working COTS tools or adequate desktop tools to take advantage of open software apps like Moodle. Maybe Mikey Moore could do a sequel about how Britain's marriage to MS is choking some otherwise great social efforts to death?? Hard to believe that a place so far advanced from your US counsins in health care has tied those advances to such a regressive IT policy. </rant> But then I don't speak for Moodle and this discussion should probably be had in the Lounge....
