ResponsesInList.Title: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
ResponsesInList.Text: In a point in time Skodak decided not not support separate student wikis... and all the UPC team exclaimed "Yay!" and we had a beer to celebrate it. Separate student wikis create weird dilemmas to deal with, because students enroll and unenroll. And yet, pedagogically, there is no point to have a non collaborative wiki going on. So we don't support it... Yay! But... there are separate student wikis out there in Moodle 1.x wikis and even on nwiki setups. So... We cannot throw away that content or somebody will be mad at me. The proposed solution : - we create a group with the teacher(s) and the student owner of the wiki, and place the content there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
ResponsesInList.Text: My reasoning was that other modules also need this mode of operation - "separate students". Since 1.9 we have the groupings that were designed to extend the uses of groups and allow exactly this. It is still marked as experimental, but groupings will be enabled in all 2.0 (only groupmemebrsonly will be kept experimental). The workflow would be pretty simple, first go to group admin UI and let Moodle create new grouping with one group for each user in the course. Then create a new wiki and set the grouping there. Everybody will have his/her own wiki. This should be fairly easy for upgrades too. If we decide to implement separate student wikis the problems are: * a lot more access control + more complex db structure * we need new UI for user selection so that teachers may actually access the user wikis * we need to handle cases where users are enrolled/unenrolled in the middle of the course * we can not change the mode of wiki from user to group * other modules need to do the same in order to keep consistency The coding and maintenance costs would be higher, on the other hand we would have a feature that probably no other wiki has and probably very few ppl use in the real life, also the UI would be cluttered with extra controls and the wiki would not be consistent with the rest of our modules. I personally think we should stop abusing modules for something they are not designed for, wiki is by definition a collaboration tool, so we should imo encourage group work in wiki and just describe potential workaround in case somebody really wants to use them in a different way. If somebody needs a personal notepad with wiki syntax support, it could be a My Moodle(dashboard) block. We should also concentrate on grading of work done by students in wikis, this could be best done as new gradebook reports that other modules may share. Another example is the Forum module, it could be hacked to support one-on-one teacher-student communication, but it would be an ugly hack with many problems, so instead I created the new consultation module. News forum type is yet another example of problematic - there are so many differences in news and forum discussions that it will be significantly easier to create News module instead of trying to fix the current new forum subtype. We had a little disagreement with Martin over this issue, unfortunately I do not remember if I managed to persuade hit the last time we discussed this ;-)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
ResponsesInList.Text: As I said Petr... Yay! For me the only issue is the migration, so no data gets lost, and I think we have pretty much covered it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everybody, I want to link to a specific part of an external page like this: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Wikis#Creative_Wiki_practices If I add a link like this inside a wiki page, it links only to the first part of the link ( http://docs.moodle.org/en/Wikis ) but omits the anchor (#Creative_Wiki_practices). (By the way, we have the same problem on this page. Just look at the first link above.) Is there a solution to my problem? Thank you for your answers! Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text: We used to be able to specify anchors within Moodle 1.8.x, e.g. [ https://eureka.westmont.edu/mod/wiki/view.php?id=2848&page=FAQ+-+Students#nopasswd ] . (This is a live, public page.) However, apparently since upgrading to 1.9.2+, when a wiki page is edited either in HTML mode or using WYSIWYG HTML editor, all anchors are stripped from the resulting code, leaving only <a></a> where <a name=nopasswd></a> should be. Previous versions of the page in the mysql database have the proper anchor tags. Anyone else seeing this problem? John Rodkey

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm having this problem, does anyone know if there was a fix? r.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
ResponsesInList.Text:
For the record I discovered the following: HTMLpurifier was casuing this problem. I had to update HTMLPurifier Lite to Version 4 and then I added 
```text
$config->set('Attr', 'EnableID', true);
$config->set('Attr', 'EnableAttrID', true);

to the constructor in HTMLPurifier.php

Anchors work perfectly and the formating of my page is retained!

R.
```

ResponsesInList.Title: About grades , grading on wiki 2.0 ... philosophy and requirements of ongoing development
ResponsesInList.Text: Two years ago I met Martin D. at Heidelberg during a nice german Moodlemoot (from which the we spaniards took some ideas for our moots), to discuss wiki 2.0 (back then!). One of the topics was Grading on Wikis. We also debated this topic with skodak when he visited UPC. Now that I the Wiki 2.0 looks stable enough to build "fancy" features upon here are my philosophy principles and requirements for the develoment that is starting as soon as Wiki 2.0 hits the moodle head cvs . --- Its not obvious and easy to define how to grade a Wiki activity. What is clear is that there are as many ways to do it as teachers willing to. So everithing I describe needs to be optional and customizable "a la Moodle" (As pigui says in every meeting "use the moodle built in scales and don't invent new things") --- We have two different sets of "things" to evaluate: - Pages. And its evolution. Its what I will call "page rating" and "page progress rating " - Grades. Wich are related to he work done for one student, and how does THE TEACHER consider that should be evaluated (and bound to the moodle grading engine... and all its complexity) Page ratings and page progress activity. --------------------------------

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: About grades , grading on wiki 2.0 ... philosophy and requirements of ongoing development
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo, and thanks for bringing this topic to the list at this (still) development stage. I would suggest two things: (1) that somehow the " type of contribution " concept (i.e., "Adding information", "summarizing information", "formulating new hypothesis", "improving markup", ...) is added as a multiple select box to the wiki edit interface. (2) And that the size (b, kb, ...) of the new contribution is recorded . This way, basic information about " quality " and " quantity " of information can be reviewed later on by faculty, provided that the report tool allows that in the future. So that we can keep track of student activity (single students and average per group): not only the number of clicks (page views, page edits, etc.), but the quantity and quality of that information added or deleted by each student/group of students. As you know, , at University of Barcelona we did some research about this field, and we found out that this type of information is EXTREMELY useful for teachers before attending a tutoriship session with students (with individual students or in groups). Of course, some short training & feedback has to given to students in the first weeks so that they know what the "type of contributions" are for, and how to select the right ones, etc. (the faculty should be able to edit the records of those "type of contributions" to avoid misuse and pollution in the database of actions, which will be used later on by him/her and other faculty to provide feedback, grade students, etc.) --- And on another stage, that information about "type of contributions" should be linkable to the "outcomes" that we expect the students to acquire with the course activities . The goal for this is two fold: a) we promote that students see/remember the outcomes that we want them to work/acquire through the learning activities (promoting experiential - reflective learning is social-constructivist scenarios - their mates see also how their mates indicate what their are doing, so they learn from this metacognitive process from themselves and their mates) b) we help (allow/ease...) faculty to assess student activity along the course, and not just at the end when they have the final version of the wiki finished/delivered at the assignment deadline. This helps single teachers to review in short what has happenend (in order of magnitude) for a given time frame with single students or whole group/s, looking and some summary graphs/tables. And students have the change to report better who where they working with when they submitted something to the wiki (or to the forum, spreadsheet, etc...) Once this is implemented in Moodle, if others see it interesting for their use cases with wikis inside educational scenarios (opinions?), I would expect any automatic grading at the gradebook, but just a new column at the gradebook, and yes, some automatic feeding of a new table with students in raws, and type of contributions in columns, with the size of the change as value in the cells, for a given time frame selected by the theacher. With that, we can let every teacher convert the activity of students into a grade for the gradebook. Does it make sense for you? Ok, enough for my suggestion of improvements (from the perspective of a faculty not using Moodle yet with my students when I need to use wikis for real). I wish someday I can use also Moodle for that (without having to clikc in so many places to have a broad idea of what has been happening with the activity of my students). For those interested, more details and examples of graphs/tables of summary data of "quality and quantity" of contributions by students (and groups) using some other free software tools, can be read at: * " New Method Using Wikis and Forums to Evaluate Individual Contributions in Cooperative Work while Promoting Experiential Learning : Results from Preliminary Experience " X. de Pedro. WikiSymâ€™07 October 21â€“23, 2007, MontrÃ©al, QuÃ©bec, Canada. http://www.wikisym.org/ws2007/_publish/dePetro_WikiSym2007_ContributionsInCooperativeWork.pdf Alternatively, there is a longer and more detailed report (In Spanish): * â€œEstimulaciÃ³n y evaluaciÃ³n del aprendizaje 'experiencial-reflexivo' del alumnado mediante la formulaciÃ³n explÃ­cita del tipo de contribucionesâ€. Grupo de trabajo sobre Aprendizaje Reflexivo (ICE-UB 2006). http://www.ub.edu/gclub/dl55 Hope this helps Xavi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: About grades , grading on wiki 2.0 ... philosophy and requirements of ongoing development
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for our insights Xavier, about 1: This could be gathered thought "a summary field" bellow the edit box and assigned to each page edit. so each contributor can assert what kind of participation is going on. also a good idea for reflection on what the heck I'm doing right now. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure that I can solve your problem, Jim, but I have done what you are trying to do before when creating a simple ePortfolio. I created the page in a Wiki, toggled to the html code and then copied and pasted this into a Word document. I saved this as Text Only and left off the extension (as the final wiki used this file name as the name of each student's wiki). I uploaded this into Files and then created the new Wiki, selecting this file to create the initial page. It worked for me..... regards, Kate

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunately, the current erfurtwiki (I assume that is what you are using, but if it is not you need to let us know that ASAP) is really not adequately documented and the fact that a new wiki has been adopted does not encourage investing time in the current one. One of the sources of continuing confusion with respect to student wikis is that once the teacher creates the student wiki, and attempt to edit the wiki's first page will only impact the teacher's instance. Can't tell if this is what you are confronted with, but this is often the source of confusion. As Kate suggests, there is a method that is, well, a bit obscured for creating student wikis that allows for multiple pages, but it also might help you to see the difference.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: We've run into that problem as well -- faculty can't edit a "student" wiki. We've had to use these 'not too intuitive' settings -- "group" wiki set to "no groups". There doesn't seem to be any way to edit wiki type once it's been set up... best to you, deb

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jim you have probably solved or given up on this one, but I had a similar problem and eventually worked it out. You do indeed set up an initial folder, with one or more of the pages that you would like the wiki to be pre-populated with in that folder. The files must be text format but they should have no file extension. You then upload them to wherever you need, create the wiki activity, select the specific file you want to start with. All pages created with the links in square brackets work because they point to files with identical names (e.g. [foo] will successfully create and link to a file called foo, but not one called foo.txt. So obvious once I thought about it but at least it is here for anyone else searching on this problem. Cheers Ed

ResponsesInList.Title: ouwiki new release
ResponsesInList.Text: (For those who are not familiar with it, the OU wiki is an alternative wiki for Moodle 1.9. It does not replace the standard wiki but is an additional option. It works with the HTML editor instead of wiki markup and is designed to be user-friendly and simple.) I have done an updated release of the OU wiki today. Read information and get it here Not many new features but it does include bugfixes, including the one Glenys posted about in this forum! If you had problems trying to install an older version, please give this one a go. For those wondering what's happening in future, there are no major changes on the horizon. We are planning to add a couple more administrative features - including the ability to revert to a previous version without having to copy/paste it - in the autumn. Also just a note - I am posting this to the wiki forum because it seemed most appropriate, but I don't actually read the wiki forum (obviously, we have our own wiki, so most of it is not relevant). I'll try to remember to keep an eye on this post for the next few days. However, if you need to report a bug, please contact me directly by email/Moodle private message. --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: MediaWiki Module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I have created a very simple module that allows you to add MediaWiki links as activities to courses. You simply set the url of your MediaWiki installation in the module settings, then add a wiki to your course. The name you choose is then added to the url you provided and the page is displayed in an iframe. For example, using the url ' http://wiki.example.com/index.php/' and the name 'Main Page', the following url is displayed in an iframe: http://wiki.example.com/index.php/Main Page MediaWiki (+browser?) is clever enough to tidy up the url, e.g. add '_' instead of spaces. Also, if the page does not previously exist then MediaWiki is clever enough to show you the edit links etc. This module's main intention is to provide a neat way to link to existing MediaWiki pages, with most administration still taking place within MediaWiki. Please let me know if you find it useful (we do!), or have any other feedback. As far as authentication is concerned, we are using transparent NTLM authentication so the user will not need to enter login details. I have not tested with the Moodle login plugin, but i would imagine it would work just as well, with the obvious drawback of the user having to enter their credentials yet another time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML Editor Insert Image upload problem in dfwiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Tom, as you know I have been working on this problem. This, for the benefit of every one else, is a list of key facts for students uploading pictures. 1) it accepts .jpg, .gif and .png file formats 2) max file size is about 65KB 3) Picture resolution / size does not appear to be a factor 4) use lowercase filenames 5) avoid spaces in filenames 6) if several students using different wikis want to upload the same picture they must make sure each occurance of the picture has a different file name. 7) It works with Internet Explorer 5.5 or greater and firefox 1.0.7. Not certain about later versions of firefox (sorry) 8) If you run Windows XP there is a useful 'powertoy' you can download which makes it easy to shrink .jpg files. Download here: http://download.microsoft.com/download/whistler/Install/2/WXP/EN-US/ImageResizerPowertoySetup.exe Has anyone else found anything which affects students uploading pictures? Regards, Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML Editor Insert Image upload problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, When the wiki is created, the allow binary files option must be set to 'yes'. The filename you want to upload must be in lower case letters AND the file extension must be in lower case letters (.jpg NOT .JPG) Warning: MS Paint creates file extensions with upper case letters You must allow popup windows in your browser I have attached my training notes for you.... Regards, Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML Editor Insert Image upload problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I am with the Liverpool Hope University . One of the course leaders uses Wiki's to run her course and she contacted me saying it was extremely important that the students be able to upload images into the wikis.We are currently usking OUWikis and the above mentioned problem seems to be plauging us all. The problem with us was that the students were about to turn their assignments in, and it was at the very last moment that the course leader realized that they couldnt upload images. She contacted us immediately but we had no more than a day to fix this. So we came up with this solution: We customized the code so that the student were allowed to upload images from their computer to a local folder within the htdocs folder and then automatically insert the image link in the textbox for the image url, then the student can proceed with the normal process of aligning the image etc, and go about his normal work. Screentshot : http://img201.imageshack.us/img201/7265/image1ut5.jpg Screenshot2: http://img201.imageshack.us/img201/4624/image2rn6.jpg Screenshot 1 shows the Upload image popup box for students. When the browse button is click they will be shown a browse dialog to select the files on their computer. Once they select a file the local file path will be populated in the box. They then click on the upload button which uploads the picture on a folder on the webserver. The image name is hashed along with the time ( (md5(time() . $file_uploaded) . $file_ext). This makes sure that any file that is uploaded is given a unique name.Â  The file upload is done in a different windows (form submit points to -> upload_image.php). Once the image has been uploaded, the new windows inserts the image path into the child window's text box (javascript opener.document.form.f1.f_url.value = http://moodle.university.com/uploaded_images/hashed_value.jpg ). Once that is done, the new window closes itself, the student will barely notice a new window opening, however in IE, it does ask the student confirmation to allow the window to close itself. Once the window closes, the Image URL box is populated with the new image url, as seen in Screenshot2. The student then adjusts the image borders and spacing and clicks on OK button. Thats it. The image is inserted as usual. Its not the most elegant solution but it seems to get the job done for the moment and it doesnt display the entire course folder to the student preventing them from modifying or deleting any of the course files. Because the images are stored within the htdocs folder, they are backed up along with the rest of the moodledata. I am waiting for official permission to post the code online for everyone to see but meanwhile I wouldnt mind helping people in this regard. Feel free to message me. Regards Ciph

ResponsesInList.Title: How I can put math formulas into Wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: For example this one $$\sqrt[m]{n}$$ Preview shows an error

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How I can put math formulas into Wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Those 2 images are in you local PC ( Users/yulia/AppData/Local/Temp/moz-screenshot-1.png and Users/yulia/AppData/Local/Temp/moz-screenshot.png ) but Wiki has problems with square brackets so your tex notation \sqrt[m]{n} will fail in Wiki One workaround is to use AsciiMathML (see other discussions) where that root is written as `rootm ( n )` or `rootm{n}` or `root{m}{n}`... You could also try external mathtran pasted to address field of image plugin and http://www.mathtran.org/cgi-bin/mathtran?D=3;tex=\root m \of {n} which should give also in Wiki without square brackets (change D smaller than 3 if you need smaller size.. Or you could use images (again)...

ResponsesInList.Title: Ending student additions to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If I have ran a group wiki and all the student have contributed. Can I stop further students contributing after a deadline of the assignment. I also want the students to see the finished product. Is this possible? MAny thanks, Darren Hitchen

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ending student additions to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Darren, You can prevent students from editing the wiki by overriding permissions for the student role and setting the capability mod/wiki:participate to 'prevent'. Please see Override permissions for more details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ending student additions to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Excellent. I have applied the settings. Thanks for the help, Darren

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What's the best way to make an FAQ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Murrary One popular FAQ I have used and seen work well is the Glossary Module . It has an FAQ display type so the concept is the question and the definition is the answer. You can then have key words and categories. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What's the best way to make an FAQ?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Murray, I think it depends on how much knowledge they're going to need. If it's just a simple idea of how it works then you could put a simple guide (or make a simple webpage) for topic 0, the heading, in your course. If it's an institution front page then there's usually space to modify the greeting (right-hand side on the standard Moodle). I've made up a couple of Word documents I link to so students can see how to operate the system (basic version) and gain better understanding of/access to e-learning (advanced version). Hope that helps, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: I am running a translation class, where the students progressively will (I hope) revise their translations of Vergil's Aeneid (or at least the parts on the AP syllabus). I want them weekly to submit their latest translations including the new lines for the next week, but also any revisions they make to their previous efforts. I want to be able to see any changes they make, and to be able to trace any versions back to their original efforts, in case I suspect plagiarism. I considered using the multiple file option of the assignment task, and allow them to resubmit any number of new files (versions), but it seems that a better option might be to use the wiki and have history to show me the versions. A couple of issues occur to me: Will I get notifications when they change things? And will this be too much, if they edit online? Is it possible to compare arbitrary versions of a page, like on mediawiki, or is it just two sequential versions? Can I take a snapshot on the due date, to be sure that assignments are properly characterized as on-time or late? Is this the best way to do all this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: Did no one have an opinion on this question?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: 1. The wiki won't send you notifications, but it will keep a record of changes and the times. 2. I believe you can compare any two versions (or at least any past version with the present) 3. You can go to the last edit made on the due date and see the work done. The wiki module hasn't totally impressed me and I hear it will be getting a big update in Moodle 2.0. You cold have them work on a wiki and then every week have them copy the current version and paste it into an online text asasignment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes I agree that a wiki is your best bet for managing successive versions. We use OU Wiki because the NanoGong HTMLArea works with it (Moodle 1.93 - you should test this first in other versions) allowing audio annotations which might be useful for translation feedback. The wiki allows comparisons between any two previous versions (not just sequential versions), and it also allows you to revert to any previous version. The only downside is that it doesn't have a mechanism for assessment/grading, but then perhaps taking a snapshot copy and submitting it in a proper assignment might be better as it would generate a gradebook entry. An alternative to the wiki might be a forum (which is gradable), but this would only be practical for shorter texts. Regards, Mike Smith, Brisbane

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki goes to blank page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi mike, even I solved a similar problem in the german forum.Â  I found the following explanation. In the Wiki code are several words defined as Interwiki-Links. If you name the Wiki with one of this words followed by an ":" it is linked to an other page in the web. Try it with "Wiki:" or "ISBN:". If you don't use such words in the wikiname or no ":" you can use the wiki normaly. Below are the word I found in the code: "ErfurtWiki" => " http://erfurtwiki.sourceforge.net/?id= ", "InterWiki" => "InterWikiSearch", "InterWikiSearch" => " http://sunir.org/apps/meta.pl? ", "Wiki" => "WardsWiki", "WardsWiki" => " http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki? ", "WikiFind" => " http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?FindPage&value= ", "WikiPedia" => " http://www.wikipedia.com/wiki.cgi? ", "MeatBall" => "MeatballWiki", "MeatballWiki" => " http://www.usemod.com/cgi-bin/mb.pl? ", "UseMod"Â Â Â Â Â Â  => " http://www.usemod.com/cgi-bin/wiki.pl? ", "PhpWiki" => " http://phpwiki.sourceforge.net/phpwiki/index.php3? ", "LinuxWiki" => " http://linuxwiki.de/ ", "OpenWiki" => " http://openwiki.com/? ", "Tavi" => " http://andstuff.org/tavi/ ", "TWiki" => " http://twiki.sourceforge.net/cgi-bin/view/ ", "MoinMoin" => " http://www.purl.net/wiki/moin/ ", "Google" => " http://google.com/search?q= ", "ISBN" => " http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ISBN= ", "icq" => " http://www.icq.com/ ",

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki goes to blank page
ResponsesInList.Text: Please ignore my previous question. We found the source of this problem. I think it is a special feature of ewiki but it was never documented (as far as I know) in moodle documents. The problematic code is the /mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php and if you comment out the "Wiki" => "WardsWiki", then the problem will be solved. There is this array which has a lot of "InterWiki:Links" which I believe that not necessarily useful for all users: " javascript " => "",Â  # this actually protects from javascript: links "url" => "", #Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  "self" => "this", "this" => EWIKI_SCRIPT,Â  # better was absolute _URL to ewiki wrapper "jump" => "", "ErfurtWiki" => " http://erfurtwiki.sourceforge.net/?id= ", "InterWiki" => "InterWikiSearch", "InterWikiSearch" => " http://sunir.org/apps/meta.pl? ", #Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  "Wiki" => "WardsWiki", "WardsWiki" => " http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki? ", "WikiFind" => " http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?FindPage&value= ", "WikiPedia" => " http://www.wikipedia.com/wiki.cgi? ", "MeatBall" => "MeatballWiki", "MeatballWiki" => " http://www.usemod.com/cgi-bin/mb.pl? ", "UseMod"Â Â Â Â Â Â  => " http://www.usemod.com/cgi-bin/wiki.pl? ", "PhpWiki" => " http://phpwiki.sourceforge.net/phpwiki/index.php3? ", "LinuxWiki" => " http://linuxwiki.de/ ", "OpenWiki" => " http://openwiki.com/? ", "Tavi" => " http://andstuff.org/tavi/ ", "TWiki" => " http://twiki.sourceforge.net/cgi-bin/view/ ", "MoinMoin" => " http://www.purl.net/wiki/moin/ ", "Google" => " http://google.com/search?q= ", "ISBN" => " http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ISBN= ", "icq" => " http://www.icq.com/ ", And if you happen to have any of the above showing in the wiki title (e.g., ISBN , ta-da! then you will have a problem. Just a quick FYI . I guess the moodle team did not try to clean up the codes when it (Erfurt Wiki) got integrated with Moodle, oh boy..

ResponsesInList.Title: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I know wikis are usually collaborative but is is possible to create a wiki for each individual student in a course. I want them to have a place to document their own private goals. Their goals may change as they move through the course so I want them to be able to make changes to their wiki. Some of the goals may be sensitive so I want them to feel obligated to share with the group. Is it possible to set permissions for a wiki page which relates to the student log in? Hope this makes sense. Help appreciated. Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Lets say it is a graduate group of only (say) 15 students. Create groups with one student in the group and assign wiki to groups. Lets say it is an undergraduate group of 200. Are you planning to read them all?? Probably this won't work. Is a wiki overkill? Here is another option: You could use an online text assignment, CALL it a journal, which is editiable on one page an unlimited number of times. It really functions like a one editor, one page wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks - I'll go the text assignment. Cheers! Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ann The Online Text assignment would work well with this, If used it successfully in the past. You should warn your students to be careful that they don't accidentally remove existing text with each successive edit. I always recommended that students keep a backup in a Word document just in case! An alternative is the Dialogue module with allows private Teacher to Student communication however students can just keep adding entries, which are all date/time stamped. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Private Wiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: theme issue with OU wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks! You are correct. Sorry about that - we should have spotted it because it causes pages to fail the HTML validator. I have fixed this in the official code - and also fixed 2 other validation errors (which may not have been doing any harm, but you never know). Now the page validates fully. Bug is CONTRIB-1370 and fixed ouwiki version is 2009062200. By the way - thanks to Helen for passing this on to me! I'm afraid I am not subscribed to this forum because most of the discussion is not related to OU wiki, so it would really help if you could report ouwiki problems using the tracker. If you select 'contributed code' to start with, and then 'Module: OU wiki' in the component field, it will go straight to me. (Of course I welcome forum discussions as well, you can link these in the bug if you want me to read them!) (If there's something that isn't a bug but just a discussion about ouwiki that you'd like me involved in, um, let me know!) --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: Heads up: Wiki 1.x interwiki disabled by default
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, wiki 1.x (the one distributed as part of Moodle 1.x core), has one undocumented feature: interwiki links. And it has been there, anonymously, since the beginning of the module. Recently we "discovered" ( MDL-19460 ) it was causing some annoyances to pages named "Wiki: whatever" and others, causing the module to automatically redirect to other URLs (interwiki ones). As long as the feature is an undocumented one (and unsupported) we have decided to disable it by default. So starting next weekly build (June 17th 2009) those interwiki links won't be working anymore under Moodle 1.x. In any case, as last resort... if somebody was using such feature it's possible to enable it again by defining: $CFG->wiki_allow_interwiki = true;

ResponsesInList.Title: How sweet the sound
ResponsesInList.Text:
We now have proof of concept. Of course, this will have been no secret to you old dab hands, but for me it's cause to say I've had a good day and I'll do the rest tomorrow. The relevant relational tables are _wiki, _course_modules and _course_sections. First, you add an entry for the wiki instance (wiki id) in _course_modules. Second, you assign the _course_module id a place in the desired section in course_sections. I may write all this up more cogently tomorrow or the next day, after I've successfully repeated the process a few times and can be sure I haven't misconcatenated or otherwise garbled the process. Just to repeat for my own benefit, The tables are _wiki _course_modules _course_sections The ids are wiki module course section The tables and pairs are
To be continued.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE / MediaWiki integration
ResponsesInList.Text: See this thread: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=44205 I'm using MediaWiki for a project alongside MOODLE, that requires authentication off the MOODLE users database for editing privileges.Â  Similar to what MoodleDocs is doing for Moodle.org.Â  This is intended to be a world-readable "wikipedia"-like project and portal, edited/maintained by my moodle-registered user community.Â  It's linked from my MOODLE site, but is not a course resource. I have both the dfWiki and the built-in Moodle Wiki modules (& am playing with the new "Wiki" wiki in beta from the dfWiki folks) available for use as course resources on my sites; either or both can be added as a course resource by instructors.Â  I'd suggest installing them both, playing with them a bit, & seeing which suites your purpose(s) better.Â  The Wiki module included with the standard MOODLE package is very simple (=sometimes the best choice, depending on what is needed).Â  dfWiki offers many more features, & the dfWiki course format - which structures a course around a Wiki - is a very nice feature, if this is what you need. will taylor moodle-master at the National College of Naturopathic Medicine Portland, Oregon/US

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE / MediaWiki integration
ResponsesInList.Text: For this purpose, I don't see any downsides.Â  I have MediaWiki integrated now with Moodle versions 1.5.3 and 1.6, very easy to set up.Â  Users need to log in separately to MediaWiki to edit, but they are authenticated off the Moodle database, so use the same username & password without needing to create a separate account on MediaWiki.Â  Using the MediaWiki permissions system, I have editing privileges reserved for registered, logged-in users, and read privileges open to the world - but you could configure this in many ways if you wish.Â  Check out the various projects created in MediaWiki (WikiPedia, Wiktionary, &c.) to see the potential of this platform.Â  If you're creating a site-specific, rather than a course-specific Wiki, it seems the way to go at this point.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE / MediaWiki integration
ResponsesInList.Text: You can set up user read and edit permission in MediaWiki any way you wish.Â  I've set up mine with world-wide read privileges, and registered-users edit privileges.Â  Registered users are authenticated from the MOODLE users database; so anyone registered on the MOODLE site can login to MediaWiki with their Moodle username/password and edit away.Â  Though it's a separate login, the login data is inherited from MOODLE, so there is no need to set up a separate MediaWiki profile. If your'e looking to muckle together a mess of platforms, this can get more than a little messy.Â  re links and forums, I run several sites & have been totally happy with the built-in functions in MOODLE.Â  These may work in ways that differ from the platforms you may be used to using, but you may find that after getting used to them, they really do accomplish what you need. Another solution that might work if you REALLY feel the need to step outside of Moodle for some functions, is to use the MOODLE integration with PostNuke (or Mambo/Joomla).Â  This would allow you to pull in the functionalities of the PostNuke platform, with a single login to the integration.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE / MediaWiki integration
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually when you delete user from MOODLE via admin interface, the user record is NOT deleted from the database (I suppose this is done to preserve logs, assignments etc. and not to mess up existing stats). There's a "deleted" field in the mdl_user database, and the value "1" is assigned to it when you delete somebody. As the auth plugin for mediawiki checks only the presence of user (i.e. "username" field) in the mdl_user db and coincidence of password entered to the db-hash, it pays no attention to the state of the "deleted" field, so the user deleted from moodle may successfully login into the associated mediawiki. Imho, that's the explanation

In good old English, this means you can have transparent windows authentication (NTLM) against Active Directory, similar in function to Dan Marsden's auth_ntlm module for Moodle. http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/LdapNtlmAuthentication.php It is still a bit of a hack at the moment, should work for most setups. Let me know if you want any further details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE / MediaWiki integration

The bit from LocalSettings.php is as follows... # setup for AuthMoodle... # require_once( 'extensions/moodle.php' ); # $wgAuth = new AuthMoodle(); # $wgAuth->setPrefix('mdl_'); # $wgAuth->setHost('localhost'); # $wgAuth->setDatabase('moodle'); # $wgAuth->setDbuser('moodleuser'); # $wgAuth->setDbpassword('moodlepassword'); ...obviously, change to reflect your Moodle db. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE / MediaWiki integration
ResponsesInList.Text: Ack... I checked and double checked those pages... it was right in front of me. Thanks. I had tried using the Mediawiki LDAP plugin to connect to my AD without any luck, but then today found another tutorial on how to do it, and got it working. Talking to some other people, I'm thinking that it's probably best to keep Moodle and Mediawiki separate, although I'm not upper management will agree. I think the two main reasons they wanted to integrate Mediawiki into Moodle is that we've had so much success with Moodle that they want that success to continue with Mediawiki, and they also wanted to be able to do SSO so that users could log into Moodle and then go right to Mediawiki without having to sign on again... something that I just could not get working with your solution or any others that I tried. Oh well, maybe we'll be able to do something with our AD Federated Services. Thanks again for your assistance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Blogs/Wikis??
ResponsesInList.Text: I am really stumped with this one.Â  We are wanting to setup a reading ' blog ' for our high school.Â  We have version 2.9 and use Moodle for various courses already. We want ALL boys to be able to contribute their book reviews onto Moodle, have tags so they're easily found and for boys to comment on the book reviews that other boys are contributing on Moodle. The blog we have set up now doesn't allow others to comment.Â  Are we better setting up a Wiki or even a Forum? Also, we want to make the access point more visually attractive (perhaps a link on an Intranet homepage).Â  Can people give me advice on this?Â  I am sure others have already set up something similarÂ using Moodle. Thanks Tanya

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs/Wikis??
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tanya, Have you thought of having a database with allow comments and possibly require approval enabled? This will allow you to check that the reviews are 'suitable' before you click approve, which then lets other users see them. The database is searchable, and users add comments by clicking on the magnifying glass??? Cheers, Sally

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs/Wikis??
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tanya, Sally's suggestion of a database is a good one, but you could also use a glossary. It's easier for a teacher who's not used to Moodle to set up. It's quite easy to make a Moodle site look attractive by adding images to a course page and changing layout and fonts to create variety. Cheers, Glenys

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs/Wikis??
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree with Glenys and the glossary but you could also use a forum for this-perhaps a standard forum for general use and then the boys could start a new discussion topic for each book they have read.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs/Wikis??
ResponsesInList.Text: That's the great thing about Moodle; we're spoily for choice. Sally

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: One of my science teachers wants to have an excel spreadsheet pasted into a wiki for students to enter data.Â  However, when I paste it in the wiki, the excel formulas don't work. We cant use Google Docs, because it is blocked by our district filter.Â  Any ideas?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I guess I am surprised that you thought the excel formulas would work, but have you thought about asking the district to allow you to access google docs either by just killing the blacklist entry or via a district google domain ? Of course if district IT refused you could a) simply tunnel to your own proxy or b) just have the students access google docs on their iPhones - LOL There is the ability to do calculation with asciimath, and given some time you could kludge together a calculated table - if you want to explore that install asciimath and check out the calculator

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I should have worded that differently.Â  Is there anyway to embedd an excel spreadsheet, so it can be edited. Thanks for your input.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I mentioned some possible ways to provide access to an online spreadsheet, but I don't know of any way to make excel specifically available via the web save perhaps through citrix. You could use another webbased app or even use thegoogle php api to do a editable noodle accessible spreadsheet, but that would be a gooddeal of work. I do believe that talking to your district IT staff about an exception for google docs or at least an exception for a google app district domain is a quick and easy way to address having access to googledocs. Btw , remember that there are conversion issues that arise moving back and forth from googledoccs to excel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: I should mention, since you did refernce excel. That you can publish excel spreadsheets as webdocs, but then you have to have ie to use them. There are quite a few resources on the web explaining how to move an excel spreadsheet to php and mysql , and if you have moodle you likely have access to both - faced with providing access to google docs or integration of your moodle with google apps as opposed to developing a php app or porting simple php spreadsheet, there is no telling what your helpful IT and EdTech staff might do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your time and information.Â  I will share it with our IT.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Excel
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Deb, Two suggested work arounds. The firstÂ way would be a bit clunky if you had lots of students, but you could enable binary files, and upload a 'starter' Excel spreadsheet. Students would have to take turns to download the spreadsheet, add their dadta, and re-upload. At least the wiki organises things with date and time stamps so that the latest version could be downloaded and editted. Another alternative would be to have a table in your wiki with the format youÂ have in the spreadsheet and have all the students enter the data. When all the data has been enetered you upload the spreadsheet with the formulas and they copy and paste the data from the wiki into it. Cheers, Sally Mack

ResponsesInList.Title: Erfurt Wiki - Nwiki - what is what
ResponsesInList.Text: The answer to this question might be buried somewhere but spending some time of searching brought me only so far ... I have a brand new installation of moodle 1.9. I have migrated a few courses from an older 1.8 installation and I now want to get into wikis. As far as I understand now, when I install moodle from scratch I get The old wiki also called erfurt wiki (maybe OU wiki, just another name I stumbled over) I also understand that I can install NWIKI which will probably be the default wiki of moodle 2.0. Is there any summary available that explains the main differences between the "old" wiki and nwiki? What do I get when I install nwiki? Is it a good idea to run nwiki right now to avoid migration problems when movibg to moodle 2.0? thanks in advance Robert

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Erfurt Wiki - Nwiki - what is what
ResponsesInList.Text: The old wiki is indeed erfurt wiki. Old, simple, limited, reliable. OU wiki is the Open University wiki - it has limited functionality and navigation but is very reliable. You also need to install OU search along with it to make it effective. It supplements and doesn't replace eWiki or nWiki (see below). When you install nWiki you replace eWiki and get either a fantastic full-featured wiki with all the features you'd expect from a wiki, great navigation and integrated discussions and some neat extras like PDF export OR You'll get a mass of problems, admin headaches and a wiki that students can't save changes to if they use IE . And if that happens you won't know which till you've done it, won't be able to go back to eWiki nor will you be able to fix it easily if it is wrong. (You may be able to guess my experience ...) nWiki is set to be the 'standard' wiki as from moodle 2 - however at the moment the problems, options and legacy systems of wiki provision in Moodle is, in my opinion, it's single greatest weakness for teaching/learning/collaboration - we've run out of time to get nWiki wokring in IE so we're using OU wiki but hoping nWiki will work sometime soon. Hopefully this will help clear up what's what and alert you to some of the potential associated issues.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Erfurt Wiki - Nwiki - what is what
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Steve, first of all thank you for the clarification. Clear words, something like this should go on the moodle wiki faq. So far nWiki seemed to be quite nice. At least I can save images from Safari and Firefox which was not possible for me on eWiki. BUT, testing that, I also cannot save from IE, whether logged in as student or as teacher. So if looks like I am pretty much stuck: Not being able to save images from Firefox or Safari as teacher using eWiki. Which I could do in moodle 1.8. Not being able to save anything from IE as student using nWiki. Looks like i have to abandon the whole wiki idea for now until this all clears up. thanks again Robert

ResponsesInList.Text: Rigth now we - the team that developed nwiki - is working with Moodle.com to write the new wiki module for moodle 2.0, let's call it Wiki 2.0 Wiki 2.0 will feature most of the features in Nwiki and ouwiki. ResponsesInList.Title: Hopefully the last release of NWiki for moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: AS most of you may already know, we are working on the Wiki module for Moodle 2.0 This wiki module is being created from scratch so will not share bugs with NWiki or Wiki. It will also migrate wikis from std Wiki, NWiki (1.9) and OU-Wiki. This being said, we found some time to fix a number of well know bugs of NWiki for 1.9. Important to mention the bugfix in IE (my first proposal is to NOT USE IE, but since some users keep on it...), fix on separate groups, some installation bugs when fancy gruops wikis are migrated and postgresql issues. We even created a new users guide . You may find the new NWiki release in www.dfwikilabs.org and in the old site . I hope this is rthe last version of NWiki and we will start talking soon about Wiki 2.0 Ale!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hopefully the last release of NWiki for moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, I manually fixed it. First I tried to uninstall NWiki since I had made backups of the eWiki modules, etc., but this failed - the original module still wanted NWiki (must have been the database upgrade)! Since all my content was still in my MySQL database, I exported the wiki_pages table as an Excel csv file. Then I cut and pasted into NWiki, but it required way to much cleanup of html code with the default NWiki editor. I changed everything to the HTML editor, tried again, and vola! I only needed to add brackets for internal links and redo the graphics as regular images. 2 hours later, and the job is done! Whew! Also, the NWiki editor is turning up unbelievably tiny, just like with the previous poster. I tried in Safari, Camino, Firefox browsers, and none of them have resize handles.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hopefully the last release of NWiki for moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: To fix the size: Update line ~1599 to add an id to the textarea: $output = "<textarea" .' id="wikitextarea"' .$propert->cols.$propert->rows.$propert->name.$propert->class.$propert->style.$propert->events.">\n".$info."\n</textarea>"; Add this to /mod/wiki/nwiki. css : #wikitextarea{width:800px;height:500px;} It's hacky but it works.

That the upgrade to nWiki didn't add a couple of fields to mdl_wiki which I think should be 'editorrows' & 'editorcols'. This probably means a few other things could be ary with my install, and I had better go back and check what! But I wont stir up any more ire on that score! Regards, John

ResponsesInList.Title: OU wiki: new release
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all. Just for information, there's been an update to the ouwiki. This includes some bugfixes and two minor features which were previously absent: 1. the ability to revert to a previous version 2. the ability (restricted by a new capability, students can't do it) to 'delete' a version The reason for #2 is that if a student posts something offensive, you want to get rid of it from the page. You can edit the page, but then it will still appear in history... So now, those with permissions can delete versions. The old version is not really deleted; those with permission can also view it (to check the evidence of the crime!) and undelete if it was deleted by accident. Also you can now download the wiki reports in CSV format if you like. (Woo-hoo!) These features might not sound exciting but you should probably upgrade anyway if you use ouwiki because it includes fixes to some minor security problems (thanks to Petr from moodle.com for doing the analysis to find these). ouwiki download page

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attaching a file (non-image)
ResponsesInList.Text: The database tool would also be quite useful. It has the advantage of being customisable and searchable. You can set it up so that the teacher has to approve submissions first, and then the students can view them. You can allow the posts to be rated also. The database module is a little tricky to set up at first, but is a very flexible tool. If you want to have a task where students see each others final product it is much better than using the assignment module, and having to move the submitted files.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Attaching a file (non-image)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Copied directly from the nwiki help: Attach Files: If the users have permissions to attach files the 'Insert File' tree will be shown. You can insert into the content any file uploaded to the server . To view the list of available files you only have to click on the plus icon. Once you find the file in the list you only have to click on the name for insert it into the text (in the text area will appear something like ' attach:filename '). If you aren't sure of which file want, you can click on the preview icon for open a pop up window or download it. If you have a teacher or administrator, you can deleted uploaded files just by click on the delete icon. Images files (gif, jpg, bmp and png) and flash movies (swf) will be inserted visually in the document. All other files will be displayed as a link to download. Upload Files: If you have permission to upload files to the server, you will see a standard upload form. Just browse the file and click on upload. If the file already exists on the server, a red message will appear in the top of the editor. Otherwise, the new file will appear automatically in the attach file list.

(I am using 1.9.2) Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Not all groups show in drop down menu, so students can't participate
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello We encountered the same bug, but have managed to trace it and work around it. This happens if you create a number of groups, then a wiki that is groupvisible. It seems moodle does not actually create the wiki instances until they are accessed. The work around: 1: Create everything as normal 2: Log in as teacher 3: Use the drop down menu to open each wiki (to force moodle to create the instances) This way the instances will be generated and available to all the students. I am also pretty sure that simply waiting for all students to log in and check their own wiki would solve the problem (but I have not verified this)

ResponsesInList.Title: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
ResponsesInList.Text:
E.g. if you create a wiki named like this: 
```text
wiki "suivi scolaire"
```
 You will get: Bad HTML like: 
```text
 a
 href
=
"view.php?id=3770&page=edit/wiki "
suivi 
scolaire"" 
title
=
"Modifier"
>
.....
```
 What's worse: The wiki entry page will show the first version created, but not the most recent version and you will have to go through history to find the page you just edited. ... just spent 30 minutes on this. Of course may can ask why people want to put quotes in names. It's beyond me but a typical thing that people who trust computers might do ;) PS: This is for the standard ewiki module. Moodle 1.9 + (Build: 20080326)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 1.9.3 w/NWIKI 2.0...no save in IE
ResponsesInList.Text: We are running Moodle 1.9.3 and this is the fix from our programmer: The tags.lib.php wiki_tags_print_editbox() method closed off the editor's form above the Save, Preview, and Cancel buttons. This made the buttons invisible to IE. There is a form close below the buttons in any case, so this is a bug in nwiki. I also fixed another bug in the wiki_tags_save_tags() method to handle the case where an argument to the method is null. If you drop in the tags.lib.php file attached above in mod/wiki/tags (replacing the one that's there) this should fix the problem with IE. Note that I'm using the latest NWiki from the developer and installed it per his instructions (that is, after removing the existing wiki in 1.9).

ResponsesInList.Title: Embedded video
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using the Wiki module as a way of posting student video tests so only they and I can see those tests. I load the videos into files by grade level, have the students create their Wiki, then use the hyperlink controls to link the videos to the student's Wiki. The problem I am encountering concerns the way videos are linked to student wikis. My videos are created on Mac as a ".mov" file, and Moodle is automatically embedding them in the body of the wiki. This creates some problems loading each wiki and presents problems if I want to place multiple videos on one wiki. It also messes up student formatting of their wiki. I have tried a number of solutions to try to prevent video embedding, but none (at the code level and otherwise) has yet to work. Anybody have any ideas about how I can still used ".mov" files but prevent automatic embedding? Thanks, Kevin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embedded video
ResponsesInList.Text: afaik there is no way of doing this. You can use QT Player Pro to Export your .mov to mp4, don't recompress, just "pass through" the video and audio. iTunes can also convert .mov to m4v (same as mp4), use Advanced>Create iPod or iPhone version. But the data rate will be about 1500 kbps. Change the m4v extension to mp4, Moodle seems to like it better. Then the href link to the mp4 will not embed the movie, it will just provide the link to the movie in same window or a new window. At least that's how it works on our install of Moodle. Of course everything needs to be tested on Mac Safari and Firefor, and Win XP/Vista IE and Firefox , but I think it will work.

If he edits the wiki in this view he changes only the instructors version of the wiki, not the students. On the other side of the coin, the student does not see the material the teacher added to the wiki unless the teacher edits that specific student's wiki. As far as I know there is no way for a teacher to make universal changes to all the wikis, which is one reason it is handy to learn how to set up multipage student wikis.

ResponsesInList.Title: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text:
I teach history at a community college and just switched from
Blackboard to Moodle primarily because of the built in wiki
application. Part of the class is a collaborative assignment where
groups of 2 or 3 students will research their own project. They are
each going edit their own page, which everyone can see, but only that
group can edit. I also want to create a central page from which there
are links to all the group pages. My main question is should there just
be one wiki and many pages, or many wikis linked to eachother? I have
already grouped the students, but how do I assign a page or wiki to a
specific group? Thanks, GP

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gary.Â  I've done something similar except I kept each group's work private.Â  I don't think there's a way to assign pages to specific groups, so that's something to keep in mind and pushes you to many wikis, which you can assign to groups.Â  Here's my recommendation. Let's say you have 3 groups.Â  You can create a wiki, call it "project".Â  In the setup page choose "groups" type with "visible groups" mode.Â  By doing this, you're automatically making as many wikis as you have groups. When you save your setup, the HTML editor will open up so you can compose the main page.Â  If you look at the top left of the screen, you'll see that you are actually editing the home page for one specific group.Â  On the top right, there is a drop-down box labeled "choose other wikis" or something like that which allows you to create a main page for each of your groups, one by one.Â  Cutting and pasting works well if you want the main pages to be the same. Students will see only one link on their main course page - it will just say Project with a wiki icon.Â  When they click on it, it will open one group's wiki - I would hope the one they can write on, but I'm not sure about that because I've never done visible groups.Â  They should have a drop-down box that would allow them to navigate among the different wikis. One caution -Â  you want to make sure that you don't have duplicate page names.Â  For example, maybe you're thinking about setting up each group with a main page that links to pages called "overview" "outline" and "resources".Â  You need to individualize the page names to, say, "overview-1" for group 1, "overview-2" for group 2 and so on.Â  Otherwise, unexpected things happen when you try to navigate to your ownÂ  overview page - you could easily end up on some other group's.Â  Even with separate groups, duplicate page names were a problem for me, and I can only guess it would be worse with visible groups. Good luck with it.Â  I think wikis are a great collaboration tool.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Russ, That helps, but I am not there yet. How do I link to other wikis from the central or homepage wiki. I was able to link to other pages within the main wiki, but students cannot edit that. I also can't seem to change page names of other wikis. What I want to end up with is a main wiki page that only I can edit which serves as an index of topics, each linking to another group wiki. Everyone can see everything but only edit their own. Thanks, Gary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text:
Gary, I think you're going to have difficulty setting up the scheme you
have in mind if I understand it correctly.Â  Every wiki in your
moodle has a link displayed on the main course page.Â  You could
set up a page (not a wiki per se, but just a topic summary) that names
the various wikis for the different groups and they will link
automatically, but I don't think you can force students to access the
wikis this way because each wiki will still have its own link on the
main page.Â  The duplication quickly gets confusing, and is
unnecessary because the drop down menu I mentioned allows students to
access all the other groups' wikis anyway.Â  In other words, the
model I suggested doesn't have a "central" wiki, but just the
individual group wikis which are all of equal rank (none more central
than the others). One other point in case this is not clear already:Â  When you set
up wikis in groups mode, every group in your class will automatically
have the wiki with the same name.Â  So you need to give it a
generic name.Â  For example: suppose your project is about flowers
and you have groups working on petunias, sunflowers, and tulips.Â 
If you set up a group wiki named Petunia, EVERY group will have a
petunia wiki - even the tulip folks.Â  I would call the wiki
"flowers" and use the specific flowers as group names.Â  Then, the
choose wiki drop-down list will be clear because it gives the wiki name
and the group name: Petunias: flowers Tulips:flowers Sunflowers:flowers Not very elegant, but it is clear and I think it gives students the navigation tool you seem to want. Hope this is not too confusing. Russ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a wiki infrastructure
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Russ, In the interest of time, I am using just one wiki this semester. There is one central wiki which links to group pages. We are going to use the honor system of only editing your own group page, of course having the history of edits will help to scare any would be sabatoers. I may try to modify the system for next semester, when my school will also upgrade our version of moodle. Gary

ResponsesInList.Title: the "code" tag seems to be not activated
ResponsesInList.Text:
hello, i'm working with the moodle wiki here on moodle.org and on my installation. paralell i work with some ewiki installations in another context . ewiki supports the "code" tag to be able to integrate code snippets in wiki pages. i noticed that the "code" tag is not interpreted in the moodle wiki. ewiki changes 'code' to 'pre class="markup code"', the moodle wiki lets it unchanged. in the ewiki documentation the difference between 'pre' and 'code' is described as follows: 
```text
#  use the 'pre' ... '/pre' 'tags' for a paragraph of 
preformatted text, that still allowed to use WikiWords and 
simple markup

# with 'code' ... '/code' instead you would really see text as 
you typed it, with square brackets and other escapes not 
garbaging your text
```
 could someone of the developer team please think about activating the 'code' handling as in ewiki? ps. the 'pre' implementation seems to have a bug in the moodle wiki. empty lines in the 'pre' block make the interpreter close the block before reaching the '/pre' tag.

ResponsesInList.Title: ewiki strips applet tags - is there a fix?
ResponsesInList.Text: Back around to the original question: How to embed java applet in ewiki. HTMLArea still strips all script and applet tags. Is this under control of weblib.php now or is this a plugin issue? There is some documentation in xref that there was an ewiki "fix" to address some tags, and it is unclear at this point whether the issue is ewiki, moodle or htmlarea. Having said that I experimented with adding the applet tag in weblib.php, which resulted in java throwing the dreaded java.lang.NullPointerException error, and the console indicates that there is an unknown source; i.e. as the applet works fine in a web resource in the same Moodle why is the applet losing its way? On comparison of the code pasted and the code remaining, however, it looks like the underlying problem may be the use made of square and curly braces by javasketch pad..... OY!!! Hoisted by square brackets yet again?!?! The square bracket issue in ewiki was noted with respect to the use of Tex in ewiki (e.g. Tex uses square brackets to set the nth root as in \sqrt [3]{27}=3, or $$\sqrt[3]{27}=3$$ ) and Eloy noted that this should be addressed in nWiki..... suggesting that there is still no way to exclude text in ewiki from being interpreted as wiki markup?? Dekiwiki does applets out of the gate and there are extensions to allow this in mediawiki (and arguably there should be a way to allow at least PHMs so to do in moodle docs ) but in as much as the Moodle wiki is not mediawiki and nWiki is not as yet fully operating, it would seem that the mass of Moodle users will be using ewiki for some time..... can someone shed some light on this?

Apart from being attached to a different course, I would like each wiki to be identical - same name, same default first page, same description. Creating hundreds of wikis manually would be pretty painful, so I'm looking for alternatives. I thought manually editing the MySQL database might be the easiest way (generating some nice big SQL file which would create everything in one go) but it seems more complex that I'd hoped and could easily mess up the whole thing (in addition to tables mdl_wiki, mdl_wiki_entries, mdl_wiki pages and mdl_course_modules, there's a fairly obscure entry in the modinfo field in mdl_course and probably some others I haven't tracked down). I've also had a look at hacking the php code to create the wikis, but tracing through the code is proving tough (it starts with course/modedit.php?add=wiki&... but my php isn't up to tracing it all through). I'm using Moodle 1.9.2 with ewiki. Any ideas? Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create multiple wikis in one go
ResponsesInList.Text: Having not had any replies on this one, and following a brief email conversation with Mike Churchward, one of the developers for the integration of ewiki and Moodle, I've concluded that this isn't easy to do and probably more involved and riskier than doing it the long, boring way. There's certainly no supported way to do it. I assume that it would be possible to script it, but from looking at the code, I've just been unable to track down the functions that actually create a new wiki, at least in a way that would let me script it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create multiple wikis in one go
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually, I think between using the directory feature I finally got figured out and the suggestion that pigui made I think you could be on to something..... though I think that perhaps a php script that simply parsed the course IDs and created a wiki using the correct file from the correct site files directory if the course had yet to be accessed might be manageable.....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create multiple wikis in one go
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ian. I have an idea about how to solve your problem "easily". Have you noticed that if you delete the default "News Forum" from a course another one is created? You can hack you course formats (weeks, topics, etc ) to create a new wiki if it does not exists. You wouldn't have to deal with Moodle database and every wiki will be automatically created on user "demand" (teacher accessing to his course). Hope it helps. DFWikiLabs, Pigui.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki Initial Content Directories
ResponsesInList.Text: We are going to remove the current initial content directory selector functions from the wiki module. As it stands, its too complex for people to use effectively. Instead, there will be an optionalÂ field when the wiki is defined that will allow the teacher to add initial content that will be seeded in all initial wiki pages for that wiki. Down the road, we will add an import wiki structure function that will allow for more complex wiki structures to be brought in by default. Any comments or questions? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Initial Content Directories
ResponsesInList.Text: That makes perfect sense. The help files should be Moodle help files.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Initial Content Directories
ResponsesInList.Text: I just checked in a large change to CVS that updates the way initial content and initial page names are handled. You can now upload initial pages to be used by a wiki in the course files area. It is best if you use an individual subdirectory for any wiki default content as the entire directory will be used to create the pages. Selecting a file in that directory chooses the directory for content and the file for the index (first) page. If you don't select initial content, the wiki will be empty to start. In this case, the first page name can be specified with the 'pagename' field. If this field is blank, the wiki name will be used. There is a database change so make sure you visit your admin page after applying this update. Michael - sorry about this. You'll have to restore some of the translations you removed. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Initial Content Directories - baby steps
ResponsesInList.Text: It would appear that at least from a formatting perspective there are the following initial considerations: 1) If the pages have been already mocked up in a moodle wiki (erfurtwiki) then the best way to provide them to a new moodle via directory is to edit the existing wiki page, click on html view, then copy the html to a text file.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Initial Content Directories - baby steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Caveats to the above: 1) Watch out for class statements in your markup! If there is no class definition then text in the paragraphs tagged with the class will simply be dropped when the page is pulled into the wiki. 2) the file must have no extensions (well, your file can have extensions but the extensions must then be referenced in your mark-up) so with MS Windows PCs this can be a royal pain as the OS does not typically show the file extensions in the file name. The manual drudgery amounts to creating a text file, copying the html markup from your wiki mockup, saving the file and then zipping all the files - then upload, unzip, and rename each file, deleting txt - yes there are undoubtedly easier ways to do this..... 3) Watch out for things like spaces in your page names! While the wiki itself may handle spaces in the page names just fine, when you create the text file for that page you have a problem. WHile there may be some more elegant solution, simply putting underscores between words in the files works fine, but this means that you also have to do that inside your text files any time you internally reference another wiki page. And as to html2wiki conversion? This actually worked better than I had expected, but the obvious cautions must be observed: 4) You must have comparable markup. In testing phpwiki there were issues as well as with a number of others.... I will post the question of comparability among wiki markup syntax separately in the hope that the additional question will draw some attention.... 5) Beware of the caveats above, however some conversions will attempt to resolve spaces in the names and other such questions. 6) The results of the conversion is real wiki markup, while the results produced by the process recommended in the prior post (develop wiki mockup and then cut and paste html) produces html interpreted by the wiki module. WIll this work for student as well as group wikis? It appeared to do just that! Bottom line: Yes, this appears to be a way to create extensive wiki "templates" that can be rolled out to individual students to provide everything from a senesters reading prompts and journals to laboratory notebooks. Why, you might ask, are details about how to implement this so difficult to find when one might expect that this might be a critical tool in the use of Moodle.... And that indeed is the question....

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki in Moodle 2.0 Development plans .... and call for contributions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, this week we have started to develope the Wiki for Moodle 2.0. Which is basically NWiki (same features, look and feel, etc) rewriten from scratch ( so the code will be neat and tiddy ). And we need some help to make this rigth, so we never need "to do another wiki ever". Help Wanted: - code revision: By the end of this week we will have the first functional release, just a wiki skeleton with a dumb parser, but with the full database and basic operations implemented. I beliebe that security issues need to be addressed here before we start building features. - markup and page behaviour - There will be a team working sole on the parsers (ewiki for backward compatibility, HTML(whateever editor) wiki, and Mediawikilike markup, and a new VerySimpleWikiFormat. We will use Unit tests to guide de parser development and be sure the things work as they are suposed to. We need you to send (as reply to this post for instance) wikipages with the page content (wiki format) and how is it suposed to be viewed ( XHTML ). If you want your wikis to render rigth in Wiki 2.0 : here's your chance. Thanks in advance for all your help. Ludo

ResponsesInList.Text: I think I figured out a couple of work arounds for this in Firefox . A bit clunky, but it seemed to work when I changed my role to student. 1. Set up a Datbase to receive images. Students canupload to it. You can limit the upload size so they have to care about file size.Then upload their file to the data base, and right click on the link and choose copy link location then pasteÂ the linkÂ into the imageURL in the addImage dialogue box. Alternatively put a link on the wiki inside a pair of square brackets, like so:[ ] That only makes a link though. 2. Alternatively, allow attachments, and have the students upload the image file there, and use the procedure above. If you have a bunch of students researching the same topic, and most likely finding the same pictures, the database option will allow to create a communal image repository, and reduce the load on your storage capacity. I'd be interested to know if this works. Sally Mack

ResponsesInList.Title: NWiki upgrade from 1.6 to 1.9 - issues to be aware of?
ResponsesInList.Text: We've got an upgrade coming on our moodle site - one of our modules is heavily based around nWiki - Are there any issues experienced with an upgrade from 1.6 to 1.9 (prob via 1.8.4)? Is there any way of backing up the existing course and ensuring it can work somewhere? I've tried backing it up and then restoring on a spearate 1.6 area we have for another organisation but got this error: Parse error : syntax error, unexpected T_IS_IDENTICAL in /var/www/vhosts/hrdnow-training.org/httpdocs/mod/wiki/view.php on line 4 The rest of the course has backed up fine and nWiki is enabled on this server /site but backup/restore not working makes me VERY worried for an upgrade. FInally - is there any way of effectively exporting the content so it could be pulled back in or at least got at to rebuild from scratch if upgrade doesn't work?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki upgrade from 1.6 to 1.9 - issues to be aware of?
ResponsesInList.Text: We have recently completed a similar upgrade 1.6 -> 1.8 -> 1.9. At each stage, we deleted the native Moodle Wiki code and added an appropriate version of NWiki before running the upgrade script. NWiki seems to be working as well or better than on 1.6 and existing courses containing Nwiki seem to have upgraded OK. That said, we don't (yet) make extensive use of NWiki so have not rigorously tested. However, we did take the precaution of keeping a working copy of our entire 1.6 system. i.e. copied the folders containing moodle and moodledata to a new location and used my sql dump to copy the database which was then reloaded into MySQL . If you are working on the same server (and you are backing up somwhere else, aren't you ? ) you will have to give the copied database a new name and adjust the copied Moodle's config.php to reflect this and any changes in the the details of the /moodle and /moodledata folders. You may also need to run the /moodle/admin/replace.php script to update any hard coded links so that they still work in the new location. In my experience, mysqldump is more reliable than using Moodle's built-in backup and restore capabilities which can have problems with 3rd-party modules. Once you have two working 'clones' of your 1.6 system you can upgrade one of them secure in the knowledge that if it all goes 'horribly wrong' you still have a functioning version to revert to! MoodleDocs has lots of guidance on all this, though I'll be happy to provide further technical details if required. Good luck with the upgrade!
