ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki for Moodle 1.9 Release
ResponsesInList.Text: I found It!!!! (but I have to add the blocks manually: if "activate blocks" is dissabled when you restore a course the blocks added were missing. After the activation of blocks you have either to restore the course again or add the blocks manually) Adding blocks to activities Certain activity modules, such as the Lesson module and the Quiz module , support blocks on their pages. The site administrator must turn this function on so that the teachers will be able to add side blocks on those pages, otherwise the interface does not show this feature to the teacher. By default, this feature is disabled in the Site administration block . An administrator can enable it by checking the showblocksonmodpages box in Administration > Appearance > Themes > Theme settings . When enabled, users who can manage course activities will be able to add blocks to pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is an expected behaviour and common to many wiki engines. For example, MediaWiki, the software which runs under Wikipedia, works like that. NWiki too. Check this page for more information about this: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Don't_use_line_breaks Bye

The second one is "\\" (without quotes), which does a line break at any part of a line. I think you can use the last one to force the line breaks that you need. Bye.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text: It's a bug, not a feature request and this has annoyed me to no end as I use wikis with younger students. I voted for your bug report. Creole markup is intended to be a MINIMUM set of markup, not the only markup.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, Are you saying that the more than 2 million of wikipedia's articles are bugged? There are reasons behind this behaviour, in case you didn't read the link i pasted before. So, i repeat: it's not a bug, it's a feature. Also, the comment about br's in that bug report is wrong because the only valid tag in XHTML for doing a line break should be "
" (without quotes) as the W3C says. Then i say that last NWiki brings some creole marks and you said that's a "MINIMUM"; well, NWiki supports MediaWiki syntax since the very beggining because it's the widest wiki engine used, so Creole is not "the only markup" AT ALL. After making this clear, i see some solutions to your ""problem"" in NWiki: Â· Don't use line breaks (check http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Don't_use_line_breaks again) like millions of wiki articles doesn't. Â· Use \\ to force line breaks. Â· Ask to NWiki devs to if could be possible to add a NWiki option to force single line breaks. Â· Don't ask them and do it yourself (this is free software, you have the code). The rest is useless IMHO. Bye.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Darrel I'm sorry, your are completely wrong. I know that we have to improve our manuals and documentation, but this is NOT a bug. You can use HTML editor with younger students, the WYSIWYG editor would be great for them. DFWikiTeam, Pigui.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree with Darrel; even my college-level students and faculty are going to find the additional markup cumbersome. (Although I am very glad there is now a way to force line breaks! Thank you for adding that feature. It makes wikis usable on my campus.) I think the real issue is that there are two different, competing schools of thought here: some people want a full-fledged, powerful wiki tool like MediaWiki, and others simply need an easy-to-use WYSIWYG wiki for use by people who don't want to learn a whole markup language. I would argue that Moodle is a tool geared toward the latter group, and the tools within Moodle should be as straightforward and easy for general users as possible. The reason the "no line breaks" convention works for Wikipedia is because its articles are written in essay format, i.e. relatively long paragraphs. Because of this, single line breaks are not needed. Wikipedia's real reason for disallowing line breaks is to prevent users from putting hard breaks at the end of every line. This messes up the formatting and makes the wiki articles more difficult to parse and edit. While this feature is very important for a huge, public wiki like Wikipedia, it is in my opinion less critical for the small, limited-group, pedagogical wikis created within Moodle. I think the flexiblity and ease of use of allowing single line breaks outweighs the potential danger of poor formatting. To make the wiki a really flexible tool, we need to have other formatting options. Not everyone is using wikis to write long paragraphs; some uses do require single line breaks. Adding the ability to display single line-breaks would make wikis much more usable for different purposes. It would also allow students and instructors to immediately create content instead of having to spend their time learning a new markup language or interface. Technology should meet users where they are, no expect users to come to it. There is no reason the Moodle wiki needs to follow MediaWiki conventions if they do not make sense for us.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text: I totally agree with Caroline analysis. For us the wiki should be very simple. We use it as collaborative pages for drafts, lists of ideas, etc Since we changes to nwiki, every time we copy and paste texts from another application then we have to add double line break, it's a pain. When we use the HTML editor, we'd like the text to stay in the same way as we see it when we type it. V

Can someone walk me through the steps?Â  Do I create the new groups first or the new wiki first?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating groups in Wikis version 1.8
ResponsesInList.Text: This feature (creating different sets of groups to use for different activities , rather than using all groups for all activities) is called 'groupings'. It is a system feature, not part of wikis. Unfortunately although some parts of it were available in 1.8 I don't think it worked properly and I'm not sure the user interface was enabled. (We had it here! We did make it work on our system, but it was rough...) GOOD NEWS: The grouping system facility is fixed in 1.9, and as far as I'm aware it all completely works. You may still need to enable the option via a checkbox somewhere in the admin system. BAD NEWS: In 1.9 the old wiki has several bugs to do with groups and groupings. So even though the option is there, you may find it doesn't work properly. (ouwiki does fully supports groupings in 1.9, but as you may be aware it has certain other limitations. nwiki probably works with groupings also, I don't know.) --sam

ResponsesInList.Title: NWiki for Moodle 1.6 - groups issue?
ResponsesInList.Text: Have done a bit of work to tidy up NWiki for Moodle 1.6.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki for Moodle 1.6 - Groups issue?
ResponsesInList.Text: ...Ooops, got timed out mid-edit. As I was saying... Have done a bit of work to tidy up NWiki (wiki_rev2007051801.zip) for Moodle 1.6. The rationale was to have a reasonably functional Wiki for staff development, prior to our upgrade to Moodle 1.9 over the summer. Fixed a few lang strings and help files (en_utf8), tweaked the parser to be more compatible with MediaWiki syntax (though not as complete as the new parser engine in NWiki for Moodle 1.9), and also added a few more buttons to the NWiki editor (== h2 ==, === h3 ===, ==== h4 ====, pre , indent :, bulleted list *, numbered list #, table etc) to try toÂ be moreÂ friendly for the novice Wiki user.Â Will be happy to zip these up and make them available to anyone else still using Moodle 1.6 . Where appropriate, I'll also be happy to port these forward to NWiki for Moodle 1.9. However, I can't get this version (before or after my tweaks!) to work with groups. Group mode: No groups|Wiki in commonÂ Â Â  - works fine However, if I select Separate groups|Students in group then [Save changes] although I get a 'Change to another group' dropdown menu at the bottom right of the Wiki page, I can't actually select another group (just get 'bounced' back to the top group in the dropdown). Anyone have any insights or a fix for this? I have noticed a few other postings on Wikis and Groups in this forum, though none seem directly relevant. Thanks in advance Geoff

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CamelCase Links
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Cherry Hey, I found out quite by accident, that the way to make the links in your wiki work is to turn off CamelCase in the setup of the wiki, then just use square brackets around the item you want to be a link in the edit box, save it, and voila! You will see the blue question mark next to your desired link. When you click on that blue question mark in the view mode, it will take you to the page for that link. Once you name the linked page, your link is established. Hope this makes sense. Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Correct way to install nWiki in Moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm sorry if this has been covered elsewhere, which it has, but perhaps ambiguously (at least in my model of the world . Given a new Moodle 1.9 installation with no wikis yet created, is the correct way to install NWiki a) to delete the moodle/mod/wiki folder and replace it with the mod/wiki folder from the nWiki zip file or b) to leave the existing moodle/mod/wiki folder in place and to copy the nwiki/mod/wiki folder into moodle/mod/ so that existing files from ewiki are replaced by nwiki files, but ewiki files that are not duplicated remain in situ. I initially used method a) as this seemed the cleanest option but found on editing pages that explorer 7 was throwing javascript errors relating to ewiki. So I assumed I needed some of the ewiki files as there is reference to ewiki as an editor. I therefore deleted the nWiki files, replaced the ewiki files and then copied the nwiki files over the top to create option b). This solved the javascript errors but now results in occasional errors referring to classes which I have seen in other postings as resulting from left over bits of ewiki. If you could confirm the preferred method of installation then I can set my system up in accordance with that so that I have a sound foundation for reporting any subsequent errors. Kind regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wikis (Nwikis) lost when upgrading to 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: Did you put nwiki in your 1.9 build before running the upgrade? If you don't do that, then the standard wiki will over-write your nwiki tables, and the data will be lost. To get them back, I think you would need to revert to your 1.8.4 database backup, replace the standard wiki with nwiki in your 1.9 build, and then re-run the upgrade.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wikis (Nwikis) lost when upgrading to 1.9

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki Errors

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: nWiki Errors
ResponsesInList.Text: Wiki was not empty - you can see the content in the mashed code there. Tried changing student mode from 'student in group' to 'individual student' - the lack of any documentation on this makes it difficult to know the effect. If I change it back to 'student in group' it *appears* to work. However there remain issues with editing being locked out if I'm working on it and the possibility/likelihood that if I try to change any settign I could lose the lot... Our hosting company have reached the end of their tether with the amount of support nWiki requires: A number of users are complaining about problems with the latest supposedly "1.9 compatible" version of nwiki, and it seems from reading those reports ... that nwiki is still not ready for production use. Especially when you are trying to implement it on systems that already have a wiki (ewiki or nwiki) present - the upgrade processes simply do not seem to have been worked out correctly yet. So, given the effort that [admin name deleted] is putting into this (and that I am having to pay him for) this is becoming economically unviable for us. Either we are going to have to charge you extra for support, or you are going to have to find some other way of experimenting with this, that does not involve us. So it would seem I'm in the unenviable position of: 1 - having a flaky wiki (nWiki) that is unreliable and about as likely as a DC-10 to go down at any moment - and certainly not reliable enough to make a core component of any course. 2 - unable to rollback to a workable, simpler wiki i.e. eWiki as it is a one-way upgrade. 3 - no longer able to call on any support due to the numerous, endmic problems with nWiki from installation to this latest problem - or have to pay more for it. 4 - Unable to find any effective documentation for the wiki with the possibility that any features may cause unexpected catastrophic errors. Suggestions of how to resolve this most apprciated... Am hoping OU wiki and search may be easy and I may be able to add them or look into media wiki integration...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing from Word
ResponsesInList.Text: 1/ I am exploring setting up a wiki for my students to develop as a group their understanding of Project Management concepts. 2/ In the process I discovered that pictures can be included in their submissions (plus graphics, audio, video etc) if you "allow binary files" in the initial wiki setup. 3/ On the question of how to 'extract' embedded pictures from a word document - I use two methods (a) quick and nasty, but results seem OK - set the display magnification in Word as high as possible so that the Word images look big, then screen capture and save as jpg - I use IrfanView Capture - free to private and educational users. (b) you can force Word to release its embedded images (including any drawings you created with Word Draw - but group them first) by first saving the Word document as a webpage (don't shudder, I do not use the crappy text) - you will find that the pictures are saved as separate image files as you would expect for any html page. You then can do whatever you wish with the image files. Hope that is of some help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing from Word
ResponsesInList.Text: I have developed a method to copy and paste from Word to Moodle, including images . here http://amgd.ro/docs/data/w2m.zip The requirements are: 1. you have a webserver accessible in your netword as a windows share (ex. a Windows machine or a samba linux share) 2. you use a different domain for your images storage than your base moodle install (it still can be the same computer, use a subdomain ex media.mymoodle.org) If your Moodle deployment is (as it usually happens) on a server at your university/school, the two statements above hold.

ResponsesInList.Title: Problems with NWiki: HTML code showing in view mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, besides the other problem I mentioned ( first page ), I'm experiencing a new problem I don't know what to do about. When you click on the 'view' tab, the wikis created by the students show some of HTML labels. This can be quite disconcerting to many of the students that don't even know what HTML is. Here is one example: I suspect they did a cut and paste from Word but I've tried to use the 'clean Word HTML' to no avail. Is this a bug? The students are frustrated and they are asking for permission to use Word for their assignments to which I'm a bit resistant. Having to get into the HTML source and eliminate the offending tags one by one seems an undesirable alternative for me (even worse than allowing them to work collaboratively on Word documents). Is there anything I can do to solve this problem? Any help will be greatly appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with NWiki: HTML code showing in view mode
ResponsesInList.Text: I had the same problem... it appears that Nwiki does not like the formatting of text, if you use left, centre or right alignment it does not understand, and puts the html text for that formatting in. You can remove the html by removing the alignment of the text (so that everything is left aligned). If there is a workaround for this, so that formatting is allowed, I would appreciate an update!! Andie

ResponsesInList.Title: Bug in NWiki: HTML code showing in view mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, I was waiting to see whether there was any response from the maintainers of this module but I guess there is no answer. This is definitely a bug. I tried to 'select all and 'left align' but this doesn't solve the problem. Is this what you meant? The only other thing that I can do is to get into the code view and remove the align labels one by one but that is a major pain because the documents are long and there are many labels. I hope they fix this soon because it is kind of a nuisance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problems with NWiki: HTML code showing in view mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Forgive my ignorance as I am learning about Moodle but I am wondering if it would be possible to convert the HTML to an XML document that would preserve the format. I know that internally Moodle uses XML as I have a chance to work with the wikis I will see if my theory is true and update accordingly. Cheers, Steven Robertson

ResponsesInList.Title: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi folks, My uni has tried twiki and tikiwiki but both have proven unfriendly to general users and adoption has been extremely poor. Does anyone have any advice or references they can share regarding a good standalone wiki platform for educational use? One important issue seems to be that it needs to have the option of a WYSIWYG HTML editor - although the wiki markup has the best of intentions, it seems to often be a barrier to entry for many potential users.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, have you trie Tiddlywiki ? Is javascript based, so you can carry it with you on a USB stick, has lots of plug-ins (even one that syncs with nwiki in moodle 1.6 ) and is very user firendly. Cheers L.

We have teachers interested in using wikis but our production LMS, Blackbaord CE6, does not have a wiki so we are looking at Moodle as an LMS wiki option. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, hints. be sure to back up the tables with "wiki" in the name, if something goes wrong you can allways delete nwiki, recopy the old wiki and restore the tables and save the day... You need to delete the mod/wiki directory... then copy the directories of the nwiki distribution into the coresponding folders ( mod, lang, course etc... ) When using nwiki be sure to enable the blocks on activies, cause the nwiki blocks are very usefull (index, page list, lastest constributions... search... you'll find out) And give a try to the wiki format course. I'm expecting this week to release a version that fixes minor parser bugs, an concurrence issues related to the section edit... Cheers L.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: For hosted sites I think the popular ones lately are PBWiki, Wikispaces, and Wetpaint. At the last ed conference I went to, all three wiki presenters used Wikispaces for course projects. For "enterprise level" use, I think the only one is Confluence, but it's not inexpensive. Both local and hosted... A newcomer that looks nice is Deki Wiki, both local http://wiki.mindtouch.com/Deki_Wiki and hosted options http://wik.is/ I believe all of the above have some type of WYSIWG editor.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim: For your Information: Tikiwiki 1.10 is already in "beta" state (last weekend), after three years of development (I guess you tried 1.9.x). And it comes with full WYSIWYG editor, and many-many other improvements. Some of them listed at: http://doc.tikiwiki.org/Tikiwiki+1.10 Moreover, on the friendlyness of the interface, huge improvements have been made, that you can see through: http://themes.tikiwiki.org (select the new themes from the "theme-o-rama" section ) It has been used for several years for production university-wide right now at: http://wiki.fub.edu/ And the other sites I know of (or I sue it at), are for individual subjects only, since our universities officially use other LMS. Reports about Tikiwiki usage in education can be found at: http://edu.tikiwiki.org Hope this helps. Xavi P.S. Deki Wiki looks promising to me (and it's free software also), even if I haven't tried for production yet. I would suggest you to go for the free software wiki engines, either on external hosted sites or on your own site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Xavier, Thanks so much for your information about tikiwiki. I have just checked and the version we have here is 1.9.6. I am very interested in the improvements you mentioned. My understanding is that tikiwiki is a fully-fledged CMS containing a wiki, is that right? Is it possible to use it as just a wiki without having all the other features getting in the way? We don't really want more functionality than we need right now getting in the way of an active wiki. Cheers, Tim.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim: Yes, you can. Just install it with a default installation profile: http://doc.tikiwiki.org/Profiles and enable just what you need. All the rest will not be shown, and it will look like just an apparently simple (but powerful) standalone wiki engine. You can see an example at: http://wiki-translation.com Check documentation for styling it to suite the theme in your site, etc.: http://doc.tikiwiki.org/Documentation Cheers, Xavi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Standalone wiki software
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim, You might want to look at Elgg and the Folio plugin. Elgg has unparalleled access controls and the Folio plugin is a really easy to use wiki for inexperienced users (WYSYWG interface only). Plus the access controls mean that users can regulate access to any page by themselves. Plus Elgg is really neat Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Nwiki upgrade options
ResponsesInList.Text: Now that Nwiki has been identified as a target for moodle core, is there a roadmap that might be best to follow as far as interim installation? Should one upgrade from 1.8.2 to 1.9 before or after attempting an Nwiki install? Should one install Nwiki at 1.8.2 or at 1.9 will there be upgrade issues (i.e. will install of nwiki at 1.8.2 present upgrade issues to 1.9 and if so how should one address them - for example, if nwiki files are copied into the wiki file structure, then upgrading to 1.9 would possibly over write the nwiki files.... no?) Likewise, will there be issues going from 1.9 to 2 (I would have to guess not since the 2.0 moodle will install nwiki??)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Nwiki upgrade options
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marc, nwiki will arrive with Moodle 2.0. And Moodle 2.0 *requires Moodle 1.9* installed in order to upgrade. I guess the best migration path will be to continue using the glorious old wiki until 2.0 upgrade. Of course there will be a long beta stage, before 2.0 release, and that'll be the time to test and report about such wiki upgrades. Right now we are working hard against Moodle 1.9 to polish all those details that never are detected before release, so we haven't analysed yet how the nwiki refactoring (changes) will be, and what parts of them will be modified. I hope we won't need to modify the DB layer, that will be good news from a complexity (and upgrade) point of view. Obviously, people using nwiki with previous versions of Moodle should be able to upgrade transparently too... but IMHO I'd continue using the old one if upgrade ASAP isn't a must for you. Ciao

ResponsesInList.Title: Nwiki help in Moodle 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: I just made the leap to Moodle 1.9 this week (Mar 8, 2008) and at first seemed to be having a problem with Nwiki. When I looked in my wikis they appeared empty. I noticed a "change student" menu as if in student group mode, but it was set to No Groups. I've never used wiki groups in my main wikis. I figured out that I had to change the Student Mode to Students in group for wiki content be visible and left Group Mode set to No Groups . I guess my logic was backwards because I thought this setting then made student content visible only to students in their same group (though in my situation I put in 95% of the content). Comments? Maybe this will help some other confused soul. Jestin Of course I made nwiki backups before migration!

ResponsesInList.Title: Problem with displaying pages
ResponsesInList.Text: It actual for languages that using non-latin symbols. Developers! Remember that you MUST not print any data in browser before call print_header() because it prevent to create right page headers. For example, we lost "charset" and "Content-Language". So, please check following: 1. All files which UTF-8 encoded should be WITHOUT signature. 2. Nothing will be before <?php at begin of file (it's simple ) 3. No empty line at end of file! (this presents in some files. For example: block_wiki_index.php, block_wiki_ranking.php) 4. Nothing should print before print_header()! Need to examine program logic (see wikitimeline.php for example) This is FireFox view:

ResponsesInList.Title: Image links failing
ResponsesInList.Text: There are various threads about problems uploading images but I can find nothing recent on how to solve problems with image links failing. I had a student inserting an image (that resided on the web) with an address that ended Laughing_buddha_statue_Buddha_gift_m.jpg The image showed up correctly in the editor but only the alternate text showed up in the preview. I tried shortening the name and then it showed up correctly. However, when I experimented to find out the length at which it failed I found I could add letters and numbers until it was way past its original length. Further experimenting suggested length was not the issue but it was to do with the use of upper-case. In particular, if the name began with an upper-case letter it could not move away from upper-case and then back again; if the letter began with lower-case there was no such restriction. So, these are OK... ABcde.jpg ABCDE.jpg abcde.jpg

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need your advice!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Perry thanks for using NWiki, this week someone reported a data loss in NWiki preciselly because he upgraded moodle and replaced the nwiki files. I would do it simpler. ResponsesInList.Title: Blocking certain users in NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: How would I block certain users from being able to access a Wiki? We are using NWiki, and wantÂ to put certain info into a wiki that we would like only our managers to view and access... Also, how do you make the search area not case sensitive, as when you perform a search right now you have to have the case correct, for example the word Copper brings different results than when you use a lower case 'c' (copper)? Finally, how do you eliminate the previous versions of a wiki page, I can perform the above search and it will bring up all older versions of the same page? Thanks, Andie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blocking certain users in NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Create a new role with all the wiki permissions set to 'prohibit; and call it something like 'blocked wiki users'. Then go to 'update this wiki' and click on the tab that allows you to set roles for this module context (locally assigned roles in 1.9) and assign the that role to the users you want to block.

ResponsesInList.Title: Camel Casing
ResponsesInList.Text: I recently had trouble inserting a jpg into the wiki module.Â  I used the Insert Image icon on the toolbar to insert the graphic.Â Â I wasÂ able to see the graphic in the Edit mode but NOT in the View Mode. After a little research, someone suggested to turn off "camel casing."Â  I had orginially save the jpg with two words using a space between.Â I resaved the jpg with all lowercase letters and NO space and itÂ worked. I would like to turn off the camel casing so I do notÂ run into this problem again, but I'm not sureÂ how to do it. Would anyone have any suggestions on how to turn offÂ camel casing? Thanks, Karen

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Camel Casing
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Karen. Attached is a pic of where to find the "disable camel case" in the settings for your wiki. It is a little check box you can see when you click to update the wiki. I have mine checked, too, as I need it off for that particular wiki. Disclaimer: I took this pic while using my admin role and have not double- checked to see that a regular teacher can see the same settings without the admin first tweaking roles. Let me know if you don't see the check box in your wiki. I have to run and can't check teacher view right this second, but hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Importing /uploading wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: You can copyÂ a backup file (zip-format) that is made in course A to course B. After copying a backup file to course B you restore it in course B. Then you can get the same wiki-contents,Â in course A and course B. Step1.Â  In course A, make backup file which containsÂ Wiki contents. Step2. Copy backup file (.zip) from course A to course B. Step3. In courseB, restore it. Backup file isÂ generated on backupdata folderÂ under each course folder.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki issues in the tracker... to 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think the words mean the same. By "Add to the page" I mean a real textarea box with a button, like the one at the bottom of this post. It would be available both in discussion tab and main tab. Why? It does two things--it's a VERY quick way to add comments to a page. Since Moodle is intended for education, we also have to look at how people use Moodle. Examples from real life: Students create a page together and put an "add to the page" box at the top for the teacher. The teacher, who has numerous ones to look at, can just hit the page, type in the "add to the page box" and press submit. The box, depending on options chosen, time stamps with the user name, and can stay at the top of the additions or move down. In-class group work. This is essentially the same as real-time brainstorming. Students quickly add comments and thoughts to pages as they work on them. Real-time brainstorming. In meetings, when we have a projector going and everyone has there laptops, we'll take a 1 minute brainstorming session. That is, everybody types in the "add to the page box" and then presses submit at the end of one minute. Since the page is locked only for the very brief update period, all of the comments end up in the page. Selections. This is similar to brainstorming, but when I have a 500 photos to sort and we need to choose the best, it's fastest to have everybody at the computer and we just quickly project each picture. If they like it, they type the photo number (I use a renaming program to give all of the photos a sequential number starting at 100), but all in the "add to the page" box on the same page. At the end, I dump the list into a spreadsheet and rank from most votes to least votes. This bring in the "wisdom of crowds". Discussions about topics. While the discussion page does exist, you loose the page with content while discussing it. This is good if people when people are only adding two or three lines at a time. In class evaluation: We have 20 students in class writing comments on each others work. Editing with page locking just doesn't work. Multiple points to add: Sometimes, we must have comments in several places. Placing an "add to the page" box makes that very simple. While I do know that we can now edit each section, there are numerous reasons why that is not as successful with younger students, such as the nine-year-olds we now have using wikis. We also have to distinguish between development wikis and production wikis as well. Wikipedia is a production wiki. Each page should always be "complete", with discussion taking place elsewhere, hence their use of the discussion tab. It's "prettified". However, we work in schools. Our wikis are often development wikis. They tend to have intense periods of work, often with multiple people working on them simultaneously. The whole discussion page doesn't have time to develop as work is being done in each page of the wiki when production is due. Now, that doesn't mean I don't think NWiki is a dramatic improvement over ewiki. It is and you all have done a fabulous job.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wrong words (eg. "++") are matched as CamelCase in spite of "Disable CamelCase Linking"
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, Moodlers. I've been in the face of two strange phenomenons under using ewiki on Moodle1.8. Under checkingÂ "Disable CamelCase Linking" on ewiki (Moodle1.8, 1.7, ...), Camel case words (eg. UsingMoodle, WikiModule...) does not match as Camel case. On the other hand, unexpected words (eg. a++, a]+[, ...) will match as Camel case. For example: for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i++)Â Â Â  : HTML editor ->Â  for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i ++ ? )Â  : View page (ewiki) '++' is linked for new page. I don't expect! Another phenomenons is as following. For example: a[] is an array. a[1]Â Â Â : HTML editor -> a 1 ? : View page(ewiki) :Â I want to avoid. a![1]Â  : HTML editor ->Â  a[1]Â  : View page (ewiki) : That's right. a[]Â Â  :Â HTML editor ->Â  a ? : View page(ewiki) :Â Oh? a![]Â Â  : HTML editor ->Â a![]Â Â  : View page (ewiki) : Oh No! a![ ]Â  : HTML editor -> a[ ]Â Â  : View page(ewiki): huum...O, OK? (How to correct these problems?) The cause of these problemsÂ isÂ on following code, in mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "");
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "");
Â Â Â  }Â  else {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
Â Â Â  } EWIKI_CHARS_L/U are used for detecting Camel case words. These constants are usedÂ on regular-expression as follows, "wiki_link_regex" => "\007 [!~]?( \#? \[" style="border-right:0px;border-top:0px;vertical-align:middle;border-left:0px;border-bottom:0px;" alt="[^<>\[" src="http://moodle.org/filter/tex/pix.php/25443382e01c0fa744dccb716a12d8bc.gif" /> \n]+\] | \^[-".EWIKI_CHARS_U.EWIKI_CHARS_L."]{3,} | \b([\w]{3,}ï¼š)*([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,}\#?[\w\d]* | ([a-z]{2,9}://|mailtoï¼š)[^\s \[\] \'\"\)\,<]+ | \w[-_.+\w]+@(\w[-_\w]+[.])+\w{2,}Â Â  ) \007x", and $value = preg_replace_callback("/((\w+ï¼š)?([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."] +){2,}[\w\d]*)/", "ewiki_link_regex_callback", $value); Most important part is ([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,} . If we set that the "Disable CamelCase Linking" is On, both of EWIKI_CHARS_L and EWIKI_CHARS_U become null (blank?). Therefore, regular expression will become to ([]+[]+){2,} . [*] (eg. [A-Za-z0-9]) is meta symbolÂ that meansÂ character class. [*] is not allowed thatÂ the inner partÂ ofÂ brankets is null. /[]+[]+/ is interpreted as [ ]+[ ] + , then the render of ewiki view page will misinterpret non-Camel case word as Camel case word in spite of Disable CamelCase is On. /[]+[]+/ means thatÂ a word matched with the pattern consists of aÂ character ']' or '+' or '['. I propose a modification for this problem. if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "\t");
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "\r");
Â Â Â  }Â  else {
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
Â Â Â  } This patch means that CamelCase word consists of 'Carriage return' and 'Tab code', for example : '\r\t', '\r\t\r\r\t'. This experssion is safe since these strings shallÂ not appear in plain textÂ generally. I'm using ewiki in Japanese. After applying this modification I have no trouble underÂ setting 'Disable CamelCase Linking'Â  On. If youÂ are also in face of this problem, let's try this patch.

ResponsesInList.Title: Warn your students: beware of reload after edit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. The current standard wiki and nwiki versions handle pretty well the concurrence issues. You can't edit a page that other student is editing. BUT. If a user edits a page, saves the changes, and then another user changes the pages... if the firts user goes to the toilet and presses reload when he/she comes back.. then the second edition is lost. Is still in the history but no more in the current page. We need to think about how to deal with this ... I've got some ideas but there are more serious issues to fix before. So warn your students about the reload button!!! Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki can't be loaded
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I am a research assistant for a professor and I run my prof's Moodle, which he uses for one of his classes. Both of us think this application is awesome - it's very versatile and based on feedback from his students, many of his students think the same. We do, however, have a recurring problem with the wiki part of the Moodle. Students are required to add content to an overall course wiki, which helps students collaborate and brainstorm with each other and serves as a good central point for study material for the entire course. This is the second semester that we are using the Moodle for a class, and in both semesters once we reach the end of the semester the wiki fails to load. What I mean by fails to load is that the wiki does not load and it seems like the user session "dies" - once you click on the wiki link the browser will sit there loading forever. You cannot reload the Moodle in the same browser/same computer, you have to go to a different computer and login (either as that same user or a different one) to load the Moodle up again. I've noticed that after about 20 minutes, you can reload the Moodle page from a 'crashed' session, so I believe it has something to do with user sessions. Furthermore, by the end of the semester, the wiki gets pretty damn big - maybe it has something to do with this size? We were thinking of setting up two wikis for next term: one containing information for the first half of the course, and the other for the second half of the course. We are using Moodle 1.7.1 (I think). I'm not at my web server right now so I cannot give more details right this moment, but if anyone is willing to help I will gladly dig up logs and do anything else. I am running the Moodle off of a Power Mac G5 (that's our web server) running Apache , PHP and MySQL . One more thing. I went digging through the My SQL console and I see that the wiki content is all there (and there's a lot of it!). I know I can dump the contents of the wiki SQL tables out - is there a way I can use this to re-create the wiki? I just want the students to have access to the information they contributed, as the final exam is coming up and it would be good study material for them. Thanks a lot to anyone who can offer insight and help, Fil

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Preserving single line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text: I this case we are talking 2 diferent things: * wiki markup: feature... all spaces and newlines are converted to a single space. To create a newline it takes double newline. This is in every single wiki, specially in the new wiki creole syntax ( intiative of universal wiki markup that we will support eventually) * html editor... as we all know the HTML editor is buggy, we in nwiki only tap at the double brackets for wikilinks.. the rest weird stuff the HTMNL editor does by itself ... there's some worky to migrate from html editor to other stuff but this is a moodle wide issue

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Preserving single line breaks?
ResponsesInList.Text:
According to Creole 1.0 , wikis must support \\ to create line breaks, with the xhtml being
. The creole cheat sheet ( http://www.wikicreole.org/wiki/CheatSheet ) does say: "Line ends will be preserved inside paragraphs. You can use " \\ " to force a line break most everywhere." As the Nwiki editor does not support \\ for line breaks. It would be nice if it did so we could tell users that they just have to know a little more markup that will be "standard" across wikis. And, of course, it would be nice if it preserved line breaks in the paragraphs as per the cheat sheet.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Since updating my Moodle system via CVS last Monday (the 24th September) I and students have been able unable to upload files to Wikis - the default Wiki that comes with Moodle, not NWiki, DFWikii etc. When trying to the upload a file via the upload dialogue box below the HTML editor a new tab opens, but with no information about the file I wanted to upload. Normally, a text would appear which I'd copy into the editor to create a link to that uploaded file. When I try to upload a file via the attachments tab I get a the following 'error message' in the attachments page: uplrejsect This happens with all browsers and file types. This has been reported before: click to see previous related messages .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
ResponsesInList.Text: Just to confirm that we are also getting this error. Amanda

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Amanda and anyone else trying to use the default Wiki, In the absence of a solution to this bug (files can't be uploaded) I have come up with a workaround. Using the Database activity module I have created an 'activity' called 'File Bank'. Students upload their files to that, and then copy the URL for the file that they want to add or link to their Wiki. Students then access their Wiki and use the icons in the HTML editor to either add links to files in the 'File Bank', or embed images that have been saved in the 'File Bank'. This seems to work better than the original method of adding attachments to wiki pages. Hope this idea is of use to other moodlers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, we had the same problem here at our end, but I concluded that I have to hack the code myself to get it to work. Now, the problem was in the file moodle_binary_store.php, which can be found within the directory /mod/ewiki/plugins/moodle/ The problem was that the save path and location for the file to be saved was created from the wiki name . I changed this to the following in the function moodle_binary_store_file: function moodle_binary_store_file(&$filename, &$id, &$meta, $ext=".bin") { # READ-Only global $_FILES, $CFG, $course, $wiki, $groupid, $userid, $ewiki_title, $cm; if(!$wiki->ewikiacceptbinary) { error("This wiki does not accept binaries"); return 0; } $entry=wiki_get_entry($wiki, $course, $userid, $groupid); if(!$entry->id) { error("Cannot get entry."); } require_once($CFG-> dirroot .'/lib/uploadlib.php'); $um = new upload_manager('upload',false,false,$course,false,0,true,true); if ( $um->process_file_uploads("$course->id/$CFG->moddata/wiki/$wiki->id/$entry->id/")) { $filename = ''; // this to make sure we don't keep processing in the parent function if(!$id) { $newfilename = $um->get_new_filename(); $id = EWIKI_IDF_INTERNAL.$newfilename; } return true; } error($um->print_upload_log(true)); return false; } I also changed this in the function moodle_binary_get_path: function moodle_binary_get_path($id, $meta, $course, $wiki, $userid, $groupid) { global $CFG,$ewiki_title; $entry=wiki_get_entry($wiki, $course, $userid, $groupid); if(!$entry) { error("Cannot get entry."); } $dir=make_upload_directory("$course->id/$CFG->moddata/wiki/$wiki->id/$entry->id/"); return "$dir"; } So, now it reflects the wiki->id and entry->id instead. It now works for us. Hope it will help somebody else to!

ResponsesInList.Title: NWiki 2.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi guys, we are back from vacation... Ferran Recio ( the F from DFwiki ) is back to the team (and David is not that far, in fact is in the team but in another project that we need to do just to be alive ) In this post I'm presentinga new nwiki version of nwiki that we named NWiki 2.0. But Why ? ... Because NWiki is not going to be in 1.9 but looks like chances are good for it to be in Moodle 2.0 ... So its a good name. This version does not include any new feature except that the installation procedure has been rebuild completelly... (the great pigui is to take the blame). This means that old issues with installation we all have been sufering should be gone, and postgres and othe databases users can install now nwiki... This version should work with 1.8 and 1.9 beta but please, please, please backup your tables before installing it. More information on the general dev forum thread about this release in the moodle docs nwiki roadmap page and in our site . Ah the code is in the CVS (contrib) and also in a new release in our site , please be careful when trying and backup your database if is a production site!!! May the force be with all of us! Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Export pages in Wiki no longer works
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello, I am using the standard wiki in moodle 1.8.3 +. This bug has also been replicated in the Demo Moodle site (username " teacher ", password " demo "). On older versions of moodle, e.g. moodle 1.8, it was possible to export a wiki as a zip file, which could be saved on a users hard disk. The zip file contained an HTML version of the wiki. This was a great feature since it allowed students to keep an off-line 'portfolio' of their work. This feature ( along with other features of the Wiki module ) now appears to be 'broken'. In order to export a wiki, the user clicks on the -- Choose Wiki Links -- pull-down menu, and selects 'Export pages'. Then teachers or admin can choose where to export the wiki: to a directory in the course files, or a Downloadable zip archive. Click here to see an image of this export page . Students can not choose, and are only able to download their wiki as a zip archive. However, on clicking on the [Export] button, the following appears at the top of the page (this is just a sample): 
```text
PK ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½LR70ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½group.htmleQï¿½nï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½W2SZï¿½ï¿½Vï¿½cKQG0ï¿½Fï¿½ï¿½2$rTï¿½ï¿½ gï¿½Dï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½;ï¿½cï¿½M>j ...
```
 Click here to see a screenshot of this page . Teachers can still successfully export wiki pages to the course Files diretory. I do hope that this can be fixed (see MDL-11816 ) since it appears the new wiki (NWiki) will not be a part of the standard Moodle release until the end of next year - version 2.0 . Or, should I take the plunge and install Nwiki now?

ResponsesInList.Title: Export - MediaWiki . . . Inport - NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I have tried and tested NWikis ability to export and import XML files and is seams to work flawlessly. I then got the idea to try and export some pages from a MediaWiki site (WikiBooks) to be precise, and try and import them into NWiki ... Well you can all guess ... it did not work, however, after closer inspection of the MediaWiki XML file I realized that it should be possible to write a parser that would take the MediaWiki XML tags and replace them with NWiki replacements. There are many tags in the NWiki XML file that are LMS dependent, these are what makes NWiki more suited to our educational needs. I am guessing that if there is no corresponding tag in the MediaWiki file then they can be simply inserted with defaults. I am imagining a stand alone parser at the moment but I'm sure that this could be written into the php scripts that read in the XML files and it could be implemented transparently in NWiki. What do the rest of you wiki'ers think? Linds

ResponsesInList.Title: Is the default wiki a mistake?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am one of the faculty at my campus testing alternative LMS's. I have experience with TLM and WebCT. I like Moodle and I loved that it had a wiki. But now I tell people, "If you are choosing Moodle because it has a wiki, then you are making a bad decision." The manual does not answer my questions, and I see pages and pages of postings here about wikis, but most of them appear unanswered...no reply. It is too late now, but should I have avoided the default eWiki and loaded up some other module like nWiki? I've only been using it for a few days now, but here is what sucks about eWiki (maybe it wouldn't suck if I could figure it out): I checked all of the Student admin options (Allow: 'set page flags,' 'remove pages,' 'strip pages,' and 'revert mass changes'), but students receive a "Sorry, but you do not currently have permissions to do that (Manage wiki settings)" message. Sometimes links to external web pages work, and sometimes they don't. There seems to be no rhyme or reason. Seeding the wiki with a page name for the first page doesn't work. The students still get a 'blank slate' when they first enter their wiki. Students can't seem to upload a graphic to their wiki. Somewhere along the line, as a student, I was able to upload a file, but the 'location' that I was told that it was stored in, was of no value in its retrieval. So if the student's graphic goes into my database and they can't use it, then what is the point? Am I doing it all wrong, or are these known problems with the Moodle wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is the default wiki a mistake?
ResponsesInList.Text: moodle.org doesn't even use the Moodle wiki for Moodle documentation...it uses MediaWiki . http://docs.moodle.org/en/MoodleDocs:About Does thatÂ answer your question? "If you are choosing Moodle because it has a wiki, then you are making a bad decision." I would say your advice is spot-on! Steve

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is the default wiki a mistake?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you haven't started using wikis yet--start with nwiki-it has it's problems but it is much nicer and adds great tools. It gets basic wiki things (like page locking) right. By the way, the use of mediawiki for the docs is an entirely different issue-mediawiki's administration tools are primitive (to say the least) and limited--it is suited for a site wiki (like wikipedia or docs.moodle.org) run by techies, but it is not at all suited for multi-level permissions and groups that a course based wiki required.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is the default wiki a mistake?
ResponsesInList.Text: mediawiki's administration tools are primitive (to say the least) and limited--it is suited for a site wiki (like wikipedia or docs.moodle.org) run by techies, Hummm...primitive and only suited for techies . but it is not at all suited for multi-level permissions and groups that a course based wiki required. Well, that's one opinion, but I've been usingÂ Mediawiki in one of my courses for a couple of years...works great for me. That's not the point here anyway...no one said anything about replacing the Moodle Wiki with Mediawiki. The point is,Â Moodle has a wiki (or 2 or 3) but none of them are good enough, it would seem,Â to handle the moodle documentation task. I wouldn't find this strange if Moodle didn't have a wiki, bit it does and chooses not to use it...there is a message there if you choose to see it . The test of how nice nwiki is will be whether it's used by moodledocs ...we'll see. But until then, I still agree with the poster's advice: " If you are choosing Moodle because it has a wiki, then you are making a bad decision ." Steve

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is the default wiki a mistake?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hummm...primitive and only suited for techies . Not sure what you mean here? The test of how nice nwiki is will be whether it's used by moodledocs...we'll see. I also don't understand your reasoning here, why would this be the test? Seems to me that how well it fits the needs of teachers using it in courses would be more important than whether it is used by docs.moodle.org?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is the default wiki a mistake?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is the default wiki a mistake?
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, I'm still not understanding you? I said in reference to the original question: If you haven't started using wikis yet--start with nwiki-it has it's problems but it is much nicer and adds great tools. It gets basic wiki things (like page locking) right. How exactly is this 'blinding' or 'blinded'? I've always done my best to give folks here open, honest, straighforward answers...when I've failed in this it has been in my lack of skill in communication, not in any decision on what to 'let on' or not. As far as what is used for docs.moodle.org, if this was switched to nwiki today, it wouldn't be a good test of whether nwiki is ready to use in courses -it wouldn't test course based functions such backup and restore, grading, group management, student files, etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can't access wiki in group mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stuart, did you try to use Moodle Doc to learn ho to use group functions ? In the search zone, "group". ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki as official wiki?

The teacher administrator can even redirect the RSS feed to a feedburner proxied to spare bandwidth and server load. I've assigned a developer to work in RSS this very month Cheers Ludo (waiting for neews... )

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki as official wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki as official wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stuart and community, unfortunately that's true. And it is as it must be for two reasons: (1)there is pressure to get Moodle 1.9 released ASAP (in the general dev forum we can see that, and who's behind it), and (2) nwiki needed to be reviewed by the community seniors, as was stated in the developers conference last April. Ten days ago, after applying considerable pressure (as you know) finally NWiki got reviewed (I really owe it to the great Knigth in Shiny Armor to take the time to do it and to endorse us, thanks Eloy!!). As is expected to be NWiki requires some modifications (specially in the installation script and data migration process, because was designed for moodle 1.6 and needs to be ported to the XMLDB engine). I completely agree with the Moodle experts resolution. I'm only sad because it came so late that we are almost too late to fix the issues. The story repeats itself again Right now we are (specially Pigui) working on the issues reported. We will try to have another candidate ready before august , but if more issues come up, we will go on vacation anyway. I'm only asking for a little fairness here, IF THERE'S REALLY A WILL TO PUT NWIKI IN 2.0 .. THEN IT MUST BE IN THE 2.0 Branch SINCE DAY ONE. Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki as official wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh well, I bet you will be glad of the holiday! When the next candidate release comes out I'll run my parser tests over it and give you any bug feedback. All the best, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NWiki as official wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: "I'm only asking for a little fairness here, IF THERE'S REALLY A WILL TO PUT NWIKI IN 2.0 .. THEN IT MUST BE IN THE 2.0 Branch SINCE DAY ONE." I wholeheartedly agree. The current wiki is a sorry mess and certainly not up to the standard of the rest of the Moodle activities . Wiki is one of the few purpose built group activities within Moodle (all very well talking about workshop, but how many faculty actually use it in practice?) and the current version is not maintained, and there has been no attention or bug fixes since 1.4 as far as I am aware. Nwiki is clearly superior and I am rather disappointed that it has not made it's way into the general release. Keep it up Ludo -- you've got another winner like Alberto Contador in the Tour! Mark

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your support Mark! Cheers Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Media wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I've noticed the Moodle documentation is based on Media Wiki but I can't find a Media wiki plug-in in the listings, can anyone tell me where I can get this? Carl.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Media wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't. docs.moodle.org is not integrated with moodle in any way. That site just has a theme similar to this one. Media wiki is designed for hosting huge wikis containing lots if information with lots of powerful tools to manage that, but to administer it well, you have to learn quite a lot. The wiki in moodle is designed to let teachers easily set up simple activities for their students. So what is suitable for one situation is not suitable for the other.

ResponsesInList.Title: Individual student/teacher wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I would be very grateful for any advice here as I'm new to Moodle and pretty sure someone, somewhere has come up with the answer to my problem. I want to set up a system whereby a student can answer questions interspersed on a page of teaching which is available to everyone on the course and the teacher respond directly under the answer, the student reply to the teacher, etc. Like a conversation - the wiki principle but, and I think this is the crunch, each individual student's conversation with the teacher only visible to those two people. The Dialogue module is fine for a single question but gets clumsy and doesn't sit within the visible, on-screen teaching notes. Any suggestions will be most welcome - thank you in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual student/teacher wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: The Wiki (or NWiki ) can serve this purpose since there is a wiki for each student mode where only the teacher and the student can access the student wiki. In NWiki there are also discussion pages (mediawiki style) which may be useful. BUT the trick is that the teacher MUST sweep the student wikis looking for questions. Options: a small block for the wiki (< spam >did you that NWiki has activity specific blocks </spam>) can be developed so that the student may be able to send a internal message to the teacher including (automatically) a link to the student's wiki and the question involved. <even more spam>NWiki includes a new feature that allows you te create grups wikis and student wikis out of a wiki template (a wiki previously created)... that can be used to help the students and grups to have a basic structure to begin with </even more spam> Hope that was helpfull and sorry for the spam... but I'm begining to be desperate to call someones attention. Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual student/teacher wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Ludo I'll have a play and investigate what you've suggested. You mention 'activity specific blocks ' - perhaps a silly question but where can I find these? I appreciate the help. Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Individual student/teacher wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Is not a silly question... there is a moodle directive that controls whether the teacher can or cannot include blocks in activity modules NWiki has some specific (juicy) activity modules. You can fin the option to enable blocks on activities in Admin -> appearance -> themes -> themes settings -> Show blocks on module pages I don't know/understand why is not enabled by default... but I don't know /understand many things in this world .... have a look at some of the available NWiki specific blocks in our demo /documentation wiki Cheers Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: CSS and eWiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
I am wanting to define the attributes of a paragraph for editing and viewing wikis. Specifically, I would like to assign a different 'margin-bottom' value that would apply to every "

" paragraph of every wiki. The ewiki readme seems to imply that this is possible (without the use of css markup plugins), but I can't work out where I would insert the style definition. Has anyone done this or something similar? Any help would really be appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS and eWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: This is more of a "themes" issue. You'll need to create your own custom moodle theme and then over-ride the css for paragraphs. I haven't tested this, but something like the following might work: #wiki-view wiki p { margin-bottom: 10px; } --Stuart.

I attempted to define "p {..." in this file but made no difference. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS and eWiki

The following actually works, but only for moodle 1.8+ with the nwiki module: #mod-wiki-view div.box.generalbox p { margin-bottom: 50px; } Let me know if you are using any different versions and I'll see what I can do. --Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: dfwiki: Selected HTML editor doesn't stay
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, exactly. I guess it wasn't a bug, then. It was intended to be like that. At any rate, I think it is better if the teacher can choose the default editor. The students can always choose to change it later on if they want. But this way you can avoid confusions like the ones my students have. Think that Moodle is used in all kinds of environments: even in primary schools. So the possibility to maintain a familiar environment is always desirable in some contexts. The teacher can judge whether with his or her group of students the dfwiki editor is more desirable as the default editor. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: dfwiki: Selected HTML editor doesn't stay
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo: Thanks for all that you and your team are doing with dfwiki. The words "Change to one of the following editors" tells the new user to change to an editor other than the default editor.Â  As this works now, the choice cannot be changed once selected. In order to avoid this confusion, the teacher should be able to make the default editor the only choice. In the meantime, the option "Change to one of the following editors" could be moved down below the buttons: save, preview, cancel. That way new users will be more likely to use the default editor and not lock themselves into one of the other options. Again thanks for all that you are doing, John

One of the key things about a wiki is that the markup is simple so that you are encouraged to concentrate on content rather than spending time of pretty colours and presentation . May be what is needed is a check box in the wiki settings next to "preferred editor" which says "Force preferred editor"? Or will this just overload the settings page with more options? --Stuart.

Upgrading dfwiki (start) (mysql): SHOW COLUMNS FROM mdl_modules (mysql): UPDATE mdl_modules SET name = 'dfwiki', version = '2006052502', cron = '0', lastcron = '0', search = '', visible = '0' WHERE id = '38' dfwiki installed. Many thanks Richard Taylor

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Install Failed
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think you can take things backwards as the database will now be changed for the new wiki. You did make a backup before you started, right?? Anyhow, this isn't a corrupted activity, it's just that the lang file is missing. The lang file is a php page which maps placeholders such as preview to language strings such as Preview. In language supported by moodle has one. In the nwiki you unpacked, look for the lang file and make sure that lang/en_utf8 folder inside the nwiki download is copied across to your moodle install. You should note that even after you do this there may still be a few 'gaps'. The nwiki is being developed by the dfwiki team in Spain. I've offered to help them with their language translation. Keep an eye out for nwiki releases and hopefully the gaps in the lang file will gradually be filled as well as nwiki bugs being fixed. --Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Install Failed

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Several students editing a Wiki at the same time?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey there - first up, itsbgreat to see you trying to use a Wiki.Â  But what you seem to have attempted to do is akin to if you can imagine that you had a car with 30 driving wheels, then how many people could steer it at one time?Â  At least that's my simplistic analogy. I suggest you come at this from a different angle - instead of thinking I want to use a Wiki, now where can I use it IN MY CLASS?Â  Why not think of a series of scenarios where you think students could collaborate OUTSIDE the classroom and set a task that requires that to be done, say, before the next lesson . It's 'horses for courses'. Also to lessen the impact of your problem - you could always try creating GROUPS within the Wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Basic wiki infos to add to the help [Re: Which wiki?]
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Helen, I myself had to struggle through this topic a while ago. For a newbee in the discussion it is indeed hard to understand why all these Wikis are used - it especially takes a while to understand that some of them are just different names for new versions of identical wikis. Neither the link you posted nor the Help Chapter 11 referenced there really tells what wikis there are which of them are the same why there are different kinds itegrated in Moodle Both ressources are very helpful for someone trying to understand what one can do with a Wiki and how it works in general though. I would therefore suggest to add a small passage to both with the following information: Moodle's wiki is built on top of an older wiki system called Erfurt wiki, which is also referred to as ewiki (second is just a guess but interesting to know if so): ewiki = Erfurt Wiki . So if you just choose "add Wiki" you get an Erfurt Wiki (which is helpful to know if you want to look up the syntax). Erfurt Wiki development is not maintained any more, so Moodle devolopment steers to replacing it by DFWiki/nWiki: Moodle: eWiki -> nWiki Where nWiki is a new development line based on the former DFWiki: DFWiki -> nWiki . This is why there are two Wikis in Moodle. Anyway the dfwiki will have a old wiki import and restore feature (for ewiki?) so you will be able to upgrade without much trouble. This is at least the picture as far as I got it after a while - probably I'm still wrong with the one or other - sources (among others): http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=30921 http://morfeo.upc.es/crom/mod/wiki/view.php?id=22 Knowing this, all the rest of the discussion in this forum and some other ressources immediately starts to make (more) sense. What do you think? Keep going, Achim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Basic wiki infos to add to the help [Re: Which wiki?]
ResponsesInList.Text: Since we realized that we may be coming into the moodle core we always did consider very important that IN ANY CASE NO DATA SHOULD BE LOST. Sometimes due to bugs and bad astral conjugations somebody may have lost anything, but these are rare exceptions. If backups exist all data can be recovered and will be migration scripts from ewiki 1.4 - 1.8 , DFwiki 1.5 and 1.6 and NWiki upgrades are absolute painless. We are even thinking about a option migration script that turns ewiki page syntax into Mediawiki (the most standard). Right now NWiki allows choosing the markup of each page in the same wiki activity (at creation time). And that's not everything.. wait a little and you'll see OpenOffice Writter documents exported and imported online from moodle nwiki activities and complete PDF printing and.... uh! That's considered to be a secret... let's say its a rumor Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deleting attachments to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Celia, You have to go to the Files section of the Moodle course (as an administrator) and drill down through 'moddata' then a fodler underneath this (which turns out to be 'wiki') then you have a folders under this with numbers that correspond to the students in the course (you have to figure out which number corresponds to which student!). Going into one of these folders gives you folders for each wiki created. Then you'll find any uploaded files within that folder.Â  At this point, if you've found the file you want to get rid of you can click the check box and delete completely. HOWEVER, the reference to this file does not disappear from the Attachments tab in the student's wiki and the file can be downloaded although it does not contain anything. I am not sure whether this has been labelled as a bug but the problem has been around for at least a couple of Moodle versions. The wiki situation in Moodle is a mess. The 'Efurt' wiki which is the one currentlyÂ  distributedÂ  in Moodle has this problem which I thinkÂ  renders it unusable (how do you tell students that they cannot delete attachments they mistakenly uploaded?).Â  Work on this has stopped in favour of Ludo's Dfwiki but installing that one is rather painful and it's apparently not slated for inclusion as the default wiki until v1.8. This is a great shame in my view and in the interim I am having to look elsewhere for a professional wiki such as Twiki. Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deleting attachments to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thankyou very much for the help

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Deleting attachments to a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: There is another way to get around this by using the â€œPage flagsâ€ function. Go into the Moodle wiki page and in the administration drop down menu in the top right click on â€œset page flagsâ€. If you untick the â€œBinâ€ box for the attachments they will not display. You can give students the right to set page flags in the Wiki settings, so they should be able to do this themselves.

ResponsesInList.Title: Restore old wiki''s in NWiki- Howto
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, a question recently raised lately is how does Nwiki deal with old wikis: migration and restore issues. NWiki migrates automatically old wiki contents when is installed. We worked very hard to be sure this works, and so far it does!!!! This process works with moodle 1. to 1.9 To restore old wiki backups in a nwiki the process is not completely automatic. Meaning that when you restore the course the old wikis will not be restored if nwiki is installed. You need to create a wiki activity use the IMPORT XML option and then select your backup file and choose the wiki you wish to restore. I understand this is not the best option but would be very hard to maintain a restore process depending on N wiki formats. The IMPORT XML also works to import old good DFWikis. Cheers Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Why I love and hate NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: 1. Why I love NWiki. I really love NWiki as the teacher, as the user. It is much better than former eWiki . It is really big progress in the publication of texts in Moodle. That's all. 2. Why I hate NWiki. As the developer I hate NWiki up to depth of soul! We shall recollect dfWiki. It was the good version. Yes, it had lacks, for example, global variables, but they were not everywhere. For this version I could write patch, allowing to insert wiki-pages into any place Moodle ( http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=42325 ). Martin has told - global variables should retire (I agree with him!). What was got as a result? Now there are a huge parameter $WS in which have fallen down everything, that only it is possible. There is no opportunity to understand, what from contents of $WS is necessary in THIS function! And here and there $WS also a global variable. I cannot improve NWiki because it works only through the web-interface. It transfers a lot of information through the hidden fields to displayed page and receives it from there. It is not adapted simply to cause the necessary function. For example, using "echo" command. Most of functions should return result, not a send in browser because sometime developer need to get result for next manipulations. Next example. I need to create page. Think it simply? First I searched, where it is doing. Has found. Oh! It seems simply - only one additional function wiki_sintax_find_internal_links with one parameter! But if we look inside - welcome global $WS. Than to fill this huge variable to me it is not clear. NWiki works very slowly. No wonder. $WS it is transferred from one function to another, it is filled on 90 % with the information which not necessary at present. Time and resources of a server is spent for all this. Let's look at development Moodle. It is system which there has begun one person. It too all over again was not ideal. But already for a long time we observe a stable direction in development - all in Moodle becomes modular and object-oriented. Expenses for support and modernization of system increase exponential with increase in volume of a code. Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a unique way to curb this process. Abundantly clear, that NWiki should be rewrite to use OOP. The evil $WS should be beaten. In function it is necessary to transfer only that information which there is necessary. Formats, imports, etc. should be easily connected to NWiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why I love and hate NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I somehow need to agree with you. DFWiki code was smaller and easier to hack than NWiki. Then came the moodle big guns and tod us to change things here and there, each 3 months a new set of issues ( when we took moodle 1.4 code as example and there where global variables and lots of things that have been banned at any point. As developer I also feel that we need to change some of the architecture of nwiki to be able to breath. We are taking this task step by step. The parser has been rewriten, and now we've got full mediawiki suport (without templates and some too mediawiki specific things). We are already wrapping functionalities under layers for developers to hack on to. But we need to take this step by step, because a BIG deal of work has been done to import data from ewiki and impement senseless features simply beacuse they where present in ewiki. I'm open to suggestions for functionalities and changes on implementation. We are actually doing some architecture changes ourselves. But regarding the "being the oficial wiki" I must say: * NWiki is WAY WAY better than ewiki in ** usability ** has less bugs ** has a active group of developers willing to improve it and change anything needed So the moodle big guns have to decide whether to upgrade to nwiki with its exposed architecture problems (that will be fixed) or to keep with a wiki module that (auto-censured) as LOTS of teachers have told me. Thanks for your comments Dmitry Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why I love and hate NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: >But regarding the "being the oficial wiki" I must say... Yes, yes, yes and yes!!! NWiki is The Best module of Moodle! I realy think so! It should be "official wiki"! I'm happy if architecture of module is changing. PS: Right now I has done MSWord's template for creating Wikis in text processor. Last problem - import results (creating wiki-pages in DB).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why I love and hate NWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Dmitry! we are developing a plugin for ms word and open office to export docs to a wiki using a OOP version of the tiddlywiki integration server files... that will become a programming interface for you and other hackers to play with nwiki More news on thet soon Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Are wikis the best way to post documents in moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, I am trying to get over 25 procedure documents into our moodle system. Currenlty the documents are all hard copy, with the content being stored in source files (with all sorts of extensions: pdf, word, excel, html, etc). I could just post a pdf of the document but i was hoping for somthing a little more fluid. Would wikis be a good way of keeping 1 source for all the content of a docuement? If so is there a way to break up sections and pages within a wiki so you could print off specific areas instead of the whole document? I understand what wikis are but my experience is limited, Any help would be appreciated. cheers, Mike. PS. if there is a better mod for this I'd love to hear it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Are wikis the best way to post documents in moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Wiki's would be a good choice. You will have to create the structure by inserting links (doc, section, page) and users will have to navigate it. Printing two consecutive pages could be a real pain. Prototype it first to see if it meets your needs. Also have a look at the third-party Book module . Each one of your original documents would become a chapter in the book, and sections would become sub-chapters. Book is printer-friendly. For an example of a Book, see the Finnish Moodle Teacher's Manual .

ResponsesInList.Title: A better wiki editor?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I've had some success integrating s5 presentations into our local mediawiki installation. After some boasting and showing off, our moodle people are interested, and I've hacked the ewiki code a little to add a 'view as slideshow' button to ewiki pages, which takes the wikitext and converts it to an s5 slideshow. I'd really like to get this off the ground, it provides a simple way for groups of students to collaborate on creating presentations, gets away from needing powerpoint, and pushes users towards focusing on content rather than form. HOWEVER, the default wysiwyg editor is not really appropriate for this, as it is slanted towards html rather than wikitext, and our moodle people rightly think wikitext is something of a barrier to non-tech people using it. I'd like to use wikiwyg , but I'm a bit lost as to where is the right place to cause the appropriate javascript to be loaded. Can anyone give me some hints? Or set me right as to why this is a bad idea?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Syncronize your nwiki with a local tiddlywiki :-O
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Juvenal, these files must be copied on your mod/wiki (nwiki) directory in your moodle server http://morfeo.upc.es/crom/mod/wiki/view.php?id=22&page=How+do+I+get+the+ImportDFwikisPlugin+server+side+scripts+working%3F&gid=0&uid=0 These files cover all the syncronization features. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: whoa, slow down
ResponsesInList.Text: If you need a global wiki you've got two options ( tree in fact) * use mediawiki same way as moodle does, using it as http://docs.moodle.org * create a course where all the users have access and set up a wiki (ewiki or nwiki ( I'd rather nwiki but I'm partial on this one ) and then just create links from the courses to the wiki pages as link resources. * you can also create the wiki as an activity in the main course. (moodle home page) cheers
