ResponsesInList.Title: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to teach my students how to maintain a Reading Wiki where they can keep notes on their reading. I have created the Wiki, but for each article read I would like the student to have a Summary page, a Inquiries page and a Contributors page. I am relatively unfamiliar with the terminology used in wikis so I do not know if I need to create the article name as a category and then create the Summary, Inquiries, and Contributors pages as sub-categories (pages). I had tried simply using the brackets; however, then other articles link to that page. I would appreciate any advice on how to accomplish what I am trying to do with the wikis which could be outlined as: Class Reading Wiki Article #1 Summary Inquiries Contributors Article #2 Summary Inquiries Contributors Article #3 etc, etc. The reason I want the inquiries on separate pages is that I want the students to be able to edit at the same time. In other words a student could be working on the summary page while another is simultaneously working on the inquiries. If this could be accomplished by keeping it all on one page (as it appears in Moodle Docs - which I realize is a different type of wiki) that would be fine. Thanks again for any advise as I try to incorporate this in to my class. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: I remain hopeful that some wiki expert will be able to help me figure out how to have repetitive subpage names in a wiki. I have read the documentation in MoodleDocs to no avail. The closest thing I found was a category but I am not able to get that working. I want my students to do reading summaries and come up with questions based on the reading. I want a summary and questions subpage for each article. I understand how to create a page; however, when they create a [Questions] link on the Article 2 page it takes them to the already completed [Questions] page for Article 1. I would greatly appreciate any guidance in wrapping my mind around this wild wiki world. Peace.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Anthony, I am by no means an 'expert', but my solution would be to create all the required pages with individual names and then to hyperlink to the appropriate page using the menu structure that you suggest. You can even hide the original wiki that you created to create all the different pages and then create a new wiki with the hyperlinks on it, so that you dont get the legacy wiki page links. Does that make sense? It might be a bit of a fudge, but it works!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Nigel - Thanks for your response. I am not sure that I completely understand.Â  I think you are suggesting that the pages be created using names like Article1Summary, Article2Summary, etc. to prevent the linking from taking the student to the same place; however, I want it to be displayed simply as summary. My attempts at using [Article1Summary | Summary] have not worked since even after the page is created I see the wiki new page question mark. When I click on it, then it takes me to the page but it is clear to me that something is not working. I am wondering if on a page, could I have sections ?Â Where students could modify oneÂ section at a time. I want the student doing the summary and the student doing the questions to be able to be writing and working at the same time without interfering with one another. Unfortunately, I do not understand that a legacy wiki page link is but I would happily accept the fudge.

Moodle wikis (all of them, just by being in Moodle architecture) offer us some solutions:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
ResponsesInList.Text: Ludo - thanks for the reply and congrats on the recent releases. A) I am using groups which does manage setting up a wiki for each section. This aspect is working very well. B) In order to preserve the richness of wiki style interaction, I want all of the articles to be in a single wiki activity. C) I will have to check out nwiki and see if that might not be the best solution since the likelihood of having students simultaneously edit the same page can be reduced. I was trying to avoid some user frustration of being told that someone else had edited the page since them. But I do like the idea of being able to provide a style guide or template. D) Since I am working with high school students in the U.S., disciplined though they may be, it is probably best not to rely too much on a naming convention although that may be my best long term solution. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add another page to Nwiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, Go to this link which talks about how to use wiki in moodle. http://edu.bioinformatics.org/help.php?module=wiki&file=howtowiki.html Instructions are valid for other wikis as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add another page to Nwiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi christ, there are two ways to create a new page. a) edit a page. In the text place the pagename betwen double brackets save the page... when viewing the page you will see a linked ? besides the new pagename. Click and the you will got to the new page editor... the first time you edit a page you can switch to the markup format you wish to use (dfwiki for mediawiki markup format, ewiki for old wiki syntax I would not do it, and HTMLEditor which is usefull sometimes) b) in the admin page enable the variable that allos the use of blocks in activity pages... then in the wiki turning the [blocks editing on] you can add a block named wiki-create a new page that allows to create a new page. This secon strategy should be used alhong with the Page list block, because the new page will most likely be an orphaned page. The admin block has a tool to keep track of orphaned pages. See our doumentation and example wiki Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add another page to Nwiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the help ludo!

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki tables could not be set up successfully
ResponsesInList.Text: Decided to stay with Moodle 1.6.x and install nwiki for that version.Â  Upon install we receive many 'success' messages but the final message says, wiki tables could NOT be set up successfully! ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ( mysql ): SELECT * FROM mdl_user WHERE id = '1' AND username = 'guest' LIMIT 1 Not sure what to do from here. Pat

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki tables could not be set up successfully
ResponsesInList.Text: Just realized I copied and posted the wrong text.Â  Here's the real error message: 1101: BLOB/TEXT column 'intro' can't have a default value

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki tables could not be set up successfully
ResponsesInList.Text: So once I did a search for the correct error in the forums I found the info needed.Â  Commenting out the STRICT_TRANS_TABLES in MySQL 's ini file moved us on.Â  We had four tables that already existed in the db.Â  Once we dropped those and continued the Moodle process our wiki install was successful Thanks to all that post problems and solutions. Pat

ResponsesInList.Title: Blank page when viewing a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Happy New Year to all. Suddenly, one of my teachers is saying a wiki he created, and has been working with is showing up blank. Upon clicking on the link, the url appears in the address bar (http://domainname/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=2602) and then the spinning wheel goes for 30 seconds (always 30 seconds, I timed it) and then stops with a blank page showing. On the bar at the bottom is the word "done". I can edit the set up of the wiki, I can create a new wiki in this course, and wikis in other courses seem to be working fine. If I understand the log, there is no record of a view of that particular wiki even though I tried numerous times. Any thoughts would be most welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blank page when viewing a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Most probably the wiki page takes to long to process (more than 30 sec.) Can you try these suggestions: If you are the maintainer of the machine go to your php.ini file and adapt max_execution_time = 30 to a higher value. If you can't control the php settings of your webser you can try to put Best is not to make one large wiki page but split them in smaller one's

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blank page when viewing a wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Herbert, Thanks for responding. I had suspected a time out issue even before I posted. When I arrived at my office this am, I upped the max_execution_time to 60. Seems to have solved the problem. I also sent a note to the teacher about large wiki pages. Thanks again. Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki party - everyone invited!!!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Moodlers, as you know Ludo (Marc Alier) and his team has been working hard with their new wiki module. After some months the module seems to be really near production-ready so we need to perform a KEY test to check if, finally, it's able to replace the old wiki. Such test is about to guarantee that old contents will be migrated smoothly to the new one, without losing anything in the conversion. So, to be able to execute that test successfully we would want to invite all you to create as many and complex wiki activities you can in order to be able to test the migration thoroughly. Here is the Party Plan: 1.- Everybody interested, go to http://test.moodle.com and enter the WIKI Arena Party. 2.- Credentials will be required. They are, simply: teacher/teacher. 3.- Once in the Party, feel free to create one Wiki activity and fill it with all sort of content. The Chef's suggestions include: Copy/Paste complex old-wiki pages from your sites Restore Wiki activities from standard course backups (be careful) Create manually any type of content (links, images...)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki party - everyone invited!!!
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Eloi, this week we'll be making backups from the wiki arena and conducting migrations on our test sites. Please guys, help us make this work!!! If we don't due for 1.6 ... TIA and Regards Ludo

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Samuli, works for me now. Ciao

Then, as the teacher, added one page to my own account, just a simple heading and two paragraphs of text, saved it and got: " Notice : Undefined index: 26 in /home/moodtest/public_html/mod/wiki/lib.php on line 493 " It's just a notice, but still... Non-ascii chars in the eWiki page names break a lot of stuff too

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki party - everyone invited!!!
ResponsesInList.Text: Yep, I agree that the eWiki module has some limitations and problems. That's one (the main one, perhaps) of the causes to test the new dfWiki module and how it migrates all our old contents. If the conversion runs smoothly (no data loss) and, if the newer wiki works like a charm (far better than the old one), the correct conclusion seems to be to replace the old one. Then, we'll have one better wiki module inside Moodle, better supported and with an amazing future. A cool evolution! Else we'll continue using the current module, with all its limitations and problems. Some sort of work can be performed to improve it, of course, but my personal opinion after looking the ewiki code some months ago, is really about to change to the new alternative (obviously if the conditions remarked in the previous paragraph are satisfied). Ciao

ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you to all of those who have joined us in the wiki arena to make a deep migration test for the new wiki, the wiki arena now has been migrated to New -Wiki. Good news is that it worked and everything seems ok. Now I must ask you to plat with the wiki arena to hunt for some bugs and to check out if all the content that was suposed to be there is it really. We have allready detected some issues and we are allready working hard on it. DFwiki team has also grown up, and a set of new developers are starting to write their usefull code lines. DFwiki will continue as an alternative module that we'll use to test our mad ideas, before integrating them into wiki. This is a short list of what's to come: * a-la mediawiki discussion pages * pdf printing and html/opendoc export along with wikibook * new improved diff features * complete grading * major/minor edit swich * page voting * new edit modes (specially for those who teach programming languages ) * better atached files management * edit mode speciall blocks And last but not least wikipodcasting : text2speech and podcast your wiki pages. We count on you to test it, imporve it and use it on your moodle sites. Ludo and the dfwiki team.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: I've just been using the standard wiki with a class of students writing essay plans and they have run into trouble saving their work. One student received a message saying that he couldn't save his wiki because another student was working on it and lost what he'd been writing, another student ended up with someone elses' work on her wiki page and several only had part of their work saved. Is this normal when many people try to save concurrently under this setup, or is it a new problem with 1.7? Matt

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt, several students can work on the same wiki at the same time so long as they are all working on different pages (all pages must have a unique name otherwise links will be created e.g in your case if they all tried to create a page called essay plan, only the first one to save would create the page and everyone else would create links to that page....) I have found that it is best to create the first page of the wiki and include every students name in [] brackets so that when they click on the ? after their name a unique page is created in their name. If they add further pages to their page each page name should be unique, so perhaps get them to add their student number or initials to the page name. Hope this helps. Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Nigel, that makes a lot of sense. I kind of assumed that when I set it to 'student wiki' that it would make one wiki page for each student automatically as suggested by the fact that the drop-down contains all of the students names and that was more or less what the pop-up help thing suggested. Iwould expect to have to use your technique if I had set it to 'groups' and 'No groups'. Did I misinterpret this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt, You are corrcect, if you set Type to Student then they should each have their own Wiki. I have been doing it this way for ages as a way of providing student feedback. I set type to student and group mode to no groups. This then ensures that the students cannot see each others entries.

ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to implement MOODLE as a support and training site for my company. On the support side, I had been using PHPBB as a place to enter and store hints and fixes we have found for the various systems problems. So right now I have a phpbb forum for the phone system, and entry for the voice mail system, software, and so on. what I would like is a place were anyone can record the steps the have found that will fix a particular problem and have a place were others can add to the solution if they find something else that works. I tried using the BOOK module, but that is too restrictive in that others don't seem to be able to add to it. I have played with the wiki module thinking that would allow others to add to the entry but it looks like i would need separate wikis for each system, that is on for the phones, one for the voice mail, one for the hardware and so on. Am I correct in my thinking here? I have also looked at using the forum module in the same manner as I did with the PHPBB installation. Here again I seemed to run into issues in that when created on the main page, it seems only the admin is able to edit or add to the forum. Perhaps my problem is in my understanding of how MOODLE works and in how I have it set up. Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Regards Rick

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki vs forum
ResponsesInList.Text: I would say one wiki would be enough, with separate pages for each issue. The front page should be the 'forum overview', with links to each issue. The problem with wiki as forum is that it is mainly a tool for collaborative writing, so it allows several users to write on the same pages. This is also one of the problems you see e.g. on wikipedia, where several authors write on each page, and thus creates a kind of discussion that can be very unstructured, commenting in between each other etc. Forums do not allow other users to change what another user has written. So for a wiki to be successful as forum tool, there has to be some guidelines easy enough for all to understand, and some moderators to ensure compliance. If you create separate wikis - this might make it easier for the users to handle different issues - you should add links on the pages between the wikis so it is easy to navigate between them. But it is important to design the forums/wikis with the users, to see how it best suits them Forums in moodle can be used the same way as forums in phpBB, depends on the settings. It looks like your forum is restricted who can reply - but this is not your fault, the standard news forum is normally for one way communication. Moodle forums have two settings that control who is allowed to post and reply, check them out. And one great thing with Moodle forums is that your users can subscribe to them to receive postings with email or via RSS feeds. So forum or wiki? I think it depends on how much effort you want to use to structure the communication. The forum tool is more focused, the wiki is more open. But to me it sounds like you would be best helped with the forum. /Ian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs forum
ResponsesInList.Text: Ian: Thanks for your comments,I played with the forum idea some more and I think I have come to the conclusion that what I really need for this function is PHPBB. I found that I could like to my existing PHPBB site using the "add resources". I need the different levels of category and topics that php gives me and linking doesn't create that much of an issue with my users. I will continue to play with this package though since I need to create employee evaluation tests with it. Thanks Again Rick

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki vs forum
ResponsesInList.Text: You could add the glosary module to the list of possibilities. In brief, Forum : everibody could post. Anibody could edit THEIR posts but only during the next 30'. Nobody could edit the post of others (they could add new post as reply). Glosary : everibody could post. Anibody could edit THEIR posts allways. Nobody could edit the post of others (they could add commnets or new entries) Wiki : everybody and everytime could post and edit what they or others write.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Separate Group Wikis
ResponsesInList.Text: The short answer is that yes, you can, but it's rather like setting up a separate groups forum. Everyone in the course will be able to see the wiki activity link, and you have to set up each group's initial wiki page. (see attached) I would direct you to a moodledoc that I posted, but it seems to have dropped out of docs, presumably because it is now fairly out of date with the incoming complications of new roles and new wiki developments in 1.7?? In any case, hope this picture helps a little bit. The short explanation: I used Moodle's overall groups setting to separate my course sections , but I then also wanted to set up group wikis within my sections. This picture shows how I did it. I teach five sections and used the basic format of this page to create the main page template for each section. Then I had each small group edit their specific pages. Again, it's a little complicated, so let me know if it doesn't make sense from the picture. P.S. Re: my "friendly warning"--I teach fifteen-year-olds; I know it sounds a bit harsh, but you really have to have different structures/expectations in place at that age, so feel free to ignore that part of the picture.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Separate Group Wikis
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Here is how Tom Clauset - Friday, August 5 2005, 04:27 PM explained it. It worked for me this spring but it might be out of date now. "Solved the problem. The solution is NOT what you would think. It turns out that you only need to create 1 Wiki from the front page of your course. The other wiki(s) are "clones" of the first one assigned to each of the groups you have set up. Here is a graphic that I captured from setting up the first wiki. Over on the right hand side is a drop down window called "Other Wikis:" When you click on the down arrow, you will see all of the "groups" that you have made and can go in individually and setup the "clone" wikis. When a student logs in to the "Wiki" they are taken directly to the group wiki they have been assigned to. Their wiki has the edit tabs available. When they use the same drop down menu, they can "look" at the other wikis, but there are no edit tabs that let them 'tinker' with another group's script. Now that is very cool! Here are the basic steps that I followed: 1. Set up your "course." Hope this helps, Tom Clauset" I'd like to know if anything is different now. Cheers, Glenys

ResponsesInList.Title: DFwiki: bug with special characters in page names
ResponsesInList.Text: We are currently using dfwiki 2006030101, and remarked a bug in the pagename handling: if users puts special characters such as ' or " in their pagenames, these get prefixed by \ in the URL , but this prefix is not stripped inside the code, so it gets appended over and over. For instance, if you create a page L'essai the viewing URL will be like : view.php?id=5170&page=view/L\\'essai and fail. The best solution in my opinion would be to clean the pagenames, by replacing all non alphanumeric or space characters by _.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DFwiki: bug with special characters in page names
ResponsesInList.Text:
Here is a proposed patch for the problem of special characters in pagenames: * inÂ  dfwikilib.php, function get_real_pagename, normalize linknames by stripping invalid characters : 
```text
        ...


        $id = ($id)? $id : $dfwiki->id;
```
 \w should match alphanumeric characters, and thus correctly handle accented characters if the locale is correctly set on the server . However, if the locale is not correct, it will also replace accented characters by _ * in wiki/sintax.php:Â  call get_real_pagename inÂ  dfwiki_sintax_create_internal_link : 
```text
... case 'internal': ...


                        // Normalize pagename


                        $linkpage = dfwiki_get_real_pagename($linkpage);
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DFwiki: bug with special characters in page names

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I upload an exel file?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I would like our students to access an excel document from the main
page of our course. I have not been able to make accessible from moodle. How can I upload it so it shows in the course window so that students can edit it? Thank you for any advice. Sarah

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I upload an exel file?
ResponsesInList.Text: Sarah, This is straightforward and you don't need to create a wiki if you're looking for students to access the file as is from the course outline. To do this you should 'display a directory'. Here's how: Go to the Files area of your course (in Administration block) Create a new directory. It doesn't matter what it's called, but you might want to call it 'excel documents' click on it to enter the directory. Now you want to browse and upload the Excel document that you want to make available. Having done this, return to the main course outline and make sure that Editing is switched on. Find the weekly or topic block that you want to present the file in and choose Add a resource -> Display a directory Give the resource a name, perhaps, 'Excel files' and in the summary say what kind of spreadsheets are going here. Pull down Display a directory and choose the 'Excel documents' directory. Click Save changes. Now the contents of this directory will be displayed to your students when they click the resource link.

ResponsesInList.Title: Fixing nwiki "continue" bug
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark, working with Pigui we have found out that the "continue" bug happens when you install nwiki and dfwiki is already installed. This happens because some tables are the same in dfwiki and nwiki and so the database creation script fails. Pigui is working in this script to fix it. meanwhile you can install nwiki by backing up (or exporting) dfwiki wikis, and erasing dfwiki directory andÂ  dfwiki tables (with php my admin ) and then installing nwiki. You can also wait two days or so til we fix it. Regards Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fixing nwiki "continue" bug
ResponsesInList.Text: And yet it doesn't really make sense. The tables were all named differently, weren't they? How could there be confusion? Unless it's related to some of the blocks. ResponsesInList.Title: NWiki installs and works if I don't have DFWiki installed
ResponsesInList.Text: Just tried an experiment in my test installation. Uninstalled DFWiki and NWiki. Installed NWiki. Still no continue button on wiki mod, but no blank files, either. Inserted a Wiki in a course. Edited a page. Edited a discussion. Everything worked. Conclusion. There's some sort of conflict between NWiki and DFWiki, in my installations, anyway. Problem. I have to convert some important work in DFWiki to NWiki, but to install NWiki properly, I seem to need to uninstall DFWiki. Can I convert under these circumstances?

ResponsesInList.Title: Second Success
ResponsesInList.Text: Tried the same trick with a copy of my production installation (and a copy of the production database ). Deleted DFWiki. Deleted NWiki tables. Visited Admin. Even got a continue button! I have reinstalled DFWiki, too. The order matters. NWiki first, DFWiki second. The problem with that is, when you delete DFWiki, you lose all instances of the module. It then becomes impossible (as far as I can tell so far) to convert any DFWikis, even if you reinsert the tables for DFWiki. Heck, I even tried copying all the DFWiki records into NWiki tables. The copying worked, but without an instance in a course, they're no use. I'm going to try fooling with mdl_course and mdl_course_section. I'll delete them in the copy installation and import or copy them from the production installation. I'm not convinced it will work, but it's worth a quick try. Can't hurt. Maybe I'll just rename, add a "1" to the name of each table. That way I can always backtrack.

ResponsesInList.Title: Failure
ResponsesInList.Text: Doesn't work. Must be other tables needed. Can't thing what they are.

ResponsesInList.Title: How about a name change: NWiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Frankly, I found the name "New Wiki" confusing, especially as most people seldom capitalize it. Another factor is that what's new today will be old tomorrow. So how about a name change? I suggest NWiki, which could be decapitalized to nwiki and still be understood as a single entity. It might also be a good idea to start appending version numbers, so that future searches will turn up relevant posts when people are interested in a specific version. So where are we now? Nwiki 1.1? 0.1? 0.1.2?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How about a name change: NWiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: I use the name "new" because the module name is "wiki"... it could also be named forthcoming wiki ... version numbers are provided by the standard moodle versioning system. All releases are kept on the dfwiki home site. The versioning is really critical since we will start the next week to make several critical changes to adapt it to 1.7 core and other security stuff. We can call it what you guys like it, but the module name is "wiki". I'm thinking about writing a wiki road-map/survival page in docs.moodle.org and ask Eloy or Martin to place a link in the forum header. Just hold on a little till we get out of this schism. Then we will focus on beating mediawiki!!!! Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Beating MediaWiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Beating MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: You mean the discussion linked to a wiki page? That is an excellent idea in my opinion.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Beating MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: That's what I mean. And thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Beating MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: mmm... you can allways create a link to a forum from a wikipage, or create together a forum and a wiki activities in the course and handle it from instructulional design... Versioning is crucial to make a wiki work... that's what is about. The in-wikidiscussion style we borrowed from mediawiki, that way way beyond is the most used and de-facto standard.Â  so we don't need even to tell users how it works. You guys use it directly! I want also to clone the mediawiki markup format... but first we need to become oficial...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Beating MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Yeah, but, in my experience,which is admittedly limited, discussions differ from pages. That said, though, I dunno. I used DFWiki for a proposal writing exercise. Versioning was great for that. The advantage of the discussion format over the forum format was that I could keep adding to my discussion and have it all on one page. Versioning wasn't so important for that (except when adding a discussion to the discussion page took out half the page of text. I could save the damaged version, revert, copy the missing text, return to the present, so to speak, and paste the missing text back in. Of course, it would have been nicer not to need to do that.) A built-in option would be nice. I like forums. The main thing I'm looking forward to in Elgg 0.7 is threaded discussion under blog entries.

ResponsesInList.Title: DFwiki roadmap
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, just talked with Martin about the future of dfwiki in moodle. As we already know the new wiki still needs some testing and adustments ( and moodle coding rules compilance). Due to the inminent release of 1.7 new wiki will not be ready. However Martin agrees to include it for the 1.8 release planned for december. In order to meet all requirements, we (dfwikiteam) will focus only in bug fixing and code tunning. I want to thank all of you that use and test and suffer dfwiki and new wiki issues. All bugs reported and commentaries are key for our success. Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DFwiki roadmap

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DFwiki roadmap
ResponsesInList.Text: Some of us are already using it in 1.6 and if you skip later versions that will prevent us from upgrading to 1.7. Keep the releases please. It may not be 10D% Moodly but it still is great. And as for 1.8 being released in December, I have a strong suspicion that we won't be seeing 1.7 until December, let alone 1.8. I figured out long ago Moodle release dates are wished for dates that have little connection with actual release date. The roles changes I think are actually very big changes and unless they get proper testing rushing out a 1.7 release at the end of September could result in serious security compromises in my opinion.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: DFwiki roadmap
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Nicole, what I mean is that we will not develop new features untill Martin makes us oficial once an for all. But we will fix bugs and issues for all versions : dfwiki for 1.5 new wiki for 1.6 and eventually a new wiki for 1.7. I'm afraid it will be necessary to have a 1.7 version because of the new roles and the new database librarys.

ResponsesInList.Title: Beyond Wikis and Blogs
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been doing some reading and thinking. I do this sometimes. I was reading W. Olaf Stapledon (Last and First Men - 1930) and came across the following: "`telepathic' intercourse had resulted in a true group-mind, a single physical process embodied in the electro-magnetic radiation of the whole race; but the group-mind was inferior in calibre to the individual minds." p. 240. Whilst Stapledon ascribed his original 'group-mind' to his Martians, in this instance he was referring to his Fifth Men (on earth). For instance, MS word has an 'autosummarise' function that extracts meaning from a large document. Does similar search technology exist to extract themes, common perspectives and counterpoints from Blog sites or online forums? Maybe you could dicuss some of this with your students? I would also be interested in pesonal viewpoints.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Beyond Wikis and Blogs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Terry, you talk about truth and I consider it a rather hard word, we could discuss long enough if there is such thing . Personal truths may exist but they may ( should ) change as we learn through life. I consider that wikis and blogs (and forums, cause we could consider a blog as a special class of forum) accomplish different tasks, as you expose. Wiki is a tool to create large hypertext collaborative documents where different minds try to create and consensuate a text while understand each others and create new knowledge while they do it ( doing something called social constructionism ). BlogÂ  is aÂ  way of self expression, through comments, permalikns, rss and search engines the blogosphere allows the revision the knowledge created (but within the blogosphere not in the blog itself). We should not forget about the tools that wikis offer us toÂ  review the processÂ  ( page history,Â  examination ofÂ  navigation, vote for pages,Â  evaluations,Â  and discussion pages ) those tell much about what's going on also. The use of autoresumees tools and so on can be useful, but I believe that for learning is best to read and follow the links and create the knowledge in our mind. That's my truth, but I've happened to disagree with myself often Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Blogs or Wikis?
ResponsesInList.Text: Help me sort this through. I am a history teacher.Â  My students have a year-long research paper project. I want the process of researching, thinking, and writing to be a collaborative one between teacher and student.Â  I want to be able to easily monitor their progress at all stages of the process. I want them to do three things on moodle: 1)Â  Brainstorm ideas & questions, and new thoughts 2)Â  Maintain an annotated bibliography as they discover new resources 3)Â  Post rough drafts of paper as they work through it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs or Wikis?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, David.Â  I think that wikis would be better as the "history" feature would be invaluable in keeping track of work done while keeping it tidy so that fewer drafts show up on the main page for each topic.Â  I believe that the way I set up my student portfolios in wikis could be adapted by you for this research project purpose.Â  (See attached slides.) In short--have THEM set up the pages as you deem appropriate by giving them specific instructions for where you want the information kept. ie: CamelCase pg 1 = BrainstormingandPrewriting CamelCase pg 2 = AnnotatedBibliography CamelCase pg 3 = RoughDrafts (As in the slide picture, I suggest that you set "allow binary files" to "yes" so that they can choose to upload drafts or to copy them in as they choose.) Two caveats: 1) I teach ninth grade and could do CamelCase, but opt not to.Â  You could adapt your instructions to show them CamelCase versus my square bracket preference. 2) To keep research wikis private to only you and the student entering the information, follow this last step: If you use groups, you have to make sure that not only do you choose "student" for the type of wiki when you are setting it up, you also need to make sure the group icon for this activity is set to "no groups." Hope this helps! Lesli

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs or Wikis?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a bunch, Lesli! I read your very thoughtful and helpful reply and decided to follow your advice.Â  I prepared some instructions for the students that they can copy/paste on their own wikis. We'll see how clear I have been and how attentive they will be! Perhaps you can give it a spin and see if what I have said makes sense? Currently, my moodle site is open for Guest Access: http://online.laurelschool.org/course/view.php?id=30 I've been working like the very Devil this summer after the Byfield MoodleMoot to get it off the ground.Â  Fortunately, I have had several years experience with Dreamweaver and earlier incarnations of a web site for AP US History to fall back on. I also teach at an independent girl's school--Laurel in Shaker Heights OH.Â  So, I believe our kids are similar in outlook. I'm looking forward to using moodle to facilitate this process.Â  I do a lot of work on writing historical essays with my students, as you can see from some of the other pages.Â  Moodle seems an ideal fit for this. Thanks again for your generous help. Best David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs or Wikis?
ResponsesInList.Text: Lesli: Hi again I'm playing around with my wiki and I have encountered an important confusion: You say: (As in the slide picture, I suggest that you set "allow binary files" to "yes" so that they can choose to upload drafts or to copy them in as they choose.) But I can't seem to upload a .doc attachment.Â  Moodle keeps telling me this is an unacceptable format.Â  Is this a bug?Â  Or am I missing something? In my Moodle manual they seem to suggest attachments are only for graphic files, but I assume you are having kids upload text files, too? Thanks David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Blogs or Wikis?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi again, David.Â  Just peeked at your school site wiki.Â 
Looks good!Â  I think the directions for the wiki are perfectly
clear.Â  I think I remember, perhaps, meeting you at
Byfield??Â  Before I came to my current day school, I taught in a
boarding/day program in Michigan and lived as a dorm advisor in the
girls' dorms.Â  Quite the experience! Regarding wiki attachments: You're right--this is a feature that has
perplexed me as well, but I guess I always assumed it had something to
do with what I was trying to attach and that I use Macs--that it wasn't
a bug.Â  Hadn't taken the time to explore why as there was the
following, seeming, workaround: Instead of trying to attach a doc in edit mode (which may work for
people using PCs not Macs, again I don't know as I haven't tried it
from a PC), click on the "attachments" tab in the tab menu (see
picture).Â  After the doc has been uploaded, there will be a link
message at the bottom stating, "This page has attachments."Â 
Clicking on that link should take you to the appropriate
attachment.Â  Not exactly intuitive, I know. Regarding doc type, I have mostly had kids uploading docs for research, etc., so I do know that it is possible. As an aside, this shot is of one of my research wikis.Â  As someone
else pointed out, you can also set the wiki to "separate groups" so
that all students in the group can share their research if they want
to--but only the student can edit his/her page.Â  That is how I had
this wiki set up.Â  Again, though, if you want only you and the
student to have access, it needs to be set up as "student" in the wiki
setup page, and as "no groups" icon in edit mode from the main course
page. Hope this helps! Lesli

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NEW (DF)WIKI -REALEASE FOR 1.6
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to go to your modules administration page first, uninstall the existing wiki from there, delete the existing wiki folder from your mod folder and upload the new one (if you didn't do it in the first place, otherwise you can skip this step), and THEN visit the admin page again. The new wiki tables will not set up properly if you don't uninstall the old version first. I forgot myself and had the same problem as you originally but now it is working ok. But also, are you sure you got the correct package? With 1.6 you should be using new wiki, not dfwiki. What I installed this morning was called wiki, not dfwiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NEW (DF)WIKI -REALEASE FOR 1.6
ResponsesInList.Text: Before installing this new wiki, uninstall the wiki that is there first. Go to your admin config->modules page and click to delete the wiki that is there. This is a separate step from removing the wiki folder from the mod folder. You need also to delete the existing wiki tables (I am assuming your wiki has no content previously), which is what "delete" on the config modules page does. This must be done first or the new wiki won't configure the database correctly even if you install the wiki files in the right places.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NEW (DF)WIKI -REALEASE FOR 1.6
ResponsesInList.Text: You don't delete the database. You go to your admin page, and then to the module configuration page, and click on "delete" next to the wiki module. The goal is not to delete the data in the database only, but to delete the tables themselves.

ResponsesInList.Text: No, my point was that, after deleting tables with the configuration tool and still having problems, using a big hammer like database deletion didn't change the situation. Anyhow, trying to give the offending command inside postgreSQL shows that new wiki is using data types (tinyint(1), mediumtext) not recognized by postgreSQL 8.1.4 that comes with FC5. Although this is different problem than the one described above, it ends up having error messages later that could be confused with the situation where one has old database tables interfering with the installation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NEW (DF)WIKI -REALEASE FOR 1.6
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo-I've been playing with the wiki, mostly with the blocks at this point. I haven't found any critical bugs yet, but some small things, particularly with Moodle consistency and overall appearance/ usability . Here's a summary: Language: There are a lot of language strings missing from en_utf8. Since you developed this in Catalan, I would assume the strings exist there but for people to translate this into other languages, it is crucial you get the strings into en_utf8. Also, grammar and spelling in English could use a lot of improvement. I'd try my hand at it myself but I think the best would be if you could find someone who is fluent in Catalan and English who could make sure that the English translations reflect the original Catalan. Wiki Syntax: I love the fact that the HTML editor can be used in the wiki. This reduces the need for students to know wiki syntax. It would be nice though if there were a help item that would explain what wiki tags are necessary to use in the wiki. I found to make links I needed to use [[]], but I wonder if there is anything else or if the editor itself can do the rest. Editor Choice: It would be helpful if in addition to allowing the teacher to set the default editor method, there was an option to make that the only option available to students. I don't want them using anything but the HTML editor but the only way I can do that now is to hack out the choice. Vote: I see this button that says vote on it appearing on every page that does nothing and I have no clue why it is there. Index Block: This is the first block I installed on my site. I was not at all happy with the appearance of the menu items with the 20 character truncation. I upped the truncation to a number that wouldn't produce any ... for the pages I want to include in it. But that made the Index Block too wide. Therefore, I removed the "nowrap" and it looks much better. My suggestion: Make the character truncation a configurable number and get rid of the nowrap. Last Updates (better to call it "Latest Updates" in English): First of all, to be consistent with the Latest Activity Block in Moodle, you might want to list the items from oldest to newest. I didn't like the numbers next to the items, so I removed them, and to distinguish the items from one another instead, I added two breaks between them. I also did the same with the truncation and the nowrap as in the index block. The image at 20 pixels is inconsistent with the tiny pics used for example in the online users block so I changed the size to 16 pixels. I changed the false to true so that the student's name is shown alongside their image since I think that is important. In fact, I would rather remove the image altogether but that isn't an option the way the function is written. The date format wasn't precise enough either. We would all hope our students would be adding more frequently to the wiki so I changed the date format to something more suitable. In reality, it would be best of all I think if the format of the entries in this block matched those in the Latest Activity block. In any case, here's the changed code if you want to see what I have done: '.$this->trim_string($page,50).'  '.strftime('%d %b, %I:%M %p',$pageinfo->lastmodified).' by '.wiki_get_user_info($pageinfo->author,16,true).'

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NEW (DF)WIKI -REALEASE FOR 1.6
ResponsesInList.Text: Good Morning! I've been reading all the posts and Id' like to sort things a litle. This version of New Wiki incorporates (as I said ) LOTSÂ  of new fetures that has not been deeply tested. that's why is not the standard wiki yet ( in we had a lockd version, no new fetures, to be candidade to standard but when martin locked 1.6 I decided to move on and include the new stuff we are developing). The developers are a team of STUDENTS with great skill but they are still gaining experience ( right now the initial developers david and ferran are hired by ouruniversity customizing the moodle production site http://atenea.upc.edu ). We have deeply tested this version on our servers, but there are so many scenarios (previous versions installed, database server, moodle version, old wikis to import, and lots of moodle 1.6 core issues that change from day to day and makes it crack ) For me the most important is NOT TO LOOSE THE DATA,Â  so please all of you who atempt to install new versions of new wiki and dfwiki make backups or exports of your wikis. We are rigth now working in the backups / restore engines of both versions. Due a some librarys in 1.6 current dfwiki backup/export does not work in 1.6, we are working on it. Those who have backups that you're not able to import please send the zip.files to me ( If the content can be seen of course) and we'll use it as a test case. Quality comes from testing and hard work. If installation of this version causes inconvinicence. We thank you for all the feedback and suport. Ludo out

ResponsesInList.Title: Future wiki options
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I presently trying to convince a bunch of Computer Scientists at the University of Manchester (UK) that they really did make the right choice in going with Moodle and not WebCT.Â  Pleasing them is a hard task. One thing that has just cropped up is a request that a course wiki can be pre-loaded with some sort of template that the students can select, for example, and template that inserts standard questions such as: What? Why? How? Benefits? Disadvantages?... I'm not particular familiar with media wiki, however I did notice that it offered some sort of template option and from speaking to colleagues it sounds as if this feature is exactly what is needed.Â  Does anybody know if the future of the moodle wiki(s) might include such an option.Â  Will dfwiki offer what I describe above?Â  I've heard dfwikie touted as eventually being "mediawiki and more...", but I'm not convinced yet(!).Â  What's the current word on the street about moodle and mediawiki full integration?Â  Is it envisaged that it can be integrated, and allow a per course/instance wiki? Thanks in advance for any news you can offer. Regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Future wiki options
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not a Mediawiki expert by any means, but I'm not convinced that even Mediawiki does this in exactly the way you describe. It does have templates but they are generally used for inserting a block of static text into multiple pages. And when the ability to insert custom page specific into templates is used it's primarily for tables of data rather than free flowing text. Have a look at the editing source of this Wikipedia page and see how the infobox on the right and the succession boxes at the bottom are done. It works but it's geeky and tricky to edit if the text grows beyond a few words or phrases. If it was me I'd just add an intial wiki page with the template text (and probably some task instructions too) and then ask the students to view the wiki code and cut and paste it into a new page before they begin. It's hardly an onerous task, works on every wiki ever made and so teaches them exciting and transferrable information technology skills.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Future wiki options
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi stuart, let's go by parts: - mediawiki cant just be fully integrated into moodle as an activity because each wiki needs a database to be setted up. mediwiki is ment for huge wikis so is like dealing with truck... dfwiki however is meant to be a minivan. If you catch the analogy. This winter we have been working in the development of the alternative wiki for moodle and this has more to do with INTEGRATING WITH MOODLE than wiki features. Rigth now we have already started to work in new partsers to suport the wiki features of mediawiki... meaning - wiki sysntax - mediawiki import / export - templates - section edit and so on This is all comming but we have firts to hit the HEAD branch on the CVS as wiki One of the current features that is working now is the possibility of having a WIKI course, meaning you can place a wiki page in the focuss of your course. Hope it helped and I strongly suggest you forget about webct and stay with us at moodle. Ludo out

ResponsesInList.Title: Excuse my ignorance but what is a Wiki and how to create them?
ResponsesInList.Text: I was wondering what is a Wiki and how do I creat one. Where can I see good examples of useful wikis?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Excuse my ignorance but what is a Wiki and how to create them?
ResponsesInList.Text: http://www.wikipedia.org - most famous example

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Excuse my ignorance but what is a Wiki and how to create them?
ResponsesInList.Text: A wiki is a virtual workspace (usually a web page) that allows easy collaboration, additions and editing of documents. A descriptions of Wikis as located here on one of the the most popular wikis of all time: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki I am just getting ready to post an assignment (in my Moodle classroom)for the students in my Human Anatomy and Physiology course to create a wiki on the anatomy, physiology and pathophysiology of the skeletal and muscular systems. The project will be a group project but I will still be able to assess individual performance because the wiki application keeps track of all versions of the document and who made each revision. If you want to learn more about wikis, I recommend going to Wikipedia (an online encyclopedia that is in wiki format) and looking up a topic that you have significant expertise - if you see an error or a place to make an addition, just click the edit button and edit away! After doing that a few times you will become familiar with wikis -- they have their own formatting that is lest complicated that html. The wiki in Moodle is even easier to use because it includes a formatting toolbar so learning formatting tags is optional. To create a wiki in Moodle just add it as you would any other activity. If you are not familiar with how to add activities to Moodle classrooms, either find a practice Moodle classroom to play with (the best option) or ask someone.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Excuse my ignorance but what is a Wiki and how to create them?
ResponsesInList.Text: You have both been really helpful. Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki image upload browsing
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carl, I have attached a set of notes I prepared for our students/pupils to use. This appears to work. In addition to the info. in the notes: 1) You must allow binary files 2) All images being uploaded into the same course should have different file names even if they are going into different wikis The information above and the information in the notes has been derived through trial and error. I hope you find it useful. You might also find the following useful: If you run Windows XP there is a useful 'powertoy' you can download which makes it easy to shrink .jpg files. Download here: http://download.microsoft.com/download/whistler/Install/2/WXP/EN-US/ImageResizerPowertoySetup.exe Run the setup program. Now open a .jpg image. Right click on it and choose 'resize pictures' from the menu. Select the size you require.... A custom size you might want to use is 480x360 The file is saved in the original folder as "filename(custom)" Regards, Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BUGS FIXED! rectification
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I've seen that you don't like "new diff" so much, don't worry is still in development. We only wanted to show to everybody. We thought that teachers are not programmers, we are used to the traditional two columns differences, but they not. We are developing grades in DFWiki, so we want new and more intuitive way to show teachers the contribution of every student in every wiki page. We thought that green highlighting of new words and red highlighting of deleted ones was most usefull for fast evaluation. Our objective is to use two column diff for admin. and new diff for grading. Thanks, DFWikiteam, Jordi.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BUGS FIXED! rectification
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Allow me to intervene here. The issue is not so much whether there are two columns or not. I personally like the two column view for the diff. What some of my colleagues had problems with in dfwiki (after having used the old wiki before) was the code view. If there are a lot of HTML tags, things can become a bit messy and comparing different versions of a wiki might become difficult. So I, for one, encourage you to continue developing the new diff view. If you are able to combine the two column view with WYSISYG that's good, too. I think it is a very good idea to maintain the two alternative viewing modes, though. People can choose what suits them best. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Change wiki from separate group to whole class
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear all, We started a wiki where the four existing groups (all of the same course) could edit and the other groups respectively could read it. Now I would like to merge the four group wikis into one so everybody can edit everything in the wiki. Is that possible? Regards, Carsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change wiki from separate group to whole class
ResponsesInList.Text: Carsten, As long as you started out with "groups" as your designated wiki type in the set-up phase, and it sounds as if you did, you should be able to change it to "edit all" simply by changing the groups icon next to the wiki on your main course page.Â  To recap, turn editing on, scroll down to the wiki, click the "visible groups" people icon until it reads "no groups."Â  (This fix would not be possible if you had chosen "student" or "teacher" as your initial type in the set up page.) Hope this info helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change wiki from separate group to whole class
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lesli, Thank you very much. Yes, you are right, I started out with groups and I did asÂ  you stated above. The wiki now works for everybody in editing mode. However, nobody can see the pages they already created while working in group mode. Is it posible to export/reimport the pages or do a similiar trick? Regards, Carsten

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change wiki from separate group to whole class
ResponsesInList.Text: Yikes, Carsten.Â  I didn't remember that side effect.Â  I just investigated in my own course with an old wiki.Â  You are right, the info doesn't transfer between settings.Â  Sorry that I didn't remember to warn you about that.Â  But, I assume you found, as I did, (at least I very much hope you did) that when you switch it back to visible groups,Â  the right info is still there. Unfortunately, I don't have a neat trick to transfer, but what I would have done with my wiki, had I needed to make it edit all, is this: In edit mode, during a time when my students are least likely to be on (usually during the day while I'm on prep), I would go back and forth between the two types and copy each group's page into the new "edit all" version.Â  It's a little on the tedious side, but not too bad if the group pages weren't "deep," just long.Â  It gets a little more complicated if groups had internal pages in their pages, so I hope yours is as simple as mine was. In this case, my wiki was a class word bank of good words for poems.Â  I would then go into 2nd Hour's bank, copy it to my clipboard, go back to the main page, click the groups icon to "no groups" type in a new page [2nd Hour], save, click the question mark after 2nd Hour that would appear, and paste the old info into the new page.Â  Then I would click the groups icon back to visible groups, and I would repeat for 3rd Hour, 4th Hour, etc.Â  Although tedious, it wouldn't probably take more than ten to fifteen minutes for me to do all five of my classes.Â  Again, though, my classes only had one page per group.Â  If yours had multiple pages and went "deep" with their info, this could be a very tedious way to go, indeed. My solution is kind of low tech, but I don't know code, etc.Â  If your wiki is more complex, perhaps someone else out there knows a quicker fix? Best, Lesli

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change wiki from separate group to whole class
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Carsten, Be sure that your backup isn't empty. I have already make such a change. The result was a totaly empty wiki . So I restore my backup. But the backup facility for group-wiki doesn't work properly on my site. gr.

IMHO dfwiki is NOT ready for inclusion into main cvs, because there are still following problems: reliance on register globals, old xxx_variable() functions - all of them must be properly converted to new xxx_param() functions incorrect use of xxx_param() functions - please do read the function definitions and comments; please make sure that all dfwiki developers understand these two functions remove those global variables - use function parameters instead; this is IMO priority #1 use p() and s() functions in forms fix XHTML compliance please use only English in comments/code - do you want me to comment my code in Czech too? skodak

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Martin... Wiki UTF is ready
ResponsesInList.Text:
I've posted this elsewhere but since it isn't really clear where your developers are monitoring, I add it here just to make sure it isn't overlooked: username is used to identify the user in the database instead of
userid. This is also displayed to students and teachers instead of
user's fullname. This is a serious bug because it poses a security risk
to students by revealing their userid to all, and it is also a serious
issue because anyone can change their username at any time, unlike
userid. This problem exists in both Dfwiki and the new wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Martin... Wiki UTF is ready
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi there, Im pasting here a list of issues in wich we have been working these days... The basic list comes from a large document Eloi provided us and we kept from there. Ludo ps. bernardino todoli is makin a hell of a job - SOLVED: There is a
bug in the versions, so the upgrade from old wiki to new never happens. - There are a lot of tabs here and there.
They must be changed to 4 whitespaces each. Where? - There is no userid column in the wiki_pages table
(author char-string instead). Thats like in the original wiki - The blocks structure isn't build over core blocks
tables but over its own. Some records are harcoded in the blocks tables instead
of allowing standard block installation/upgrade. I would create a bunch of wiki_xxxx
standard blocks instead, only usable under the wiki pages, of course. Also,
their strings should be present in the propper files and some other details to
become standard blocks. - wiki_synonymous table name is correct? (although
it's possible that migation become painful, so we can change it in the
future...). Yes, its correct - wiki_synonymous table hasn't pageid, is it needed?
How does it work? Just by pagename? Yes, with only the original entry (pagename)
works fine - Are pagenames sticky? Cannot they be renamed (moved
in mediawiki language)? Yes, they
can be renamed. Thats at Administration Tools block in the update page xxx utility - The Wiki icon. I cannot see anything meaningful
there! (personal opinion, of course) It seems to become corrupt either after the migration process or CVS problem
with images - In the upgrade from wiki to dfwiki, as there aren't
userids, my wiki-pages were assigned to "guest". - SOLVED: When one page
with more than 1 version is retrived from DB, I get: Error: Turn
off debugging to hide this error. SELECT * FROM
mdl_wiki_pages WHERE pagename = 'One utf-8 page' AND dfwiki = '1' AND groupid =
'0' LIMIT 100 Found more
than one record in get_record_ sql ! It seems to be
related with the anonymous block executing one wrong get_record() call! - SOLVED: Exactly the
same error is showed with any of the 3 tabs (view, edit, history) - Some help files are mising (contributions...) Done. CVS updated - Some strings are mising (resultincontent...) Done. CVS updated - Search doesn't work for diacritics. And/or match is
performed with case matching (I think). - Search seems to work against titles and contents
always (no matter the checkbox was selected or no). Perhaps it's due to that
usage of globals? Ah! After a
second try I saw that such checkbox is to decide to show the details of the
search in the body of the page. Perhaps the title should be changed to be a bit
more clear? Something like "show results page" and some sort of nice
help... Ok - The text in some blocks (search, index from
current... doesn't wraps, so blocks get wider and wider). Done. A trim function is implemented already. - The useful "who links here" block isn't
available. - Adding a block always jump to module main page. It
should be retained. fixed - The wiki title in the breadcrumb should be linked to
the main page to be able to go there quickly. Done - Wiki backup and restore don't suppor individual activities ! - Wikies aren't included in the backup/restore at all! - PostgreSQL upgrade script isn't available! - UTF-8 migration always get user_main_language() and
it should get page author language! Its done the same way as in the Forum
migration - There is one bar with one big "dfwiki"
inside at the begining og each block. If it hasn't any use, it should go away. Fixed - In the wiki_pages table there is one
"dfwiki" field. Should be "wikiid". Such name doesn't sound
ok. (although it's possible that migation become painful, so we can change it
in the future...). - If the name of the page contains ' or " or \ it
gets slashes when previewing. Also, < and > seem to be stripped and links
are broken (because of quotes?). It works fine in my local version. More
details are needed to fix the problem. - Page names containing ' produce this SQL errors
because of un-slashed: You have an
error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near 's page' AND dfwiki = '1' LIMIT
100' at line 1 SELECT *
FROM mdl_wiki_synonymous WHERE syn = 'Helen's page' AND dfwiki = '1' LIMIT 100 You have an
error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL
server version for the right syntax to use near 's page' AND dfwiki=1 AND
groupid=0 LIMIT 100' at line 3 SELECT MAX(version) AS maxim FROM
mdl_wiki_pages WHERE pagename='Helen's page' AND dfwiki=1 AND groupid=0 LIMIT
100 You have an
error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL
server version for the right syntax to use near 's page' AND dfwiki = '1' AND
groupid = '0' LIMIT 1' at line 1 SELECT *
FROM mdl_wiki_pages WHERE pagename = 'Helen's page' AND dfwiki = '1' AND
groupid = '0' LIMIT 1 It works fine in my local version. More
details are needed to fix the problem. - dfwiki is inside a lot of places in code. It should
go out (although it's possible that migation become painful, so we can change
it in the future...). Ok - globals, globals, globals usage should be out. Just
request parameters filtered with xxxx_param() functions. Work in progress - Uses ob mb_xxxxx() functions. Fatal error: Call to
undefined function mb_internal_encoding() in
C:\cvs_moodle\moodle_head\mod\wiki\blocks\list_pages\block_list_pages.php on
line 145. Fixed. Text class used instead. - Uses of htmlentities() should use s() and or p()
instead. It isn't utf-8 safe! Only for display text! Done - Analyse uses of htmlspecialchars(). If they are used
to display text, consider swithing to s() and p() too. Done

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Martin... Wiki UTF is ready
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo, I've been working a bit this weekend against your wiki code (helping where I've been able to patch without adding risks) and here it's the list again, updated and with some of the points in the previous one deleted (although not fully tested). Perhaps we could maintain the numbering for further reference (or send this to MoodleDocs too): There is no userid column in the wiki_pages table (author char-string instead). Must be supported in migration too. There is no intro and introformat in the wiki table. In the upgrade from wiki to dfwiki, as there aren't userids, my wiki-pages were assigned to "guest". Once more, userid seems to be critical. Wikis having different wiki_entries (group or user ones) have no support in new wiki (only one simultaneous line of versions is available?) so we get a lot of duplicate version errors with data-lost of such pedagogical feature! Or am I losing anything? With only groupid and version in the UK of the table, old student wikis can fit in the new one. Once more, userid! Search doesn't work for diacritics. And/or match is performed with case matching (I think). Search seems to work against titles and contents always (no matter the checkbox was selected or no). Perhaps it's due to that usage of globals? Ah! After a second try I saw that such checkbox is to decide to show the details of the search in the body of the page. Perhaps the title should be changed to be a bit more clear? Something like "show results page" and some sort of nice help... The useful "who links here" block isn't available. Wiki backup and restore don't suppor individual activities! Wikies aren't included in the backup/restore at all! Blocks system. Would be difficult to migrate to core block system? UTF-8 migration always get teacher_main_language() and it should get page author language! If we know the author responsible of the version, we must look for his original encoding instead of using the teacher one! Similar to forum_posts (if I'm nor wrong). And we should know the user: userid again! In the wiki_pages table there is one "dfwiki" field. Should be "wikiid". Such name doesn't sound ok. (although it's possible that migation become painful, so we can change it in the future...). dfwiki is inside a lot of places in code. It should go out (although it's possible that migation become painful, so we can change it in the future...). globals, globals, globals usage should be out. Just request parameters filtered with xxxx_param() functions. Attachment storage (as I've seen in the old-new migration script) seems to be a bit special with a lot of "dfwikiXXXX" dirs generated. The old-new migration script seems to be twice, once under the wikimigrate dir (the used one) and under the mod directory (unused?). Under my perspective, the lack of userid is really a big problem, because it's basic for all the system to have such info coded (migration, backup, utf-8, other functionalities...). Also related it's the lack of support for student-based wikis (I assume that you support course (or common) and group based wikis without problems, although I haven't tested it). The big conceptual difference between the old wiki and your great wiki is that the old one supported different lines of versioning (for each group or for each student we have versions 1,2,3...) while your alternative seems to lack this. Hope this helps, ciao P.D.: At home I've some changes pending to be sent, affecting point (2) above and adding some changes to the migration script (without changing anything but the style of database calls and support for (2) ). Obviously the problems related above about the old-new migration will remain until we have userid and student-based wikis in your module P.D.: Another thing that is lately rounding over my head is HOW all these changes over your wiki module will affect your dfwiki module. Does dfwiki module continue its own development? Is there only one module?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Martin... Wiki UTF is ready
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim's right. Many students when they reach the real world will be hired to work on already existing pieces of software, not necessarily create new works. They will first need to get up to speed on what has already been done and the standards that exist for that software, and then put their creative skills to work within those parameters. To be fair, I wouldn't say it is a problem only with DFWiki. I find a lot of non-standard modules in Moodle lack conformity with standard ones from the outset and lack the basics of a proper module. Things like an option to hide the module from the beginning for example or add its use to the logs, are lacking in a lot of contributed modules. A lot of people focus on what new things they can create without first building the foundation that will make their module work like a standard Moodle module. It might be worthwhile to put together a list and even code for must-have features in every module. In fact, that might be a worthwhile assignment for some students itself. Have them study the existing standard Moodle code to identify the commonalities between all modules and extract the relevant code to create a module template.

ResponsesInList.Title: Preview problem in dfWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: This appears both Firefox and IE when I edit dfWiki with html editor: I click "preview" and get following error: " Fatal error : Only variables can be passed by reference in /opt/lampp/htdocs/akkuna/mod/dfwiki/dfwikilib.php on line 266 "

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Preview problem in dfWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: This problem might come from using PHP 5.0.5 or later.. Only variables can be passed to function calls, notÂ the output of function. In dfwikilib.php on line 266 there is: dfwiki_print_page_content (stripslashes($dfform['content'])); Changing it like this should fix the preview problem: $stripslashes = stripslashes($dfform['content']); dfwiki_print_page_content ($stripslashes);

ResponsesInList.Title: How do you use wikis for teaching?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, just for once lest not talk about wiki, dfwiki, mediawiki, bugs and code tunning For my research I'm wondering about how do we use wikis for teaching. To start I'm explaining how do I use wikis in my teaching software project management and another strange subject abut Information Society ethics and History of computing. I use wikis for everithing - content delivery - assigment inscription. students must gather in teams of 3-4 students, and choose a theme from a list , and choose when they want to make a presentation about it at class. All this is managed througth easyly within a wiki page. - the students write their papers in collaboration within the wiki, and the other students use it as studi material for exams - project managementÂ  simulation... students play a RPG developing together a ficticious project but with real meetings reports, planifications and so on... the game is thayed betwen the forum, the wiki and internalmail with copies active And how do you do it? Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki and Copyright
ResponsesInList.Text: If one has a closed course that contains a wiki, is it legally enforcable to restrict students from sharing the content of that wiki beyond the course if it is stated up front that copyright of the material remains with the organization offering the course, with the exception that individual students retain the copyright of the material they themselves compose personally in the wiki?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Copyright
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not a lawyer but... The organization can enforce the copyright of its material, but cannot automatically act on behalf of the other students to enforce the copyright of the material they have created, as they retain this. You create the wiki Student A adds some content Student B copies A's content to a public arena You have no IP redress against student B, but student A does , as you've said that student A retains the copyright of the material they composed, which they would have done anyhow, unless they'd agreed otherwise. You might however want to phrase the AUP in such a way that you can expel student B from the course. It might be worth using a creative commons licence for the wiki stuff, as it would be difficult to identify who has composed the material, and thus retains the copyright, if it goes through a process of iterative editing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki and Copyright
ResponsesInList.Text: I like the point that what a student writes belongs to them. My concern is not if a little bit of it slips out at the hands of the individual authors, it is the whole work that would be a problem. But since each individual owns their own copyright, they would have to work en masse to do that.

Thank you to all of those who have joined us in the wiki arena to make a deep migration test for the new wiki, the wiki arena now has been migrated to New -Wiki. Good news is that it worked and everything seems ok. Now I must ask you to plat with the wiki arena to hunt for some bugs

This is a short list of what's to come: * a-la mediawiki discussion pages * pdf printing and html/opendoc export along with wikibook * new improved diff features * complete grading * major/minor edit swich * page voting * new edit modes (specially for those who teach programming languages ) * better atached files management * edit mode speciall blocks And last but not least wikipodcasting : text2speech and podcast your wiki pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: The morning hangover after the party
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks so much for the work you guys are putting into this, it's much appreciated. It's come a long way in the past few months. But, please, before you move on with new features, can you concentrate on finishing the existing ones so we can use it in Moodle to replace the existing Wiki? In particular I noticed the following problems in the code base after a quick look on test.moodle.com after the party: use of local global variables in practically every function (eg global $CFG,$cm,$course,$dfwiki,$page,$id,$pagedata,$pagename,$pageaction,$dfperms,$wikieditable,$dfform,$editor,$groupmember,$modname;). Basically the only globals should be $CFG, the rest you should pass to the functions (it's part of good design). a lot of times data is read from the database and written straight back in without addslashes(), causing problems on data with 'apostrophes'.Â  I checked in some quick fixes for this but it needs to be looked at systematically. overuse of get_records_ sql () and execute_sql () everywhere which means you need to write SQL everywhere. Please use get_records (), update_records () etc instead, I think you can replace over 90% of your SQL calls and we will get shorter, safer, more portable code. lots of output like this: echo 'no s'han pogut actualitzar els hits'; which should firstly use strings from lang page and secondly, use notify (), notice () or error () functions as appropriate. dfwikilib.php should be locallib.php to fit in with mod conventions. Don't use ipatlas, use /iplookup/index.php?ip=xx&user=xx Try to use lib/weblib.php instead or hardcoded XHTML for menus, boxes, tables etc. If you do specify HTML, make sure it's XHTML-compliant. Don't use hardcoded styles and HTML style parameters, make CSS classes and put default styling in styles.php within mod/quiz and each block as necessary. When developing, make sure you have $CFG->debug turned on to catch more errors. Please take these as constructive tips. I think this module has a lot of promise. I like the simple user interface and I REALLY want to see it replace Moodle's current wiki module.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki Party thank you...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ludo! The plans you and your team have sound really great to the old wiki lover - and the new wiki does appeal with its simplicity and elegance, too. However, it seems to reproduce an old deficiency I also find in the current wiki module - insufficient support for mixing of alphabets, esepcially Cyrillic. Wikis in general seem to be upset by users writing page titles in other alphabets, and this one didn't recognize CamelCase at all when in Cyrillic. In the text's body I also mixed Cyrillic with other alphabets from my keyboard (German and English) and found that either the Cyrillic, or the rest of them do not display correctly, depending on which character set was chosen in the browser. I used Firefox 1.5.0.1 and the HTML editor mode in the wiki itself. As wikis are an excellent educational ressource (esepcially since they started having HTML editors incorporated in them and learning curve is even shallower for any MS Word user), it would be great to see them as truly international as the rest of the modules. Thanks a lot for addressing this and looking forward to see the (old or new) wiki fully at work Best regards, Kremena
