ResponsesInList.Title: Finally deletion of attachments
ResponsesInList.Text:
I got annoyed with the problem that you can't delete your attachments in Moodle, so I decided to code a piece for it. To make it work: Change line 356 of the file %installation dir%moodle\mod\wiki\ewiki\plugins\moodle\downloads.php into: $o .= ''.$info->icon.$info->title.''.$info->size. " wwwroot /mod/wiki/delete.php?file=" . $info->title . "&name=" . $meta["section"] . "&returnsite=" . ewiki_script("", "" ,"") . "\"> Delete file
". Then add the attachment, delete.php, to the directory \moodle\mod\wiki\. Now there's an option "Delete file" behind each file. Enjoy!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finally deletion of attachments
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, this script is very dangerous, you should not use it on any production site

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finally deletion of attachments
ResponsesInList.Text: Any suggestions on that topic? It has some potential I think.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finally deletion of attachments
ResponsesInList.Text: Didn't fix the security issues, but did fix a bug that caused the addition to fail when the Pagename isn't the same as the Wikiname and added some more verbose output. Well, I'm off adding some security. Is_teacher() is not really neccesary since pupils are allowed to add attachment with wiki's with the Binary flags enabled, so they must be able to delete them as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finally deletion of attachments
ResponsesInList.Text: I've fixed security issue 1 and 2, but I don't know how to patch up issue 3. Well, here's the new code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Finally deletion of attachments
ResponsesInList.Text:
Okay, this should be the final version. I fixed cross-site-scripting by tweaking the parameters. Now it should be safe to use. To make it work: Change line 356 of the file %installation dir%moodle\mod\wiki\ewiki\plugins\moodle\downloads.php into: $o .= ''.$info->icon.$info->title.''.$info->size. " wwwroot /mod/wiki/delete.php?file=" . $info->title . "&returnsite=" . ewiki_script("", "" ,"") . "\"> Delete file
". Then add the attachment, delete.php, to the directory \moodle\mod\wiki\.

IMO only teachers should be allowed to do so. skodak Edit: looking at the code again, the "LIKE '%$filename%'" seems a bit weird to me, you might delete too much... Edit2: Do you think that anybody would use such code from anonymous user?

ResponsesInList.Text: Well, they could use it, I just made it Could you elaborate on the security issues you pointed out, I seem to not completely understand you? 1. So require_login($courseid,false); is enough? 2. this I don't understand 3. I can change that... *ponders I do think that students should be allowed to delete the attachments, because when you enable binaries to be uploaded to the wiki's, they can upload attachments too. Well, difference in opinion. Maybe you want to change it. When is this option going to be standard with the Wiki Module, it seems very handy to me, since you currently can't delete the attachments you have created without diving into the database and removing the entries AFTER you have deleted the local file.

ResponsesInList.Title: Problems with formatting in dfwiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, some students called my attention about a problem (and big frustration) they are experiencing when trying to edit a wiki (I'm using dfwiki). Before presenting the problem, let me say that it seems clear to me (although perhaps I'm wrong) that the source of the problem is not the dfwiki module itself but rather the HTML editor. However, I would like to say that in order to make the dfwiki module a really successful module, a solid, full featured and friendly HTML editor should be included in it. The dfwiki editor is very good but certain kinds of users will never go for it. The current HTML editor in Moodle is also very good to do little things like posting a message in a forum with a little extra formatting but shows its limitations when it is used in more involved tasks with longish documents and more complex formatting. If dfwiki is going to be used extensively for collaborative work with complex documents, I think we should perhaps start thinking about doing something to improve the default HTML editor. I don't want to complicate the lifes of Ludo and the members of his team because I know they are working very hard. But there are enough problems being reported with the current HTML editor to grant some attention is devoted to this issue. OK, having said this, here's the problem. In the edit screen you see the following: -------------------- But after saving the document, you see the following: So, is this a problem with the HTML editor or is it a problem with the integration of the HTML editor in dfwiki? At any rate, could anybody help me solve the problem? These students are telling me they don't want to work with wikis anymore because it is too frustrating and I don't want to have to do that. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: df wiki and groups
ResponsesInList.Text: I know this topic has been initiated in other threads but believe the implementation of groups within df wiki needs be addressed in a thread by itself. 1. It appeared from our testing that setting up a wiki to have separate groups kept everyone except group members out of the wiki (including the teacher). In other moodle assignments an instructor is not limited by enabling grouping - which is why you do not put a teacher in a group! 2. Visible groups enabled all others to see other groups' wikis, but also appeared to give them editing priviledges in another groups' wiki. What are the plans for updating dfwiki group features to enable a teacher to be able to view and edit all wikis and to keep the visible group features supported so that if visible groups are used, students can view (but not edit) another group's wiki. We like the group features that were supported in efurt wiki in moodle and would like to see the same type of support (including individual student wikis as has been mentioned in other forum posts). Again - I love dfwiki but the support of groups at this point does not seem to be fully implemented yet - do you have a timeline on any of this - or is there a new version that has been released that addresses some of these issues? We are using dfwiki in our courses now and can not just upload a new version each time it comes out without testing first ....

ResponsesInList.Title: Little request for new wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: When Ludo's team finishes with the most prioritary work (I stress this is so that Ludo doesn't get pissed off again ), I have another request to make (besides making a more WYSIWYG diff mode for the new wiki, at least similar to the one in the "old" wiki). I am now using dfwiki in our production site (it works wonderfully so far) and I find that I would like to do the following. When I create a wiki in group mode (one wiki for each separate group), I would like to have some prepared content before the students start to work so that the students can work on it and improve it. This is possible when you are not in group mode but if you activate the group mode, whenever the members of different groups start editing the wiki, they see a blank page. This was like this in the old wiki, but I wonder whether it would be possible to allow the teacher to create a wiki with some prepared material and have it be visible for all the groups. Now the way to do it is to access the course as a student of each one of the different groups and introduce the content in the wiki. If you have many groups, needless to say, it is a pain in the butt. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki login misbehaving
ResponsesInList.Text: I am experiencing problems when users attempt to login to edit a wiki page.Â  The scenario is as follows: Users visit the wiki page with guest login access. The page instructs them to use login link in footer to edit page. They login and are returned to the page, but login status is still set to guest and the wiki page doesn't display edit tab. They navigate to otherÂ pages of the wiki or anywhere on the site and login status shows that they are logged in. They navigate to the page they want to edit through the wiki site map and login status shows they are logged in. This doesn't occur on the usersÂ first visit to the page but on all subsequent visits to the site. Refresh (F5) of the page does not change login status In addition, the opposite effect occurs if the user logs out and revisits the page without closing the browser: User visits the page logged in Logs out Navigates to the page with guest login access When the page is displayed, user login status is logged in to their account User had edit tabs for the page Navigating to the page through the wiki sitemap results in guest login status & no edit tabs A sample wiki page that is having this problem is http://www.wels.net/university/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=469 or http://www.wels.net/university/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=469&page=group (link from sitemap) I have observed this behavior using both IE & Firefox browsers. I have searched the forums and not found mention of this behavior elsewhere, so please post links if it has been addressed already. Thanks! Sallie Draper

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dfwiki: list of features?

We'll the list of features of dfwiki (not complete) would be: * multiple language wiki ( I've seen this only in old moodle ) ewiki/dfwiki(wikipedialike)/wysiwyget * easy configurable blocks - index/page tree - page tree/from current - user contribution pages ( a kind of rss block to track the pages where the user posted ) - built in search engine ( within page names and content ) - new page block - page synonimous - user permisions at page level - page wishlist ( list of pages referenced but not created yet) - orphaned pages ( very important to keep a coherent wiki net) * Atachments and images * Integration with moodle, of course * backup and restore integrated with moodle * import / export (with the hability to "merge" wikis ) * export to a static website * works fine with non latin charsets * and the new module wikibook wich I'll explain in detail in the future whe'n I've got time ... Do I forget something?? Ludo ps list of main missing items that will come soon...before summer time * wikipedia files import * discussion pages / page comments insertion * grades ( see last tim takemoto post) * templates * ampliation of markup to meet mediawiki standard * export to PDF - open office - rtf throught wikibook * export to lesson (see messages with bernard in gen dev forum) and petr's book module *... suggestions are wellcome

ResponsesInList.Title: Template for wikis
ResponsesInList.Text: I wish to create student learning plans and have now set up a wiki in student mode so that each has their own personal wiki. Is there a means of stting up a template so that each one independently has a set of blank pages with common headings...any help gratefully received.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Template for wikis
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Wendy, Good news! If you create a text file and upload it to the course files area this can be used to seed your Wiki's initial page by using the " Choose an Initial Page" setting. Tips: The name of the file you use file you create will create the name of the initial page in the Wiki (you can delete the .txt extension). The file name must be in CamelCase format. This is a once only operation i.e. you cannot change your mind about the use of this feature after the Wiki is created. Create a folder in the course files area and put the initial page file in there or all files in the main course files area will show as pages when you select options from the "Choose Wiki Links" drop down menu. Ray

Of course, you can also add a Wiki on the Site page (which is technically a course anyway) in the Main Menu block or the Topic area (if you have that enabled to "Yes" in Site Settings.

ResponsesInList.Title: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
Can data from a table on a Wiki page be exported as CSV (text separated
by commas or tabs)? I have the following problem. We have a project
where it is necessary that all people participating in the creation of
materials can keep track of the codes and names given to documents that
are created by other members of the team. This is necessary because we
want to build some sort of database with information about the
documents and the documents must have a unique code number. People who
create new documents must know whether the code already exists for a
particular document and assign a higher number if this is the case. Excel files work very well for this purpose but the great inconvenience
is that one must download them and upload them again once they are
modified. Since there might be many people working at the same time
that might be a problem. I thought that creating a table on a Wiki
could be a good solution. And here is the reason for my question. Every
once in a while we would like to export the data in the table to be
able to feed it into an excel file or perhaps some data base aplication
but I don't know whether this is possible with a Wiki. Does anybody know the answer to this question? If this is not possible,
does anybody know of some possible solution to this problem? Thanks very much. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I haven't tried to export a large table but I have exported wikis containing tables into HTML and then copied the tables in an excel file without any problem. The problem, though, was more about filling in the table in the first place as some people (students in my case) may prefer to have 'ready-made' cells rather than having to type the '|' themselves. FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm showing my ignorance, but how does one do that. How does one export a table from an HTML document to an excel file? Thanks. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Just highlight the table(making sure that all the cells are highlighted), copy to the clipboard and paste into an Excel worksheet. FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot, FranÃ§oise, I didn't think it was going to be that simple, but your solution does work rather well. Somebody else on a different forum suggested also using the data > import data > web query option in Excel. That didn't work, however, probably because the page is within my Moodle site and it needs a password to access it. Josep M.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried what you say but the presentation is wrong in excel (see next example). I'm working on macintosh (Safari 2, Firefox 1, Firefox 1.5, excel 2004). For example, for the following table in the wiki: Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 row 1 col 1 row 1 col 2 row 1 col 3 row 2 col 1 row 2 col 2 row 2 col 3 row 3 col 1 row 3 col 2 row 3 col 3 row 4 col 1 row 4 col 2 row 4 col 3 the result with a copy/paste in excel is: Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 row 1 col 1 row 1 col 2Â Â Â  row 1 col 3 row 2 col 1Â Â Â  row 2 col 2 row 2 col 3 row 3 col 1Â Â Â  row 3 col 2 row 3 col 3 row 4 col 1Â Â Â  row 4 col 2 row 4 col 3 After the first cell of each row, a return is added. So the presentation of the table is wrong. Perhaps, may be from the coding of the return on macintosh which is different on windows. What do you think about that ? Last minute : the problem is solved using internet explorer. However, microsoft stopped the development of IE on macintosh since few years. So, I would like that the problem will solve with a another web browser like Firefox. Thanks in advance for your help. Christian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Exporting data from a Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hola Josep MÂª, keep you data on the wiki ( a dfwiki of course ), if you need if I can provide you with a way to save the content of a wiki page to an html file (that you will be able to import from excel or open office ), and a way to import html data into a wiki page. This way you'll have a two way comunication tool. Wold this solve your needs? Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Severe performance issues after import/export to latest dfWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey all, I recently upgraded my dfWIki whose pages were created using a 'pre-export feature' version of dfWiki. I upgraded to the recent version of dfWiki I exported my current wiki pages (no history) I loaded up the new server and imported that the import seemed to work fine -Â  all the pages were there. Two problems remained, however: formatting - pages created with the wysiwyg viewer lost the carraige returns between lines so all the text runs together. (~1000 pages - yikes!) Performance - each page takes 30sec to load now. The performance issue is the real drawback - the site is very hard to study from now. Has anyone else had similar issues? any idea how to fix this?Â  I had originally imported the whole wiki with all the historical versions of all the pages - then, thinking that was the source of the slowdown, i recreated the wiki using just the latest version of each page - but still have the same problem. thanks for any help you can offer! -jon

ResponsesInList.Title: edit opens blank page, international wiki links, and more.
ResponsesInList.Text: I have some trouble with wiki module in moodle 1.5.3+ (2005060230) First of all, I have trouble editing existing pages. You can check it on the wiki at http://apuntes.byethost3.com/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=40 Clicking on edit tab of any page, it navigates to: http://apuntes.byethost3.com/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=40&page=edit/PageName which is interpreted as editing a new page called editPageName (i.e., if you aim to edit WikiFormato, you end on a new page called editWikiFormato). I have slash arguments disabled in my site, since my hosting provider has it disabled in apache and does not allow overrides. (EDIT: I've just seen a bug in wiki has been corrected in the last days. I'll check that). Second problem deals with international chars. I have no trouble with putting wiki links with accented chars in moodle 1.4.x in my local server , but the exported wiki does not work in moodle 1.5.x in my hosting provider. I think it deals with url charset, but I can't find a way to make moodle unaccent every wiki link (i.e. I know wikipages with accented names will be inaccesible, but other users of this wiki could forget about it).

ResponsesInList.Title: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. I've started to use Moodle three months ago for an international project including schools from Wales, Denmark, Ireland and Norway (a Comenius project). I have very little experience with wikis, but I think it would be a good tool to gather the information and knowledge we put together during our 3-year project. I have a few questions I hope someone can answer: Is the wiki module stable and ready to use? What is dfwiki? Is it standard with Moodle 1.5.2? Would the wiki module be able to handle uploading of images, audio files and small videos? Thanks, Thor Hauknes, Norway

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: as far as I know, the wiki module that comes with the standard moodle distribution hasn't been developped for a while, that's why we are looking forward to including the actively-developed dfwiki module into 1.6. Concerning the stability issues: Generally, I do not like the wiki module because it has some problems with non-cyrillic characters, and some code customizations are needed to fix that. Imho, the dfwiki is now ready-to-use - it comes with a pretty-simple interface and a number of editors, including their own editor and std. html-editor of moodle. I've set up several modules with dfwiki, they seem to work stable and are easy-to-update and change. Concerning upload functions: - upload of images is very easy , you may do that without any problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alexandre, thank you for endorsing our dear dfwiki module . The pdf error that you report looks like a MIME type error in your apache server, I've been uploading PDF's into moodle since version 1.3 and allways worked fine. The size limit that you anounce is limeted by the admin in the general upload limit and by the teacher in the course preferences. In our university we are uploading files up to 100MB . By the way you can download the lastest stable dfwiki here dfwiki_1.0_rev2005110201.zip or in the dfwiki home page http://appserv.lsi.upc.es/palangana/moodle/course/view.php?id=15 Regards Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Svar: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, both of you for taking the time to help me. If i understand this correctly, I would be fine using dfwiki for my project. This is a three-year project; would I be able to update dfwiki (and moodle) during this timespan without losing my work? And, most important, how do I install and combine dfwiki with my existing moodle 1.5.2 installation. This is installed on a linux server, my access to this is through Cpanel and ftp . I would also be happy if you could point me to sites already using dfwiki regards Thor

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Svar: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text:
I think you'll be able to update both moodle and dfwiki without losing any data. The dfwiki course format is rather new, I doubt there exist many
courses at the time, but a pretty nice course demonstration is located
at the developers' site Ludo (Marc Alier) yes, thanks, I know I should dig into apache but for the present moment I'm too lazy for that . I thought I mentioned that those are not dfwiki's problems ;), but my hands' . >This is installed on a linux server , my access to this is through Cpanel and ftp . just download wiki and unpack to appropriate folders (instructions are inside the distribution). Then go to the admin page of your moodle installation - you should see the log of successful installation. After that new resource and course will be available. Generally, the process is the same for each module installed

ResponsesInList.Title: Svar: Re: Svar: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: I've uploaded and unzipped the file in moodles root directory. I still can't use it, even after logging in with administrator privileges. Could the problem be that my moodle directory's name is not moodle, but comenius? Thor

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Svar: Re: Svar: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: assuming you've downloaded dfwiki_1.0_rev2005110201.zip: it contains a folder "dfwiki pack" with 3 subfolders: - course - lang - mod. Unpack "course" to "course" folder of your moodle installation, so that a folder dfwiki appears in the "course" folder, the same with lang and mod. So if, for example, /var/www/html/ is your moodle root, it should already contain course, lang, mod. After you unpack the archive, course/format/dfwiki/, mod/dfwiki/, lang/en/dfwiki.php should appear. Don't forget to chmod them to your httpd-owner user (not actually necessary, but sometimes useful). Then go to http://your-moodle-site/admin/ as administrator and you'll see that dfwiki is installed. It will appear in the modules list. That's all

Thor

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: I've found the cause of the error. Postgres doesn't like the ` characters around the column names. These don't appear in all of the queries, just the two max queries. I've taken them out in my copy and it's started working. I've changed the query to read: if (!$max = get_record_sql('SELECT MAX(version) AS maxim FROM '. $CFG->prefix.'dfwiki_pages WHERE pagename=\''.$pagename.'\' AND dfwiki='.$dfwiki->id)){ error ('ha passat un error al accedir al mÃ xim in english');

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The Wiki module - stable and ready to use?
ResponsesInList.Text: Using the existing architecture, I've created a patch which makes the system work with postgres. I've removed all the ` characters from the queries and adjusted some of escape quotes.

ResponsesInList.Title: formatting problems with wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: We are running moodle 1.5.3 here at Thanet College on Windows server 2000 and IE6. We are using wikis to support student lesson plans but have noticed that we can't hold the formatting of any wiki page once it has passed through one editing. For example any table settings imported simply collapse. Using tables to create charts andÂ simple formsÂ is an excellent way of sharing student attainment amongst tutors and the student concerned. Formatting text also will not work so we cannot use bold orÂ colour distinguish between student and tutor entries which is so helpful to us. Wikis are such a great learning tool that we want to keep using them. AnyÂ suggestions please.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to protect text on a Wiki page
ResponsesInList.Text: As a teacher, how can I put text onto a wiki page that students cannot delete? I would wish them to be able to perform edits on the remainder of the page, but not on the language i use as the header...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to protect text on a Wiki page
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I assume you've considered putting the text in the summary? Otherwise, there's no way of protecting text. However, if students understand that certain text in the wiki must not
be deleted, they have no incentive to do so, knowing that you can
simply revert back to an earlier version.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki problems - layout and prepopulating
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm using a prepopulated wiki page with some of my users, who are organised in groups. Most of the groups prepopulated OK, but some (who logged on for the first time yesterday) found that the prepopulation had not worked - they just got an empty page. Today I've been trying to add the template content into the pages they edited yesterday. (It's just a table containing heading and empty bullet points.) When I save it the document appears to have been cut in half and reordered. The "Thank you for your contribution" occurs half-way down the page with the top half of the document below it. The rest of the document comes above the "Thank you.." message. When I go to edit again, a number of tags have been added, similarly to Bug 3721 ( http://moodle.org/bugs/bug.php?op=show&bugid=3721 ), but I'm using version 1.5.3+ not 1.6 [Edit: just noticed that the break is happening just above the "referring links" text. Anything from then on, until halfway down the document is going to the bottom of the page. The split then happens just above a set of bullet points]

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki problems - layout and prepopulating
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The problem appears to be something to do with tables. If I take the content out of a table things go in the wiki OK (except for losing some tags) Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki problems - layout and prepopulating
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark, we have the same problem. We are convinced the problem has occured since upgrading to 1.5.3+ and is a bug in the latest download . In the absence of anyone telling us any differentÂ I am going to report it as a bug.

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki for Co-authoring publications
ResponsesInList.Text: This question isn't particularly about the Moodle wikis, but I thought I would post it in this forum because I would assume those who read it would be wiki-knowledgeable. The common conception of a wiki is something that is open to anyone editing it. However, I'm wondering about the applicability of using a wiki to collaborate on a co-authored academic publication. I've talked to two different colleagues (individually) in the past about the possibility of collaborating on a book on a particular topic that each of us has certain strengths related to it and also differing access to useful sources. Currently, we are in three different countriess (US, Egypt, and Australia) and so we face not only physical distance but also timezone distance so synchronous collaborative activity seems prohibitive. I'm pondering the idea of writing the book using a wiki, even perhaps setting up a special Moodle course to do it. Does anyone know if this has been done before in the academic world? Does anyone know of any wiki-authoring guidelines (I'm not talking about technical ones, more the writing process) available that would be applicable to such a situation? Any ideas on this idea?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Co-authoring publications
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I strongly believe that the wiki model is the best one for collaborative authoring of texts of any kind. As you may allready kwno I've ben developing a new wiki module for
moodle:dfwiki. This module is designed specifically to host projects of
collaborative authoring. Tha'ts wy we include the "blocs" with the
"index page tree", page glossay, page navigation,Â  admin with page
locking, wanted pages, orphanded pages, user contrib page list, and so
on... Ah you also can choose wich wiki markup language to use and even the moodle HTML editor. Rigth now we have released a moodle course based on a wiki content. In the next weeks we are going to release a wiki indexin tool, wich
will hep you to solve one of the porblema asociated with the wiki
contents: caos. The links in a wiki text tend to grow exponentially, so
is a good idea to have a MAIN INDEX to guide the reader throug the text
(and a eventual pdf export filter, that we are also developing). Meet dfwiki here: http://appserv.lsi.upc.es/palangana/moodle/course/view.php?id=15 download dfwiki here: dfwiki_1.0_rev2005110201.zip Test dfwiki here

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Co-authoring publications
ResponsesInList.Text: I strongly believe that the wiki model is the best one for collaborative authoring of texts of any kind. I agree, there are two approaches for writing together with ICT: The workflow format, better in control of the process, worse in supporting the creativity flows in aÂ collab. The wiki format: the ultime free format tool. Most of the supporting tools of Wiki are there to prevent that it becomes a mess. So if you choose a wiki: You must set rules how to use it together: for example in the past I was moving a text from page 3 to page 5 in collab project, and everytime it went back to the old page.. Until I got a message from the famous Alan Kay that he was the other person, moving the text from page 5 to page 3.. We settled it in our emails, I forgot the solution, so he won? ) I use for years a privat wiki (Swiki) to store al my snippets in a Wiki, for exampleÂ (see picture)Â Moodle things I find in the forums. When you start a project you hardly know how the end-result will look like, so it is very important that you can reorganise the pages AND the page names before your final book will crystalize in your wiki. In the example I wrote Moodle 1.3, but Janne's CMS is for 1.5, so I should AND CAN change the title of the page in this Swiki. I hope dfWiki wil get - or already has ? this option Another nice option in the Swiki is the easy way I can lock the pages page by page (as writers) but still can allow other people to add comments on the closed pages: the visitorÂ can fill the commentbox and I get an email. YouÂ canÂ divide the pages by simply putting different emailadresses in the edit forms of different pages: the person with the email on that page will receive the messages on that page. When your book gets structure, you can decide who will work on (the comments) of which chapter / subject. If you need a form on some page - in Swiki -Â you can design a form in your webbrowser and publish that for the visitor (or yourself With forms you can force more page structure, the pages are stored as XML , so the form-pages are easier to harvest.Â You even can design the form pages in edit-view and view-view with additional html or so, so the form stays not that abstarcat when you fill it.) In the new version of Swiki you even can past a calendar page and hang "yellow" wiki pages behind every date. Swiki is a standalone mini- server . I can install and start to use it in less then 30 seconds and if I get a faster laptop I will improve that record. (Before we had Moodle we used it with secondary school children - for example to write their own guide for the visit to Rome. Soem teachers still combine it with Moodle.) If dfWiki will get all these options, I will prefer dfWiki:Â for advanced users it offers much more support. When I want to close a wiki for a group, but still wish to allow not-moodle-users (I hardly can imagine that these people exist) to access the pages AND FILL the comment boxes, then dfWiki must support the guest account for that purpose. (Maybe that is already built in, I did not look for dfWiki for several weeks or so.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Co-authoring publications
ResponsesInList.Text:
Wow, wow, wow, this feels lika a requirement list , I like it... quality feedback is allways hard to find and wellcome! Let's take it poit by point: >When you start a project you hardly know how the end-result will look like, so it >is very important that you can reorganise the pages AND the page names >before
your final book will crystalize in your wiki. In the example I wrote

This for instance can allow you to merge subjects A and B without changing all the links. You delete B page, and define B as A synonimous, so all the links to B will go to A. >Another nice option in the Swiki is the easy way I can lock the pages
page by >page (as writers) but still can allow other people to add
comments on the >closed pages: the visitorÂ can fill the commentbox and I
get an email. Yes dfwiki has it ! Its in the Admin bloc you can enable and disable the edition to students. > If you need a form on some page - in Swiki -Â you can design a form in

so the form-pages are easier to harvest.Â You even can design the form
pages in edit-view and view-view with additional html or so, so the
form stays not that abstarcat when you fill it.) Ohhh we don't have this, we are working on something alike, but maybe we can use the idea (and the code if is in php and open source ) >In the new version of Swiki you even can past a calendar page and hang "yellow" wiki pages behind every date. Amazing.. I want that on dfwiki! >When I want to close a wiki for a group, but still wish to allow
not-moodle-users (I hardly can imagine that these people exist) to
access the pages AND FILL the comment boxes, then
dfWiki must support the guest account for that purpose. (Maybe that is
already built in, I did not look for dfWiki for several weeks or so.) Comment boxes and discussion pages are one of the forthcomming features, a matter of weeks. Please ANY suggestion will be wellcome... I want dfwiki to be as great as it can be. Regards Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Slow WIKI... fixed!
ResponsesInList.Text: Used moodle on my laptop for proof of concept - worked great! Installed it on the "big server ", and wikis would take 20 seconds or so to update. Grrrr! Found that Ewiki.php, around line 3000, does a hostname() lookup, which is good in theory. EXCEPT that the web server is in the DMZ, looking at our external DNS server. My client is on the inside of the firewall (10.x.x.x) number, so there's no entry in the external DNS. Evidently, the lookup times out then posts. Probably not elegant, but I made the following change: #$hostname = gethostbyaddr($ip); $hostname = $ip; I'm thinking it *might* work OK without $hostname being defined, but it's rockin' and I'm happy... Derry

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Slow WIKI... fixed!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Derry, your change has been applied to source code (now in CVS ). As the hostname isn't used at all by the wiki module, it will reduce a lot of DNS searches (specially notable when the lookup doesn't return anything). Thanks and ciao

ResponsesInList.Title: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear wiki developers, we are developing virtual environment for university thesis writing and thesis supervising for Finnish university students and their supervisors. We think Moodle would be probably best platform to our environment and we are starting our own development work. We are very interested about Wiki and its development like dfWiki. In dfwiki there seems to be some very interested features. Wikiexport is important feature to our project. So, I am asking your help in following questions: 1) When exporting Wikipages, is it possible to include ALL links in Wiki? We have tested Moodle's current Erfurt Wiki, and there is a problem because you can only import "downward" links. Referring links (breadcrumb trails) are not included when we have tested wikiexport. So if you look your exported wikipages in browser, you can go from one wikipage to another, but you cannot come back via wiki's links. 2) It would be useful to export wikis to pdf- or rtf. Is anyone developing solutions to this? 3) When exporting wikipages to html/pdf/rtf, it would be also useful to replace Wiki's CamelLetters with normal text. Is there solutions to this? TIA ,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jani, first of all wiki (efurt Wifi) and dfwiki are completelly diferent modules and they almost don't share code ( only in the backward compatibility ewiki editor mode ). In dfwiki we have the import / export feature and the backup/restore feature wich integrates into the moodle backup system. I prefer the import export feature because it allows me to replicate wiki contets to any course or moodle installation. In the next two weeks we'll release a new dfwiki feature that will allow us to import data from old efurtwikis to dfwiki (extracting it from the moodle backup files). PDF and XHTML export is scheduled for next month. If you use dfwiki in html editor or dfwiki editor mode you don't need to use CamelCase, you simply use double brackets for links . Regards Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Vast: Re: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marc, thanks a lot! We are looking forward about this pdf export - it sounds really interesting. In dfWiki XHTML export, is there solution to link export problem I described in my first message?Â  I have been testing dfWiki at your Moodle site's sandbox and it looks really great! regards Jani

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Vast: Re: Wikiexport: some questions
ResponsesInList.Text: There's allways the option of creating page synonims in dfwiki so CamelCase can become "Camel Case" and a search an replace tool can be used to change CamelCase links to Camel Case or Camel Case.. Regards Marc

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki for teachers only?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for teachers only?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Matt, Please note that there is a teachers' forum link in each course administration block. Re. a teachers' wiki, this may be easily accomplished simply by hiding
it from students. Indeed, any activity that teachers are developing may
be hidden from students until ready for use. If you're using topic format, you may like to consider setting up an
additional course section for teachers only, that is permanently
hidden, for activity development and for displaying files for teachers
only. I've found that teachers in my college particularly appreciate
such a section.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Headers sent Error for newbie to Wiki
ResponsesInList.Text:
Still having problems with this? As it says in the error message, you are not allowed to execute /usr/bin/patch, because your service provider uses open_basedir restriction. The function is_executable returns false, and the plugin 'edit_patch' does not get loaded. This is the correct behaviour, I believe. Have you enabled 'debug' mode in your Moodle (configuration/variables/debug). If not, the warning should not appear and mess with your headers. If debug has been set to 'No' and you still get the warning, you can remove it by adding an error control operator (@): 
```text
Â  if (@is_executable( ...
```
 Regards, Jarkko.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to draw in the DFwiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: Tremendous to hear that Marc.Â  I believe the a Wiki with drawing capability will have GREAT potential.Â  I just played with the ImaginationCubed site (posted here previously) with other users simultaneously - it is really really good - it's got the WOWÂ  factor -Â albeit with some limitations.Â  In schools, this could be a very powerful tool, so please do consider development in this area.Â Â  Teachers like me will then be eternally grateful to you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to draw in the DFwiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: Um, if I may add a point of view ... such things should not go into a Wiki ... but be a separate activity module.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to draw in the DFwiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: I feel that there is great potential in having SOMETHING which would allow collaboration Wiki- like as I feel TEXTUAL Wiki Working is only part of the 'deal' - whether it is a tool WITHIN a WIKI or a separte entity, I wouldn't be fussed.Â  Fooling around with some friends inÂ the GEC ImaginationCubed site has shown me that. I think that such a truly collaborative tool, which in the case of ImaginationCubed works SIMULTANEOUSLY ,Â  run with a group ofÂ  students WHEREVER in the world they happen to be (such as my boarders when they are on holiday all over the world)Â could expand learning in my school dramatically. I take your point, but making a Wiki multi-faceted beyond text input, would be something I'd find useful.Â  But then I don't have the bigger picture I'm not aware of the other rigours and demands placed on developers and I'm also (as you know) ETERNALLY grateful for WHATEVER tools are put at our disposal by the BRILLIANT team that are behind Moodle development.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to draw in the DFwiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: No worries, Drew ... the whole of Moodle is meant to be collaborative to some extent ... my concern is just to organise the overall interface in a logical and usable way so that the widest group of people can make sense of it. If you are thinking mostly of synchronous co-drawing then a much better match for this would be in the chat module (search previous discussions on whiteboards) because you can talk while you draw (and also share audio/video later). A asychronous whiteboard is sometimes called a " grafitti wall " ... it might be possible to develop something like this as an optional part of each Wiki page but we should really talk about how the interface should work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to draw in the DFwiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: Uuh, then we can get into "what is a Wiki", meaning, what are the characteristics that make Wiki a Wiki If you "just" need a collaborative whiteboard with both drawing and text options, it certainly should/could be a new module.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to draw in the DFwiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: In the past (1996) we had websites presentingÂ information. It was in the days that most of us assumed that good education was all aboutÂ feeding the students on the right time with the rightÂ knowledge (sometimes even piece by piece: like in programmed instruction). ThenÂ check it with tests andÂ Word-assignments and show them the way to other resources. The first VLE's showed alsoÂ that face on the early internet. Typical parts in these days: resources, weblinks, quiz, faq, glossary, guided instruction (AICC) Around 1997 the next generation VLE's came up:Â websites combining the presentation of information with tools to support the communication about these (new) artefacts: forum,Â  *) chat, poll,Â shared workspace, It could help the individual student to sharpen his individual thoughts by comparing them with the expressed thoughts of himself and others in the forums or by sharing collectedÂ (and selfÂ created) artefacts.Â Moodle was born in this era,Â focusing on forums andÂ missing in the beginning the shared workspace. With Wikis (popularity starts around 2000)Â you introduce a new kind of tools: it offers the opportunity to construct - in a loosy way **)Â - together with other students a new knowledge artefact while the teacher can monitor the ongoing work (and give on-line helpfull cues). Without the wiki the collaboration is happening outside the view of the helpfull teacher: they get an asssignment, construct something in Word and deliver that after several weeks as their masterpiece: difficult to help them during these three weeks and give feedback on their learning process if you only can see the final product. The last innovation is that the focus is more and more shifting from teachers to students: Give students tools so they can monitor (and steer!) their own learning process. (MoodleFN, the project templates and our own humble checkmark-graph, visible in my personal iconÂ areÂ such attempts, I hope Martin spends some time on it.) Giving students access toÂ the toolsÂ for creating the education artefacts in a course:Â students as constructors: glossary, wiki, (So when can we give students AS CONSTRUCTORS access to all these beautiful teachertools like book, multipage, quizz, lesson , (shared) journals, etc... WITHOUT LOOSING THE PRIVACY RESPECTING MONITOR FUNCTION for the professional teacher/coach. Can't we create a mechanism like in the wiki: teacher class group student access under the same button and combine this witha better filtering on the edit-fields, also wished for non-expert teachers as editors...) I disagreeÂ with the well meant attempts to limit the teacher in his choices. ***) Why not allow them to add all kind of tools inside a wiki? OR...why not allow them to add all kind of tools in the sidebar of a central forum? Wasn't that the original thought behind the social format? If you want to help the teacher with his design choices, then a growing set of templates would help more then restricting possibilities. *) Social Constructivism is not the inventor of this forum-idea: I found the idea in a book from 1962 by A.D. de Groot (founder of the Dutch Curriculem Institue and famous writer of "(Misconseptions about) The thinking of the chessplayer".Â The book is called Methodology, foundations for research and thinking in the Social Sciences.Â In this bookÂ the author explains that after constructing your artefact you "as little scientist" go back to the forumÂ forÂ checking your idea/theory/idolaÂ against the thinking of the "ruling" community.. **) In the past the Computer Industry was trying hard to build very restrictiv tools to collect and store Knowledge (AI), what neverÂ worked in educational settings. ***)Â Do you remember the early discussionsÂ abaout the wishÂ to have aÂ Wiki in Moodle? Now we have two

Here belowÂ is a screen shot showing the way that the wiki garbles with Japanese. The areas circled in green show correctly displayed Japanese characters - i.e. most of the Japanese displays fine. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Major Japanese Language Problems
ResponsesInList.Text: Over at the Japanese forum toward the end of last year a very accomplished programmer called Mr. Kashiwagi (he called himself a C programmer or something and said that he was not too good at php) created a patch to solve pretty much all of the garbling problems for moodle 1.4. He created the patch and then left. Then I was asked if this was still going to be a problem when we started to use ja_utf8 and I did not know how to answer. But after having spent a lot of time upgrading my sites to UTF8 I find that the garbling (mojibake) problems are still pretty much as they were. The Wiki still garbles in places as before The Excel files need to be downloaded in Shift JIS format. I think that GD and the graphs it produces still garbles The mails sent out by moodle are almost okay for many mail software but more primitive mail software (such as that ofÂ mobile phones and theÂ mail software used at my university to avoid all the virus problems inherent in Outlook Express)Â only deals with JSIS or the ISO xyz format, especially in the subject sender, and adressee headerÂ fields. Even (?) outlook express cannot deal with UTFÂ in the sender field. By the way does SJIS goÂ under another ISO xyz name? Meanwhile Narumi Sekiya has created a block to allow moodle to send outÂ abreviated mail in ISO xyz formatÂ to mobile phones. And the Japanese forums abound with people having problems with garbling related to the above issues. I think thatÂ if Mr. Kashiwagi were to return, or someone of his expertises (e.g. Mr. Kagotani from Okayama Uni?) then another patch for 1.5 could beÂ created, but basicallyÂ there areÂ problemsÂ with garblingÂ here in Japan.Â SJIS isÂ naff but a standard. Untill mail software,Â mobile phones,Â GD image processing libraries and the spreadsheet software we are using becomes UFT8 friendly then I think that the oldÂ SJIS format needs to be used?? But I am not sure. I also think thatÂ DFwikiÂ has a lot of future since 1) I hear that the developer of this wiki is not around, much. 2) It uses a more popular wiki style (that of wikipedia) 3) It is being actively developed. I hear that there are or wereÂ some problems (fewer but some) with DFwiki as well but I pray that these may be solved. AsÂ co-faciliator of the Japanese Moodle community I feel that I am letting everyone down by not conveying the problems adequately. If anyone wants to contact me in Japanese to tell me what I should be telling the developers, and what bugs I should be posting then please mail me (tim at nihonbunka dot com) Timothy

Your suggestions will make DFwiki better, Ferran Recio.

ResponsesInList.Title: Status of Wiki modules?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm sorry if I'm disturbing, but I'm a bit confused by wiki modules and diferent versions of it. I understand the standard bundled version of Wiki module is based on ErfurtWiki. While, many recent (and promissing) messages in this forum refer to "dfwiki". My conclusion was the two are not the same thing, and that there are two wiki modulesÂ being developed in parallel.Â Is that right? If yes,Â my questions would be: What is the general orientation for future bundling, which one will become standard? Which one is currently more indicated (stable, scalable, etc.) for production installations? Thank you in advance for your kind answer. Regards.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Status of Wiki modules?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John, I'm one of the developers of DFwiki. As you said, DFwiki isn't the same as ErfurtWiki. DFwiki is a completely new wiki module project. ErfurtWiki is a good software, but it doesn't work well with Moodle. Obviously, we want DFwiki to be the next Moodle oficial wiki. If you want to try it, the URL is: http://appserv.lsi.upc.es/palangana/moodle/course/view.php?id=15 I can't answer your second question (which is better) because I'm not objective. But DFwiki is developed to solve all ewikiÂ troubles and we are working hard on it. All suggestions about DFwiki will be helpful. I recommendÂ toÂ try it both and post in this forum your conclusions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Status of Wiki modules?
ResponsesInList.Text: HI John, tree months ago I asked Martin his aproval to develop a brand new wiki module. The main developer of Ewiki (current main moodle wiki) module is now missing and another moodle developer is maintanining it. In its due time Martin will have to decide if he wants dfwiki to become the official moodel wiki ( we hope so ). But before we bring this issue, dfwiki has to reach two specific requirements that martin asked: * import capability from the old ewiki. * backup / restore I believe the other requirements are allready accomplished. However, rigth now dfwiki is pretty stable, and if you want to use it within your moodle 1.5 server you only have to download , copy the files and add the activity to your courses. Cheers Ludo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Status of Wiki modules?
ResponsesInList.Text: >I believe the other requirements are allready accomplished. Is there any way to include dfwiki activity in the Moodle activity logs? The professor for the course I'm working on really likes being able to see how many times students have viewed all the other resources in Moodle (text pages, forum postings, chat logs, etc.), especially for calculating participation marks. However, under all the dfwikis, no activity is shown. Within the dfwikis themselves, I can tell which pages have been viewed the most often, but not who viewed them. ResponsesInList.Title: What is a Wiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not clear on the WIKI format. Can someone please describe what it is and an actual example of how it can be used? If at all possible I would LOVE to have access to see one in action. I am a visual learner. Thanks a bunch!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is a Wiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: What is Wiki? Moodle's internal wikis are for use within the context of a course. There are also public wikis. WikEd (operated by my research group) is specifically for education-related topics. Here's an example of how a public wiki can be used in a classroom situation. The internal Moodle wikis are much the same, but you have tighter control on who can access and edit them.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is a Wiki??
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Karrie, A wiki is a web page that can be edited and changed by the users.Â  That means that your students not only read the page: they write the content, can add new pages, change them, construct the site. To actually enter teh text you need a syntax, codes to say to the computer "this is a link", "this is bold". There are several wiki-syntaxes. Moodle offers several, Markdown is one. But you can use the regular HTML editor with Moodle wikis if you like.Â  So, the key point about wikis is thatÂ  they are user-editable, the wiki syntax is a minor point, an optional one. - Enrique -

ResponsesInList.Title: A first encounter with the Wiki module
ResponsesInList.Text: I have deployed Wiki too hastily and ran into the following difficulties: a. The students were supposed to use ellipses like [...] to mean ommited text. All these have been converted to ... ? b. For an unknown reason, students have created multiple Wiki-pages. And they have difficulties in finding their work again ( Our setup is pretty simple: For a certain exercise each student is supposed to maintain his/her own wiki-page. The trainer writes his comments on the _same_ wiki, which the students then intergrate into their work. The students can _read_ other wikis at any time. The course is set to Groupmode=visible groups and force group mode=no. In the Wiki HTML-mode=HTML-only, wiki-type=student On the edit view I see a "group icon" (two busts) behind the Wiki-symbol. Question 1: Can I deaktivate the Wiki-mark up entirely?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A first encounter with the Wiki module
ResponsesInList.Text: Got it all sorted out thanks to Ralf Hilgenstock here http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=18811 (bottom of the discussion) (my translation) "Question 1: Can I deaktivate the Wiki-mark up entirely?" No. We hat to change the notation [...] to (...) Sidenote: The correct term is "mark down". "Question 2: Are the settings above correct for my plan?" They were correct. The confution occured probably because the type of the course "visible groups" was set _after_ the wiki was created. "Question 3: I want to do a clean-up since the students and teachers are lost in the Wiki jungle sad I though of exporting the Wikis, delete them, recreate and add the text. Since there are only 14 students affordable. Is there a better way of doing this?" May be. But I didn't want to take any chances: - exported each student's wiki - deactivated the old wiki - created a new one - added the old text manually to each student's wiki For a class of 15 that was OK. It had the pleasent side effect, that I could clean some horrible mark up generated by MS Word cut-and-pasted to WYSISWYG editor. "Question 4: It is planned to give the students _another_ Wiki to work in groups of two. The students are supposed to find a parner. What is the best way of doing this? For example, can they register the groups themselves?" Created a "group wiki" (after I have set the course type). Works perfectly. best regards Visvanath.

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor
ResponsesInList.Text: I was just playing with the SandBox in the MoodleWiki that Martin created, and I noticed a few features I was not aware ewiki had: alignment of figures and font coloring, to name a couple. Trying to look at the source of the pages that generated that page, I realized that those tricks were not being inserted by ewiki but by the HTML editor. This is a potential source of trouble. For instance, to include an image, some users will use the ewiki syntax [image URL ] while others will insert it directly with the HTML editor in a form that is not the standard ewiki method and which will be very hard to parse by wiki-to-something parsers (they are actually inserting HTML code directly, which is a feature of ewiki, but in a hidden form that goes against the simplicity of other wikis). On the other hand you can see in the SandBox that users waste a lot of time playing with fancy tricks in the HTML editor, rather than writting content without worrying about format. I propose that the use of the HTML editor be forbidden in the Wiki module, even for those users that select it as default.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor
ResponsesInList.Text: That's a choice you have when you set up your own Wikis in Moodle. Some sites will want to allow the editor, some will not.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor
ResponsesInList.Text: In a WIki users do a lot reshaping their pages. With the HTML-editor of I see two problems with the HTML-editor: all theÂ Â "do's Â and undo's" when editing a resource areÂ inserted as new tags, again and again... (it is moreÂ a kind of "redo and redo") if you insert a relative pathÂ  to a resource and you reopen theÂ editor, the editor makes it absolute and most of the time you even end up with a serious browser-error. Also here a problem: When you migrate to a new server , like we do on this moment, you have to change all these absolute paths in documents that were touched by the HTML-editor.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor
ResponsesInList.Text: So, what are you suggesting with respect to the wiki module? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Nothing, ask others to repair the html-editor: make it more sstupid? I was wondering if tools like HTML Tidy (behind a button ) could help?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestion: please disable HTML editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Not necessary John. When you set up a wiki, you can specify "No HTML", which disables the HTML editor for that wiki. So you can do what you want for each and every wiki activity you create. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Markdown format for wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: I was wondering if there is any plan of including the markdown format in the wiki module? Or the wiki format (as opposed to the wiki-like format) in other activities (such as forums and glossary)? I am a bit concerned about the possible confusion if students need to use a different syntax depending on the activity they do. In our university, the HTML editor has been disabled (but I won't go into the reasons, they are pretty sound), so the HTML format is not the most convenient. FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Markdown format for wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmmm. I wasn't actually aware of the 'markdown' format. I suppose it could be incorporated â€¦ If you use the 'No HTML' setting for the wikis, it won't use the HTML editor, but most of the HTML tags Moodle uses can still be coded manually into the text and they will work. This probably means that the Markdown format would mostly work anyway. But, wikis are really meant to be used with wiki format. You could always use the 'wiki-like' format in the other activities. It should be the same for formatting - just won't have wiki links. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Markdown format for wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I understand it, the wiki-like format is actually quite different from the wiki format (as in your wiki module). The issue arose because I realised that when my students were using the moodle auto-format to build a glossary, which I use a lot (I teach French for Science and Technology...), exporting the glossary was a nightmare as the XML file did not include paragraph tags. The markdown format looks very appealing, and can be used in most moodle activities. I don't think that my students will have any problem learning it. And no more need to type in html tags, which really slows down the writing. So I am thinking of pushing them to use the markdown format almost everywhere. But then, when it comes to the wikis, this means having to learn a new format again. Mind you, it may not be a huge problem, but it could be a bit confusing, if not overwhelming for first year students (although the students come to me to learn French, they come out of my course fluent in html, wiki and markdown...). Perhaps the solution would be to replace the wiki-like format by the proper wiki format in all activities... In any case, this will be an on-going issue in our place... It will be interesting to see which format the whole university adopts for communicating via moodle. FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Markdown format for wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: Does anyone know if the formatting module in the current wiki is pluggable. I'd be really interested in adding Markdown if it is. Also here are some links related to this discussion: A wiki (written in ruby) called instiki that allows markdown as a formatting option: http://instiki.nextangle.com:3000/instiki/show/Markup+Languages It also allows textile (which is the main inspiration for the Wiki-like format and rdoc , a ruby code documentation format. There is also a PEAR library in PHP for parsing Wiki Text: http://wiki.ciaweb.net/yawiki/index.php?area=Text_Wiki This could be easily slotted into Moodle, everywhere that Markdown currently is. Unfortunately, while it is more truely wiki-like, there is no actual standard for Wiki markup so it probably differs in a few places from the markup in the actual Wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Markdown format for wiki module?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would love to see the Wiki offer exactly the same options for formatting as the standard Moodle list (Markdown, Moodle format, HTML, etc)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wiki type
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to set the activity (or the course's) group setting. To change an activity group setting, go to the course page and turn editing on. Next to every activity you will see the group switch icon. Clicking on it will rotate through the group modes. Stop when you get to 'no groups' (icon looks like a single person). mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Handling same time editing
ResponsesInList.Text: Can someone clarify how the WIKI handles multiple editing sessions at the same time?Â  If I have more than 1 student working on the same page at the same time, how does the module handle the SAVE?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Handling same time editing
ResponsesInList.Text: If someone saves a version of the page after you started editing, then you will be told that you can't overwrite it when you try to save. It will suggest you copy your text, and edit the new version (I believe). The message it provides is: " Sorry, while you edited this page someone else did already save a changed version. Please go back to the previous screen and copy your changes to your computers clipboard to insert it again after you reload the edit screen. " mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Handling same time editing
ResponsesInList.Text: Mike, Do you think it might be possible to prevent a user from editing a page that someone has already started editing, rather than tell them that all the work they have done was in vain? Practically speaking, can we maybe add a checked-out flag to every page? I think this would be extremely useful Markus

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Handling same time editing
ResponsesInList.Text: A checked-out flag is a good idea . One thing though - might that tie up pages for large chunks of time and kill motivation? Maybe if there were also a setting which could allow contributors to see exactly who had a given Edit screen open at any one time and an easy way to negotiate turns - possibly with a built-in chat space in each Edit screen... After all, face-to-face collaborations would instinctively use communication avoid this kind of guesswork - why should it be different with wiki? Meanwhile I've been encouraging contributors to busy wiki pages to create their changes in a text editor and copy them in, but there are a load of reasons why that isn't a good idea - the danger of overwriting other people's changes with a former version, for example, as well as the lack of confidence that creates, and the convolutedness of the process. Mira

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Handling same time editing
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Mira, for hinting at the timing issue I absolutely agree that checking out pages for hours, days, ... would definitely kill any motivation, and I think it would be awesome if someone implemented your suggestion to combine the wiki with a chat window -- sounds like a near-whiteboard/application-sharing module for Moodle For the time being, I've got a maybe somewhat more modest proposal : Assuming that a checked-out flag was in place, how about limiting the time any given wiki page can be checked out? Of course, it would be useful if this were an option in the settings of each wiki activity, so that a teacherÂ may decide on the appropriate time frame, depending on what the learners are supposed to accomplish through the wiki. And to make sure that one doesn't "miss" the check-in time, we could maybe have a timer similar to the one in the quiz module; and some kind of reminder before the time is up would be nice, too Oh well, my wish list is getting longer and longer... Any thoughts? Markus

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Handling same time editing
ResponsesInList.Text: Markus,

ResponsesInList.Title: Does using HTML editor kill ewiki text markup?
ResponsesInList.Text: If a wiki page is created or edited with the HTML editor, it appears that all subsequent edits must use the editor as well.Â  At least on my moodle/wiki combination, if I attempt to edit a page with the simple text form (no HTML editor...my preferred method), all the html markup is inserted and the simple wiki structure is indiscernible.Â  Is this "just the way it is", or can one reclaim" simple text markup that respects the ewiki syntax? A second question: if a wiki page is created using ewiki markup (i.e. no HTML editor so no html markup in the first place), it seems to ignore blank lines when there should be paragraph breaks.Â  I can force a line break with "%%%", or insert a <_p>, but of course this defeats the purpose of wiki markup.Â  Have I missed a setting? I'm using the wiki module that ships standard with Moodle 1.4.2+(2004083129). If it matters, I have the TeX, algebra, wiki autolinking,and glossary auto-linking filters on. Thanks for any insight. Moodle's cool... Steve

ResponsesInList.Title: unwanted automatic links to wiki pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Yikes - on a wiki I have a page called, for example, [test]. Now all instances of the word "test" in that course link to the wiki page [test]. I find this use of hypertext troublesome and I want to turn it off - does anybody know how? You can see an example of the problem where I experimented at http://moodledev.gold.ac.uk//mod/lesson/view.php?id=260 - the 3 links at the bottom aren't wanted. Thanks, Mira

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: unwanted automatic links to wiki pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Mira. Go to Administration/Configuration/Filters and set Wiki Page Auto-Linking to Inactive.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: unwanted automatic links to wiki pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks Tony - easy as pie when you know how. Learning... Mira

One of the things I wanted to try is to use a different Wiki system (Wikka for example) in Moodle instead of the currently moduled one. This is not a critisism to the current Wiki integration in Moodle, I'm just exploring possibilities to easily switch or add modules like this. I haven't found anything on it and I haven't actually tried it yet but could someone maybe comment on the possibilities? How easy/hard is it, is the wiki very much adapted to use in Moodle? Thanks!
role: Picture of Karin van den Berg

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: The current Wiki in Moodle is not a good one, like, the flag function never work. That is, you cannot lock (RO) a page or flag any page. The best Wiki, I think, is http://wikipedia.sourceforge.net/ It can make auto TOC (Table of content) as well. If you can adapt Wikipedia, that will be fantastic. Email to Martin (The moodle man) to talk about your idea.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I think that the best wiki is http://tikiwiki.sourceforge.net web-based Groupware. Is easy to install andÂ  powerful. for example visit http://www.sedredacademica.net/tikiwiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: I fully agree with Rodolfo. I've been using wikis for two years (plenty, on my own or shared servers), and Tikiwiki is the one I like the most, rich in features, fairly plane learning curve (According to my own experience teaching students on howto use it, in just 1 hour), easy to install, config, etc. Some people from the tikiwiki community related to education ( http://edu.tikiwiki.org ) are studying the possibility to join tikiwiki (as CMS/GRoupware) and Moodle as one of the bests (if not "The" best LMS free soft. solution. It would be great to see the wiki module in tikiwiki, adapted to work with moodle... Some information about using the wiki (in tikiwiki) for educational field, see: [ http://uniwiki.ourproject.org ] And specially, some of our results that we presented in a congress some months ago: http://uniwiki.ourproject.org/tiki-list_file_gallery.php?galleryId=7

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: While I wouldn't want to discourage anyone from trying, tikiwiki is an extremely complex stand alone portal/community/workgroup solution on its own. It is not a wiki, but rather a platform that uses a wiki as its basic paradigm. I'm not sure that integrating it with Moodle would even make sense. Certainly, someone would need to draw up a plan of which application's pieces would do what and go where. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mike: By the way, thanks a lot for you nice work integrating ewiki with moodle (I started adapting myself ewiki for Claroline two years ago, and thought of pushing ewiki integration into moodle, but I had to stop using moodle by then due to lack of support for it in our university). I agree that ewiki is the easiest full featured wiki engine to be integrated into moodle or any other php application (not tikiwiki, I know . However there are plans for splitting tikiwki features into modules (similar to phpnuke'd websites), and also there is tiki-light (which is a wiki and a very little else, afaik). This might make easier to adapt the wiki from Tiki to any other program. Well, if the person which is studying the kind-of-integration of Tiki and moodle succedds (who knows , you'll hear again about it. The idea is to use it, afaik (again), for the WikiCampus project: http://sourceforge.net/docman/display_doc.php?docid=25496&group_id=123746 Ok, good luck with wiki use in moodle (I hope one day I can use it for my educational paid work at uni or wherever Cheers, Xavier

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: What version of Moodle do you have? I'm having several problems with wikis in Moodle, but this in particular is not an issue for me. I have several wikis with the first page flagged Read-Only, and other dependent pages open for studenst to edit. I am using 1.4.3 - Enrique -

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you reported this as a bug in the bug tracker? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: The wiki that was integrated into Moodle was erfurtwiki (ewiki). It was chosen because it was built to be integrated into other applications rather than stand alone. To integrate another wiki as a module, you would first need to determine how to modify the code so that it could act as a Moodle module. This is not a small undertaking, but one that anyone is welcome to try. Anything that adds improvements or added functionality is always welcome. However, you may be better suited to try and suggest improvements to the existing one. Even better, take out the code, experiment and offer the changes back! Many of use would be happy to have another developer. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: Mike writes "suggest improvements to the existing one". I know EWiki and use it for other work. There are already many plug-ins which are not (yet?) aktivated in the Moodle implementation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using other Wiki's
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Urs - Absolutely there are many enhancements that can be added via the plug-in capability of EWiki. They aren't activated so that we have minimum required functionality. I don't think its a good idea to just activate them all either. I think it makes more sense to figure out what and if we need them, and then activate them. But certainly, anyone can custom fit their own installation. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: What is the added value of integrating YAW? (yet another wiki) Erfurt wiki is rich and complete with the integrated HTML-editorÂ and the added password-structure. (And yes, Mike still finds new ways to improve it, a happy miracle) IÂ  think you should focus more on the question of added functionality for the students, teachers have now enough toys in Moodle: for example in your area of wiki's: students could profit from a wiki that helps them to keep APA or MLA syntax when they are gathering resources - and not at the end! - for their piece of art. http://wikindx.sourceforge.net/ wiki's that help students toÂ create a written structure with export to xml and publish facilities: start on a page like this: http://wiki.splitbrain.org/wiki:compare find tools that can help students to plan (an easy workbreakdown in a gantt), visualise ideas (freemind) and find ways to integrate these in the workflow of a Moodle course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: I thought I was clear enough on this point. It's not about the wiki that's in there or that there are others that are better. What I want to test is the ability to integrate modules like a 'random' wiki into moodle. It could have been a complelety different module, it just happens that a fellow student here is researching wiki's and using it in a class that we will also introduce moodle to. I was just wondering how easy or hard it would be to do this type of customization.
role: Picture of Karin van den Berg

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: Karen, Thanks for the clarification. Regardless of what underlying wiki engine is used for the module, I think a very important consideration is how well it integrates into the Moodle user interface. It's been mentioned in other discussions, but I think Moodle is close to imploding (like WebCT almost did) due to increasing inconsistencies of user interface and overwhelming features as more modules are added. The other wikis mentioned have some positive things going for them (also negative such as TikiWiki "kitchen sink" overkill) but are pretty set on their way of doing things. Mike's done great work in adapting ewiki to integrate into Moodle that I don't think can be easily done with many other wiki engines without looking like "hanging furry dice on a Mercedes car mirror". Cheers, Bob

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: "inconsistencies"Â  yes, it's a problem.Â  I hope after 1.5 is out with the new themes that we can have less rush on piling in features and more attention paid to sorting these out ... For example the Wiki still needs a lot of smoothing out, and Workshop and Lesson just scare me

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: What is scary about lesson? It's just a cute little hypercard wannabe in a big ol'moodle .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: Firstly, I've had occasion to trundle through that big spaghetti script a few times lately .. secondly the interface is getting very, er, busy. The first view a teacher has of it has 30 options!Â  I rewrote Ray's Mixed Case strings last week too. But this is getting off-topic, sorry.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why another YAW?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Karin - I understood you. A concrete answer isn't possible though - there are too many variables. Creating a Moodle module is pretty well documented - look in the 'contrib' directory in CVS for the 'NEWMODULE' directory. Any other problems or questions you have while doing it are best discussed in the General Developers forum here on Moodle. To answer how long it would take to integrate any other wiki into Moodle can't be answered. It all depends on how easy the code you are integrating gets along with Moodle. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Link-Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Okay, I'm not sure why its not working, but there is a better, wiki way to do this. The link you want on the text 'Raum34' is to the wiki page ''ElberfeldRaum34', correct? To do this use the wiki link '[]' feature. Anything enclosed in square brackets in a wiki becomes a wiki link. Furthermore, if you have a '|' character separating text and a wiki page, the text appears as the link for the named page. So, you could put ' [Raum34|ElberfeldRaum34]' in your wiki, and the text 'Raum34' would be hyperlinked to the wiki page 'ElberfeldRaum34'. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Link-Problem

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Link-Problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh. I see. Now I understand... Have you tried this: [Raum34|http:// yoursite.com / yourmoodle /mod/wiki/view.php?id= modid &wikipage=edit/ElberfeldRaum34] Replace the italicized words with your information. the modid needs to be the same as the one you see when you access your wiki page. mike
