I'm trying to explain it to teachers and while I think I understand it, I'm at a complete loss to *explain* itÂ and all the bits I've seen use very unfamiliar vocabulary to me (I think it's a special wiki dialect, I'm not sure). 4. other modules - every once in a while I see mention of other modules in development and yet when i go into the Moodle modules site it's all the same old stuff. Is there somewhere else I should be looking for Moodle modules? Thanks for any and all suggestions!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sarah, I have lots of questions about wiki as well, so I can only answer #3 and #4. I hope to hear some other answers, too. 3. There is no documentation that I can find about wiki in the official documentation or Matt Riordan's Teacher Manual 1.3. You might contact him and see if he has a new version 1.4 coming out and could he send you an early draft. To explain wiki to other teachers and students, I simply call it a "group document". In other words, a group of people can individually edit and re-edit the content. 4. New modules (such as Form, blog , etc.) under development are mostly available in the nightly build of Moodle version 1.5dev. If you have a separate server which you reserve exclusively for experimenting, then you can go to Downloads and try this one. It is unstable, which is why they are not available for general download yet. A few modules which have been under development for a while and are fairly stable (Book, Hotpot, Questionnaire) are available for special download under Add-on Modules in the Download section. By the way, I have another question about wikis. If two or more people edit a wiki at the same time and then save it about the same time, what happens? Which version gets saved?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Don, I have an updated manual based on 1.4.1 that I am determined to get out on Friday (the 17th). I am almost embarrassed how long it has taken me to update it, but this has been a busy couple of months. -Matt

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: This is great news.Â  I have two groups ready to "wiki", but am not comfortable enough myself to set them off.Â  I will be lurking on Friday.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: "If two or more people edit a wiki at the same time and then save it about the same time, what happens? Which version gets saved?" Only one can save at any given time. The second person gets a message saying that the wiki is being edited by somebody else and can then copy the changes and paste them in the latest version. It actually works pretty well as far as I could see from my students's use of their group wiki (I had 10 group wikis with 3 to 5 students in each group). FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki usage
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the explanation, Francoise. So a wiki requires turn-taking. Student1edit >> Student1save >> Student2edit >> Student2save >> Student3edit... and so on. It is not like a physical blackboard/whiteboard where many contributors can simultaneously make a comment. I wonder if online "whiteboards" operate like wikis or like their physical counterparts. This means when I ask for evaluation comments at the end of my face-to-face class, I should not use a wiki. I should use a forum (with setting to one-person/one-comment). Then everyone can make a comment and save it at the same time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll limit myself to question no. 3: One nice source of info on the wiki phenomenon is the Wikipedia. Their listing for "wiki" can be found at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki It contains some nice tidbits on the etymology of wiki, the underlying wiki philosophy (make it easy to fix mistakes, rather than make it hard to make mistakes) and some of the pros (wonderful collaborative environment) and cons (vandalism) of wikis. Cheers, Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki philosophy
ResponsesInList.Text: On the pros and cons of wiki: it should be used in a high-trust environment. In other words, only have a group work in it *after* they have built trust among themselves or you sense trust has developed. Needless to say, group wikis should often be closed to group members alone. Note also that if a wiki has been accidentally or deliberately messed up, you can go back to an earlier version to start over.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki philosophy
ResponsesInList.Text: You can set the group wikis as separate and then switched to visible at the end when the wikis are ready for "public view". Other groups can then see every other wikis but cannot edit them. I found it really good to give some space to groups to work together on a project, knowing that nobody else (apart from the teacher) would see it until its completion.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki philosophy
ResponsesInList.Text: >> You can set the group wikis as separate and then switched to visible... Yes, I agree this is a very powerful procedure. Groups should wrestle with a problem/project independently at first, coming up with their own original responses privately. Then when they are ready to revise and rebuild, it is helpful to see models/results of other groups. Therefore, maybe a step or two before the "end product", we can turn the wiki on publically.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki in 1.4: Upload and Linking Problems -- Fixed
ResponsesInList.Text: Problems fixed. Thanks, Martin. -- Art

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki in 1.4: Upload and Linking Problems -- Fixed
ResponsesInList.Text: What was the problem?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki in 1.4: Upload and Linking Problems -- Fixed
ResponsesInList.Text: It was a wierd thing.Â  There was this include_once in view.php: include_once($CFG-> dirroot ."/mod/wiki/ewiki/plugins/moodle/moodle_highlight.php"); Now, I know it's only included once, and it's the only place within wiki that it's included from, but there was a PHP error about the functionÂ  ewiki_moodle_highlight trying to redefine itself on line 28 of that file.Â  I know this function doesn't appear anywhere else. I looked for a while couldn't find out why this was happening, so I just commented out the include_once.Â  The search highlighting doesn't seem to be affected and it fixed the problem, so ... perhaps you want to look more into this!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki in 1.4: Upload and Linking Problems -- Fixed
ResponsesInList.Text: On my installation this is definitely an issue. When that's commented out, I don't get search highlighting. When its included I do - and I don't ever see errors. Is this happening on more than one site? What filters are being used? I wonder if there's a strange conflict with filters... although that still doesn't explain the include_once... mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki in 1.4: Upload and Linking Problems -- Fixed
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, this was my bad. I went back and tried completely clearing the PHP cache from the server , and wouldn't you know it, the error went away.Â  Now, the thing is that the PHP cache should have been regenerated when I edited view.php anyway, but for some reason it wasn't doing so.Â  Wierdness (shrug). I've reinstated the original include in stable.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki in 1.4: Upload and Linking Problems
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Art - Some questions: What type of link are you trying to make? What filters do you have active? Are there any specific formats that aren't being allowed with your upload? What type of wiki (teacher, group, student), and what editing format (HTML, safe or wiki) are you using? I can't duplicate your problems yet. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
ResponsesInList.Text: In a wiki you are free to put your comments on the page under construction. (and others are free to read it, change it orÂ throw it away. (It will still survive in theÂ  history of that page.) It is another kind of collaboration: constructing together, very democratic, must beÂ a hororÂ for..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ger: Think about several long discussions about several points in one page. The problem here is page contents mixing up with content discussions. One discussion page (with its own history) for each wiki page should be very helpful in achieving understable communication purposes. Best wishes, Juan Miguel

ResponsesInList.Title: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm wanting to use the wiki module in Moodle to collaboratively edit a rather long document. I copied and pasted the document into the wiki, and it seemed to work fine, but when I went back to the page, much of the last portion of the document was missing. Is there a maximum page length or something that is causing this? Haven't found any wiki or Moodle settings (yet) that would address this problem...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hmmm. I've had that problem with the HTML editor before. Were you using that or the text editor?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: I was using the HTML editor in an attempt to preserve some of the formatting of what I was copy-pasting into the wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: So does this mean that the truncation is the HTML editor's fault. If so, I guess I could copy and paste the document as HTML code... Would that work?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have seen this before, too, when pasting a lot of formated text (with tables, bulleted lists etc.) from OpenOffice to the HTML editor. When the page is presented it is truncated ( BTW , in the HTML editor itself I do see the end of the document, but it is not rendered when displayed). This is an issue of the HTML editor, it happens in wiki module, but also in resources. Although using pure HTML text may be useful for a teacher-created resource, it is not a good idea for a wiki. My students (first year at university) cannot edit HTML source. I have solved the problem just breaking the long document into parts, and using each as a separate wiki page. The initial page has the index to access the rest. This approach has other benefits: It is the way the Web should be: small pieces linked together, not a single "monolithic" page. It is possible to control access permissions to individual pages. For instance, I have setup index page as Read-Only so students cannot change it. Hope that helps, - Enrique Castro -

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: I've seen this once, with a student who was copying and pasting HTML generated by Microsoft Word (ick) into the code window of the HTML editor. I probably should have investigated further and filed a proper bug report, but as it happens I just told her to not do that. This was in the journal module, btw, which would be further confirmation of your statement that it's an issue with the editor itself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a maximum page length?
ResponsesInList.Text: I've had the same experience with copying/pasting from Word. Using the Clean Word HTML button seemed to fix it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: What if two (or more) people are editing the wiki at the same time?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: ...which ever one saves last will be the most recent version! Neither would have each other's edits while they were working, so something would get lost in the newest version. But, you can always look back to the previous versions. This only effects the page that is being edited, not the entire wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey! I just discovered that its actually much smarter than I thought! What happens is this. If I open a version for editing, and before I save, someone else saves a new copy, I won't be able to save mine. It will tell me to use the 'back' button on my browser and cut my changes out of the editor. Then I can open the new copy and reapply my changes. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear zhenfei chen , If I had a delete button I would have pressed it right now.... At least have the decency to post this stuff in the open social forum. Do you really think you will get any benefit from this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Double-editing the wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, as an introduction to "Chinese culture" it's not impressive. Fortunately I already have a pretty good knowledge of Chinese culture so I know there's a lot more to a country of 1.3 billion people than spamming dodgy merchandise. I've deleted the other copies of his post.

ResponsesInList.Title: help files using wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I was just looking at the help files and it occured to me... what a great place for the wiki... is this old hat? Dennis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: help files using wiki?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree . especialy in those hard to understand features or methologies . it would be also useful to help translation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Apostrophe problem
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm trying to paste text files (Word) the students have sent me as a basis for a Wiki. Problem is that all the apostrophe (there's a lot: it's in French) are turned in to this funny character ï¿½. Everything I've tried (save to .rtf; to .html; use Wordpad, etc.) as failed. Any advice? Thanks!, Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Apostrophe problem
ResponsesInList.Text: What's the actual character? Apostrophe's (') work, so it must be a different character. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Apostrophe problem
ResponsesInList.Text: You're right. I finally worked it out. It has to do with the (stupid ) default automatic replacement feature in Word. Is automatically replaces the straightforward apostrophe (0027) into a "typographic" apostrophe (2019). The worst part is that this feature overrides the "Insert special character" command. So whenever I tried to "insert" a regular apostrophe, it would immediatly be replaced (no obvious to spot when you're working in Arial, where the two actually look the same...). Anyway, I've cancelled the option, and now everything's fine.... Moodle 1, Microsoft 0..... . And a great big thanks for the Wiki module. Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm testing out the wiki-module in 1.4.Â  In the Help I read: "a typewriter like font will be used if you enclose text in two equal == signs. I tried several things like: ==hghjg== == jhjkhk == === jjhkjh === None of these show up with a typewriter font.Â  I get a proportional font (Mozilla 1.6).Â  Am I doing something wrong???Â  I would like a typewriter font because I'd like to use the wiki to publish programming code fragments. TIA Stefaan Plets.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll take a look into this. It looks like we've lost all of the wiki formatting formats. I will put this in as a bug. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I take it back. The formats are working. The '==' isn't working because wiki converts them to <tt> tags, which Moodle isn't allowing. Martin - Is there a reason to disallow <tt> tags? Can we add them to ALLOWED_TAGS or should the wiki use some other tag? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I think <tt> is a very defunct tag, isn't it? Can we use <pre> instead?Â  If we are trying to be forward-looking to XHTML compliance then even that is probably not the best solution.Â  Is there a better XHTML tag or do we use a style? If we just need a short-term fix feel free to add <tt> to the allowed list as a short-term fix (in stable and dev).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure what a good fix is... For now, I've added the <tt> and the <code> tags to the valid tags list. What we may want to do is define a 'code-markup' class in the style sheets, and turn all <tt> or <code> tags into <span class="code-markup"> instead.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd keep the code tags and convert tt to code too, particularly if this tag stripping code isn't just restricted to the Wiki Module. But I think tt is allowed even in XHTML 1.0 strict: http://liorean.web-graphics.com/xhtml/comparison.loose-strict.html

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Stefaan - The current wiki version in CVS , and the updated weblib in /lib will allow your typewriter tags to work. You may also want to consider using tags as well, as they were more specifically designed for code fragments. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Typewriter font in wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your quick and adequate response!!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Still struggling
ResponsesInList.Text:
Still trying to get my code fragments inÂ a typewriter font...Â  I seem to get the best results with the 
 tag...Â  With  tags, like this: Private Sub cmdSom3Getallen_Click() ' 'declaratie van variabelen Dim intGetal1 As Integer Dim intGetal2 As Integer Dim intGetal3 As Integer Dim intSom As Integer ' intGetal1 = InputBox("Eerste getal:", "Invoer eerste getal") intGetal2 = InputBox("Tweede getal:", "Invoer tweede getal") intGetal3 = InputBox("Derde getal:", "Invoer derde getal") ' 'berekeningen intSom = intGetal1 + intGetal2 + intGetal3 ' 'uitvoer txtSom = intSom I get this output: `Private Sub cmdSom3Getallen_Click() ' 'declaratie van variabelen Dim intGetal1 As Integer Dim intGetal2 As Integer Dim intGetal3 As Integer Dim intSom As Integer ' intGetal1 = InputBox("Eerste getal:", "Invoer eerste getal") intGetal2 = InputBox("Tweede getal:", "Invoer tweede getal") intGetal3 = InputBox("Derde getal:", "Invoer derde getal") ' 'berekeningen intSom = intGetal1 + intGetal2 + intGetal3 ' 'uitvoer txtSom = intSom` With the 
 tag, all lines are put under each other, but I cannot leave any blank lines, so I have to put comment signs (quotes) in them. With the == markup, I have to put == signs around each line... Basically, what I'd like, is a tag (or some markup) that leaves the fragment between the opening and the closing tag untouched (and preferably displayed with a non-proportional font). I used the MoinMoin wiki for a while, and there it was possible to put {{{ }}} around code fragments.Â  These fragments where left untouched, displayed in a typewriter font, with a light background color.Â  That worked very nicely... but now I'd like to transfer all of our tools to Moodle. I use "Safe HTML" in my Wiki, since I don't want my pupils to mess around with the layout too much. Any ideas, someone??? Thanks a lot. Stefaan

ResponsesInList.Title: Student can upload file into teacher's wiki - is that normal?
ResponsesInList.Text: Using my 'dummy student', I was able to upload a file into the teacher wiki. I am not sure whether I like it or not... Does this mean that any one can upload anything in somebody else's wiki? (if they can view it, that is). FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student can upload file into teacher's wiki - is that normal?
ResponsesInList.Text: You shouldn't have been able to do that. How did you do that? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student can upload file into teacher's wiki - is that normal?
ResponsesInList.Text: That's what I thought... How did I do it? Well, I have the habit of clicking on everything I see until I know a program inside out (but I can't program...). So I logged on as a student (my 'dummy student'), had a look at the teacher wiki I had created and started clicking on any clickable thing. On one of the pages, I (as the teacher) had attached a couple of files. When students view that page, there is a link at the bottom of it: This page has attachments (or something like that). If the student clicks on the link, it brings her to the attachment page, which gives her the possibility to upload a file, change its name and write a comment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student can upload file into teacher's wiki - is that normal?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for finding that. I'll fix it. You should be able to handle any attachments in the same way. I attach and download Word documents all the time. The way you describe it, it sounds like something your local browser is doing. In both Firefox and IE , I just open it (not save) when I click on it. If I save it, it works fine too. I know that Windows will add extra '[1]' charcters to files that it downloads from email attachments if they have identical names when they come into Outlook. Perhaps your browser is set similarly?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student can upload file into teacher's wiki - is that normal?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mike. I'll check my IE and Word settings... FranÃ§oise

ResponsesInList.Title: Changing the formatting of Markup / HTML tags
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd like to do some minor changes in the way WIki text is shown.Â  For instance, if I use <code> tags (or == markup), I'd like to give these fragments a light background color.Â  Is there an easy way to do this (using some stylesheet customization, perhaps)? TIA Stefaan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the formatting of Markup / HTML tags
ResponsesInList.Text: I think the easiest way to do this is to add style definitions for <code> and <tt> tags in your stylesheet. That way, it will work for all occurrences; not just within the wiki. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: There has been some discussion of allowing a frontpage wiki (site level) to be open to anyone, including non-logged in users. The current wiki will allow members to contribute once logged in, but not anonymous users. Do people think this is a good idea? Is there any good reason not to provide this option? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Surely a user who is willing to contribute to a wiki will be willing to log in. I think the wiki should follow the same conventions as every other modules. User's not logged in can view but not change. I am not sure to what extend this is implemented in the wiki yet. On pages that should be accessible to users without logging in you can use the function require_course_login($course->id) instead of the usual require_login($course->id).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Surely a user who is willing to contribute to a wiki will be willing to log in. Hi, Gustav. That's not necessarily the case. Wikipedia allows anyone to edit entries, logged in or not, and quite a number of their entries are in fact contributed or edited by anonymous users. For example, see the history of the entry for Lev Vygotsky and note how many of the edits were done by anonymous users (denoted only by their IP address).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think that those users were unwilling to log in. They probably simply weren't prompted to log in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I think most people are starting to look on the idea of yet another account and password with horror, at least I do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: A non-default option for this might be OK I suppose, but in general I think it's a bad idea for most sites: people should log in and identify themselves when altering common property. Tony's case might be a bit of an exception. It's not like it's hard to log in or anything...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree with the non-default option. This is definitely something you would want to be sure you wanted to do... And, if it is an option, it should definitely only be an option for the front page . No other activities would allow this (I think) at the course level, and the wiki shouldn't be an exception. My guess is the question comes up because a lot of wiki sites do allow contributions from anyone.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Open front page wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree with the non-default option. Absolutely, it should definitely be a choice if it gets added at all. I'm not sure how well a public wiki meshes with the overall philosophy of Moodle. As Martin noted, our situation is something of a special case. It may not be worth it if it adds a lot of complexity; installing Mediawiki isn't hard to do if someone really needs a public wiki (especially since anyone running Moodle already has PHP and a database installed anyway ) On the other hand, if you can add the option without much trouble I think it would be useful for some. Several of the people associated with my program (including me) really hate the fact that so much student work winds up as essentially wasted effort. The student hands in the paper, the teacher grades it, then no one ever sees it again. Having it locked behind a login wall is almost as bad. A public wiki not only puts the work out for the general public, but also makes it possible for the work to be improved and revised at will, even if the original author is long gone. Think about it for a moment... assume that only one student paper per course per semester is worthy of public distribution (and I think that's an extremely low estimate). Now multiply that by the number of courses per institution and the number of academic institutions in the world. It's disturbing to think of all the useful academic work that simply disappears (okay, maybe not as bad as the burning of the Library of Alexandria, but still disturbing). So far we've gotten around that in Moodle by opening some of our courses for guest access and having the site open to Google, but that's still not a completely satisfactory solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm very excited about this module and have watched it grow with anticipation. I look forward to documents that students build with wikis, but probably even more, the chance to provide in-line comments to student wikis, thus helping them revise their writing. The versioning aspect will be just great. My only fear is the jargon and the remaining wiki feel. I appreciate the way that wiki links are disappearing and being replaced by Moodle help buttons, etc., but I wonder whether it is time to be more radical and to lose more of the wiki jargon. Maybe it is too soon in development and I'm talking about superficial language issues, but I'm still a bit intimidated by this interface. Similar, perhaps, to the way that I'm spooked by the complexity of the workshop module. Let me start with this suggestion: why not call it the collaborative writing module? Do we benefit from teaching students about the wiki concept/history at all? ... should they care? What about the drop-down menus? Wikis are flexible, but users need the simplest functions in the clearest spaces. How about this in the bottom right corner of the /moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id= page? Edit | History (Borrowed from the very familiar forum module)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: I like the name collab writing tool (I agree: do not bother them with a Wiki concept and then have to explain weuse it a little bit different.) For the same reason I renamed lesson in Action Matrix /FlashCards.. In Swiki I had no preview, so I had to save any trial to view it AND when I (or somene else) was working on the same page was pressing the save button, the slowest one got a conflict message: In eWiki the page gets blocked for others when someone opens it for editing: fantastic!! (And then the preview is very useful: until that user saves the page really, it stays blocked. Makes life for a teacher much easier..) Organise Pages? Everyone can do that by cutting outr a piece of text (includingÂ CamelCases) and paste it on another page: should work thereÂ too.. A teacher can insert a comment starting with his name (TEACHER TOM: Why not put in a description etc...), A student can read, use it, and remove it. You need a commentbox on the moment that the student can lock the page for others.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: Not frustrating, Tom, useful. Comments can be added in-line for now. With HTML, you can differentiate them. I am planning on adding a more formal comment mechanism, like some other wiki products, but I'm not sure when I'll get to it. Also, I'm not sure whether I should try to integrate it with the existing forum mechanism or not. The 'wiki way' is not complex - just the opposite. In fact it was created to be used by people who didn't have a lot of time to learn new technologies. The basic premise is to create a page, name it. 'If you name it, it will come.' I don't have a problem renaming it - you can call it what you want in your language file. But it is an implementation of the ewiki open source, so I think we should at least acknowledge that. I like your menu ideas; looks cleaner. Michael and I will look into those. I haven't looked at the journal, but what would you want instead of the 'Edit this page ...'? IÂ think the preview should stay. The wiki naming convention must remain, but you don't need to use it. If you enclose any word(s) in '[]' (square brackets), it becomes a page. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Mike for your comments. I think you are already there with inline comments. I plan to just use a different font color when I edit the page. Also, I have an ambitious scheme to create a kind of pop-up palette of "common composition, grammar, and punctuation errors" (maybe ones that are stored in a glossary and that can be inserted in the way smileys are added in a non-html window). I hear what you are saying about linking a forum to a wiki for comments. That is one way (I was thinking about it myself when I posted feature request, bug 463). Another way might be to create a kind of glossary (contained to the particular wiki), that allows you to highlight words or phrases and to create a kind of annotated comment on the side. (My feature request, bug 1341 talks about this a bit... but I'm sure it would be a pain to introduce...) I agree with the idea that wiki-way editing is far simpler than html mark-up, but I suspect the HTML editor is even simpler. As for the difference between the edit pages of the wiki and the journal, I think, simply, that when you reach the editing moment in wiki, it is odd to look at a line that says "edit this page." The user has already clicked the edit button, he is currently editing, it seems like a disorienting reminder to do so again. I'm probably saying this in a really convoluted way -- please excuse me. Thanks again, Mike, collaborative writing is a critical element of Moodle that continues to transform possibilities for teaching. -Tom p.s. I approached an HTML designated wiki in your last build with a browser that doesn't allow for an editor. It hung. Is there a way for it to recognize such browsers and to offer up the html code instead?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: Wiki is another way ofÂ  thinking about collab webpage creation, I support that idea. Suggestion: Why not change the label "How to Wiki" into "WikiWhat" you refer to the attitude of first-timers you show your first CamelCaseWord, the soul of Wiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: The route I've taken with the Wiki in my company is to give it a name and acknowledge that it is a Wiki i.e. "CollabWriting is what we are calling our implementation of a Wiki."Â  In general disscussion we would then call it CollabWeb, CollabWriting pages, etc.Â  Many of our pages and actions have been retitled to suit us too(we don't use the title in action-links for example).Â  Our help pages talked only about what WE have decided to do until reccently when, with the increase of Wikis in the news, (see Business Week, June 7th, 2003, "Something Wiki this Way Comes") we realized that we could talk about the wikiness of the system.Â  I reccently gave a presentation to about half the company which was partially focused on "The WikiWay," and included topics like refactoring and navigation by backlinks. I would suggest a similar approach, call the module whatever you like, but acknowledge that it is a Wiki so that users familiar with Wikis can understand that they have one.Â  Don't explain Wikis too much, but include some links for those that care like a link to Wards Wiki or the WikiPedia.Â  Make pages with more detailed information on topics like Refactoring available on the Moodle site so that users who find a need for them can add them to Wikis that have developed enough of a culture to use them. on the postscripts: * Preview is great and happens to be where eWiki links in the spell checker.Â  Also some users will be nervous with the markup if every variation they try is saved. * You can remove the Wiki naming convention, but I wouldn't.Â  WikiWords are easy to guess and remember leading to good references in long-lived Wikis (like a class wiki carried forward from year to year). * This post is just the kind of reaction I got from my boss when I first said the word "Wiki,"Â  He has since come around.Â  Definately the Wiki plugin should blend with Moodle in every way possible, eWiki is designed for just that kind of embbending and we would accept patches needed to make it more embbedable.Â  Some of the strangeness may become comfortable and useful with time. AndyFundinger

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: (Hmm, I thought I'd already written a reply to this but I must have closed the tab before posting it.Â  Anyhow ..) Thanks, Tom.Â  I agree that there is a lot that could be done to polish and clarify the interface and taking it a feature at a time seems to be a good way to do this.Â  Keep up the suggestions - you're very much in the "zone" for using this module to it's fullest. However, I'm not sure about calling it Collaborative writing, firstly because it seems the name Wiki is gaining some traction now ... but also because there are probably other things that it can be used for apart from collaborative writing, such as simple publishing or individual webs.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: Exactly, Martin. This would hide the engine under the hood (bonnet?) of the car better. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: I think in fact you are talking about the same thing as Tom (the engine would not change ... only the display of page titles) Tom was also referring to the new filter that creates links throughout all of Moodle to Wiki pages.Â  These should definitely NOT be searching for CamelCase.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: Can you explain me how the search will work then? I thought it will search the database and there the words will be stored as CamelCases.... or are you thinking of a trick toÂ do a conversion before the store?Â And you do a reconversion againÂ when the page opens in edit-mode? The TITLE of a page can be converted, and in VIEW MODE you can show the words as Moodle Hyperlinks with spaces, butÂ all the in-line references on that page in EDIT MODE should stay CamelCases, otherwise you make it very complex for users (it would interfere with the functions of the HTML-editior that has also a hyperlink function ) and you would driftÂ away from the concept Wiki. (And I think like Tom that theÂ HTML-editor will replace the easy-editing-folklore of Wiki also in the other wiki-products, but this very clever CamelCaseForLinksInEditModeIdea will surivive, so stay compatible in edit mode..)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: First off, for a wiki, the page title cannot change after is has been created. A wiki page name is it's identity.Â To do this would break all the links to it. This is equivalent to changing the file name of an HTML page - you need to go back and change all the links. Or changing the MySQL 'id' number of a module.Â (So Tom, once named SillyPage, always named SillyPage). We could de-camelize a page title before displaying it as a page title, but we would have to make assumptions. In other words, if the title had mixed case, we would have to automatically assume that it was CamelCase, and not something else. Keep in mind, you can now name a page without using Camel Case, as long as you enclose in '[ ]'. I don't think its a good idea to display the page title as anything other than what it was named. I think that would be too presumptious of us. As to using CamelCase, I think we need to always have it. It is the backbone of a Wiki, even if it isn't needed any more. And, some people actually can learn it faster than teaching them to use square brackets (really). mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: Wait a minute, are you saying that Tom already can do what he wishes, as long as he embraces his [Page title names with spaces] with brackets?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I've been aware of this idea. And I'm certainly good with it. I really also like the idea of creating new pages on the fly by typing WordsTogether, too. Sorry I've been incoherent about my wishes. I think they have been evolving as I've been learning from this discussion. I now wonder whether the CamelCase could be parsed (as it is created) and stored as a title like "Words Together" -- just like a page title that was created between brackets[]. That way, it wouldn't STAY funky in the Moodle system. It would just have a funky birth. Again, I think the best modules allow people to think they are doing something simple: maybe writing a journal. Then, in time, the users realize that the journal can be versioned, can be linked, can create additional pages on the fly...wow! But if a user sits down at a wiki with a big dashboard of flight controls, I suspect there will be a kind of paralysis. Likewise, a dashboard of permanently FunkyTitles SuddenlyMakes a SimpleJournal FeelLike a ForeignVehicle. Mike, you are ever-patient to listen to any of these ideas. I'll step away from the machine and let others share view points. Thanks so much, Tom

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text:
Tom writes: I now wonder whether the CamelCase could be parsed (as it is created)
and stored as a title like "Words Together" -- just like a page title
that was created between brackets[]. That way, it wouldn't STAY funky
in the Moodle system. It would just have a funky birth. At first glance, this sounds like a great idea to me! In addition, I prefer the [brackets method] so much more that I think the CamelCase linking should be severely demoted in the documentation.Â  I'm all for keeping it so old-time Wiki-enthusiasts can continue to use it, but it should really not be presented as the main method. Speaking of which - who wrote this in the How to Wiki docs!? "While language purists hate Wikis for that naming scheme, it is very common in the
computing world and well known to most programmers."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: I promise I didn't touch the wiki docs!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: That was from the original help file. Sounds like a translation of a translation. I massaged a lot of the text - but not all of it. Its basically trying to say that wiki page names are based on programming variable naming schemes. It probably, really,Â doesn't have a place in this document... The idea of parsing the CamelCase into Camel Case upon creation, sounds interesting, and probably could be done, but I think that makes it even more difficult than using square brackets. Either we are forcing the writer to stop midstream, and remove spaces of titles they want to use as pages, just so those spaces can be reintroduced, or we are changing what they write. I really think that teaching them the square brackets method will make more sense. They still have to do a bit of backtracking, but they don't need to change what they've written. I'll take a look at demphasizing CamelCase in the help files. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: There are two significant problems with parsing CamelCase at display time, you may avoid these, but I suggest thinking about them: MyPage and [My Page] would be displayed the same.Â  Users who wish to make a link would have to hover around trying to find out what it is they need to link to, even in the normal case. Would you want to display EUCouncilofMinisters as "E U Councilof Ministers?" "EU Councilof Ministers?"Â  Teaching people to manage the mangler might prove non-trivial.Â  I use a similar mangling on titles(not text) for my Wiki and the incidence of mis-mangled titles is rather high. I would suggest that display time mangling is worse than turning off WikiWords, which itself is worse than silently depreciating them. If you do go this route, consider doing a save-time mangle with an edit_save plugin to look at the page text being saved and replace any simple CamelCase with ["{Target Page}"{TargetPage}].Â  That would give authors full capability to correct the mangling and allow the plugin to be turned off at anytime without affecting current pages.Â  See the /plugins/feature/timestamp.php plugin for an example edit_save mangler. AndyFundinger eWiki Developer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: wikiness at odds with moodleness? simplicity
ResponsesInList.Text: First let me say that I like the concept of a Wiki. I like its idealistic roots and the monitored anybody can edit mentality. I think it is a concept deserving recognition and as such should keep its own name: wiki. For any users it takes a bit of time to learn how to use a wiki. The idea of creating pages on the fly, using certain codes to do the markup of the page, etc. I do not think that there is a lot of difference in the difficulty of teaching somebody to use CamelCase or teaching them to use brackets. Both of them are not intuitive and need to be taught. I would probably go for the method that is used in most other Wikis on the web, One thing I will never get used to though is the way that CamelCase looks on the page. I can't stand to see the titles of my pages and do not think they will be taken seriously by anybody who is not in the know about Wikis. I do not have enough knowledge about how the wiki module work, or how things are stored in the database, but there must be some sensible way of showing Normal Titles in display mode and WeirdLookingTitles in edit mode.

Now, as the wiki documentation says rightly about CamelCase: "it is very common in the computing world". So it can happen that the bit one cuts and paste contains CamelCase words. Besides, any automatic link (camel case, [], orÂ !http)Â can be prevented by prepending it with an '!' or a '~' character. That character tells the wiki engine to not link the following text. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No WikiNames in HTML only mode
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gustav - I just re-read the help file on HTML-Only mode, and it seems to say what you are saying. However it works differently. It allows HTML tags and wiki tags. My preference is for the way it works. I like being able to use both formatting methods. The HTML editor is much more familiar to a lot of my users and results in more success with formatting the documents. The extra wiki formatting codes (bold, italics, etc.) I could live without, but the simple linking and page creation mechanism is critical. Its much easier to teach people that they can create and link new pages just by naming them (whether in camel case or in [] ). As for cutting an pasting, again, because this is a wiki (not an HTML document), I expect wiki link codes to work as wiki links when I paste them in. That way, I could actually create wiki structures off-line, paste them into the wiki, and have them work as expected. So, for me: - HTML editor for easy text formatting, - wiki words for easy link definition. mike

ResponsesInList.Text: That's an interesting question. I think the answers depend on what the wiki is used for. In a pure wiki context , anyone who has edit abilities should be able to do these things. But I can see a use for being able to just let them edit, and not change any of the versions. I think this needs discussion. My thoughts - If its a 'student' wiki, than the student should have full control over their own wiki - including admin functions. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "Admin"-Functions
ResponsesInList.Text: Short answer: Introduce an extra level: split student wiki intoÂ student wikiÂ and personal wiki Long Answer: Good point: As Tom wrote: what if a student deletes a teacher hint on his page withoutÂ really using the hint (then it is not a personal but a student/educational wiki) If the studentÂ cannot delete the old versions, You and the student can see this hint shining in an older version of that page and have an educationalÂ conversationÂ about that.. One of the mechanism to protect a Wiki when it is open for everyone is this page-version-control, so be carefull when you give it away as admin/teacher. The same protection should there be for the uploaded files: Everyone can upload , only the admin can delete. Everyone can overwrite a file with an empty one, to hide the content for others,Â but in the versions there should be a file version store with the old file for the adminÂ to put it back in place (Like I had inÂ my Swiki ).

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, three comments: Most wikis have for the user open html pages so theyÂ can paste any html/javscript they wish. Need a calendar? paste your favorit in it! ResponsesInList.Title: Re: flat DB files
ResponsesInList.Text: Without gzcompress (compile with php configure switch "--with-zlib") you can only generate tar archives.Â  The plugin should detect if it has been configured with a default type of ZIP and no gzcompress function and not register itself.Â  If the default type is TAR the registration skips this step and it should run fine(though it cannot create zip files).Â  I have gzcompress but the TAR generation code works for me too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeing Wiki pages as admin or teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, Swiki is another implementation of Wiki, I am just a demanding user of eWiki and give my comments to M&M. So my comment here is that I think teachers should have always access, because we are an educational setting not a wiki community. I use Swiki as a stand-alone programÂ until this eWiki is fully integrated in Moodle. I like this integrated eWiki now very much: And IÂ prefer the HTML-editor above the Wiki-simple-text-philosophy.. But this Swiki option (coomentbox)Â was very nice: the only thing a user had to do was place a commentbox symbol on the page, place his email in a "send me an email"" -field and lock the page. (Students can take ownership of a page when they put a lock on a individual page of a group-wiki.) A visitor sees then the locked page with the commentbox. As soon as the visitor types his comment and presses the comment-button under that box, the owner gets an email.There is no database behind it, pages are stored in XML -format. Another option I did like was the possibility for a webuser with editor rights to create a webform instead of the standard fill-in screen. The page-storing mechanism makes collecting the content of the forms to difficult, no database.. SwikiÂ is a standalone server that runs on Mac,Â  Unix, Windows.. We used it for several years at our secondary schools to collect experience with collab-work on a website. Works great. http://minnow.cc.gatech.edu/swiki The program Swiki is written in the Smalltalk version Squeak. The pioneer Alan Kay is one of the founders. Their children project eToys is inspiring http://www.squeakland.org/ During meetings they play the game to install and runÂ this Swiki-server in less then ... seconds.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeing Wiki pages as admin or teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: Alright, I double-checked the code and tested it. I was wrong; I implemented it such that teachers can edit any wiki - even student ones. So, if you're not getting that functionality, something's wrong. Now, there is an issue with changing the group mode on an existing wiki. I haven't figured out how to resolve this yet. If you were to change a group wiki, that was previously set to 'no groups' to 'separate' or 'visible', and it already had wiki entries, you would orphan that pages that were originally created. The effect you would get is that the teacher would always see the orphaned wiki first when they looked at the wiki. The teacher can see the real wikis by selecting them from the drop-down list. If the teacher edits the orphaned one, only they will see it. No students from the course would ever see the orphaned one. So, to summarize: A teacher can edit and view all wikis, regardless of type and group setting. Group wikis can be edited by anyone in the group. If the group setting is 'no groups', then anyone in the course can edit them. Group wikis can be viewed by anyone, for 'no groups' or 'visible groups', or by members of the groups for 'separate groups'. Teacher wikis can be edited by teachers only. If you are not seeing this functionality, make sure you have the latest code from CVS , and try a fresh wiki. Don't change the group setting once you have entered wiki entries. Let me know any anomalies you see. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeing Wiki pages as admin or teacher
ResponsesInList.Text: Since the teachers can edit student wikis, they should also be able to create them for the student. I will put the code in for this today. Now, some other questions: Do we want to handle this differently for groups? Should the teacher be a member of the student's groupÂ to create the student's wiki? Should teacher editing privileges affect this? Should a teacher from a different group be able to view a student's wiki if groups is set to 'separate'? My thoughts: Editing teachers and administrators can view/change/create entries forÂ any wiki. Non-editing teachers not assigned to a specific group can view/change/create entries for any wiki. Non-editing teachers assigned to a specific group can view/change/create entries for any wiki in their group, and view wikis in other groups for 'visible' groups. Make sense? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is Wiki and what can I do with it?
ResponsesInList.Text: Check this link out for one of the first wikis. Essentially, a wiki is a way for everyone to add content to a web page. They can create new pages, edit existing ones and see a change history of all of them. We use it to add an activity to a course that allows multiple participants to create and edit web pages. This implementation lets you specify who is allowed to edit and who can only view. Additionally you can multiple parallel wiki structures being maintained by different people / groups. mike

ResponsesInList.Text: I am undertaking the task of fitting a Wiki module into Moodle. The group thatÂ I will have using Moodle need to be able to work together on documents both as planning operations and as assignments. Wikis seem to be the best web-based choice for this. Features of Wikis: Group document creation. Non-HTML formatting controls. Automatic document versioning. Undoing last changes. Displaying similar pages. Ability to 'lock' documents. Ability to set 'read-only' function. (Any Others?) Nice To Haves: Comments on Wiki pages. Comments on changes (versions). Attachments. Software: PHPWiki ErfurtWiki PMWiki My cursory investigation leads me to believe that ErfurtWiki will be easier to integrate into Moodle than PHPWiki. ErfurtWiki, or ewiki, has been built as a library rather than a stand-alone application. It is OpenSource and has many plug-ins which can be integrated or not. If anyone has any information that can affect this choice, please post it here. Some Moodle specific functionality I will look into: Visibility - Can we define a wiki at a global, course and topic level? In other words, can a wiki be limited to a topic such that it will only link to other wikis in that topic. Same with course. An can we make it global so that it can link to all wikis (or, in fact can we prevent this). Any Others? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Wiki (Collaborative Document) Module
ResponsesInList.Text: I hadn't heard of ErfurtWiki before but after a quick glance I agree it does look like a good starting point. My brain is too tired to think about the linking issues right now but I look forward to hearing what that usual suspects have to say about it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Wiki (Collaborative Document) Module
ResponsesInList.Text: Mike, these sound great. (usual suspect #3 steps in). Somebody will probably be interested in grading the collaborative documents, so you might keep your idea on the forum code (that is also used in the glossary module) that allows flexible scale assessments (for each version?). I would recommend that we don't create new pages with wiki-style StickWordsTogether formatting. Your module has great potential of being wide-spread and IMHO ThisParticularConvention speaks to webheads more than classrooms. Maybe links don't appear unless the corresponding pages are already created? (Hyperlink/Library/Glossary style?). When you choose the non-html formatting controls, you might want to post them up for some discussion, as folks might want to wrangle over the most sensible formats. Comments are cool (and appropriate), but I wonder whether it might be more useful simply to attach a forum to the document, so that all of the cool functionality of the forums gets sewn onto the end of the wiki page (I've thought about this similarly with the glossary module). This is a huge project--thanks for jumping into it. A bunch of us would be happy to test the code as it develops.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Wiki (Collaborative Document) Module
ResponsesInList.Text: I am in the process (again) of integrating ErfurtWiki into Moodle as an activity module. The biggest issue I've come up against is handling multiple wikis. The basic design of a wiki allows for all wiki pages to access all other wiki pages simply by using their names. Obviously, wikis will have much more value to Moodle if they can be separate structures that only access pages within their own structure. These whole structures can have limited lifetimes (as long as a course runs). As a minimum I can see that we would need to be able to have self-contained wikis by course, group and user. I would like to have them also by category and site. Unfortunately, ErfurtWiki doesn't support multiple wikis directly. Its based on the basic concept of "one open document". The good news is that the developers of ErfurtWiki are looking into it to see how much effort it would take to make these changes. I'll keep you posted. mike

ResponsesInList.Text: Michael - Very cool. It seems we did do some overlap, but I think it'll make both versions better (I haven't uploaded mine, yet). Two problems I had installing yours: The MySQL . sql file has an extra comma after the 'PRIMARY KEY ('id') statement for the first table, which prevented the table from getting set up. You'll see it between the two parenthesesÂ - ' ),) ' If you set titles to 'on', it initially tells me I'm editing 'mod/wiki/view.php'. This title sticks with the first page from then on. I like the 'Allow safe HTML' and 'Fill in Default Content' options, not sure about the title one though. I got around the multi-wikis issue by talking with the Erfurt Wiki developers. For mine, instead of giving the option 'Allow students to contribute to the Wiki', I created a 'Wiki type' options which could be 'course', 'group' or 'user'. If its is a 'course' type, anyone registered in the course can edit it. If its a 'group', anyone in the group can. If its a 'user', only that user can. For 'course' wikis, every wiki page is prefixed by the course id; if its a group, they're prefixed by the course id and the group id; if its a user, they're prefixed by the course id and the user id. I was planning on uploading mine tonight or tomorrow, but I'll wait and see if you can solve the problems I had. I think it might be better for me to force fit my changes onto yours. ResponsesInList.Title: Implementing Wiki Types
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm going to release the code, based on Michael Schneider's modifications to Erfurtwiki this weekend. This code should be considered 'in development' for now, and not used on a production system unless you are prepared for potential problems. For Developers: To implement the wiki types, I believe we will need another table. With the current implementation, wiki's are differentiated by wiki id's from the wiki table. This id's are specific to a wiki instance added to a course. If we were to set one as a 'student' wiki, we need another level of differentiation. To stay within the Moodle standards, the wiki table should probably remain as holding records for every specific instance of a wiki added to a course. Therefore, we need another level that keeps track of specific wiki structures (per student or per group). Then we need to update Michael's code to use this new identifier. For now, I have left the 'allowstudentstowiki' field in the database, pending the resolution of the wiki type issue. Thoughts? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: In several forums, desparate teachers of writing have been dreaming of collaborative document-making.Â  I just discovered your forum today and want to jump in with lots of questions and comments. First, in teaching writing, the trend is completely in the direction of process writing.Â Â  Process writing involves multiple drafts of a composition including peer-editing, self-editing, and teacher -editing in the process.Â  Until we have group documents, this is almost impossible online. Now I am puzzled why the wiki features do not use the HTML editor like we have here in the Forum module.Â  It is great.Â  It allows color highlighting which is the best editing tool.Â  Instead of telling students what the mistake is or problem is, you highlight the word or sentence and let them focus on that area and figure out the problem themselves. Next, we need to make a switch onto the forum module or journal module, to allow multiple individuals or groups to edit.Â  And make editing time non-expiring.Â  For example, couldn't a particular forum be set this way?Â  Why do we need a "wiki" to have group collaboration? I have also used the wiki module which has been part of the Documentation sectionÂ  (see detailed step by step installation instructions under Apache , PHP, MySQL ).Â  I believe it was phpWIKI.Â  It was so clumbersome to operate.Â  I would say it is even terrible.Â  Also it had no highlighting, no way to attach comments, and no indications of who added what. So my list of essential features to Group Collaborative Document Module is as following, in order of importance... 1.Â  Non-expiring editing 2.Â  Groups can be designated for editing rights

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Don, forÂ months (years?)Â I beg for a Modul with the look and feel of D3E and more: a two column window with the draft on the left and the annotations on the right. In he full-blown D3E version you hang annotation-anchors in the paragraphs of the running text on the left and you can comment on this comment in the forum-threads on the right. Only one drawback: You cannot doÂ re-sead the forum with an improved draft.. So Moodle should install D3E as a Modul, PLUS: one student (or a group!) must have access to the left column the modul must support the reworking of the draft on base of the comments then a re-sead of the discussion, that leaves on resolved comments open etc.. Wikis are starting from another perspectiv: you are less concerned with the actions of each independent student and more concerned with their collab construct and the collab activities aound that. You trust that working together regulates a lot of teacher-replacing-support. (My old Smalltalk Wiki allows to place a comment box on each page, but I prefer now eWiki inside Moodle!.) OK, i know, groupswork is most of the time: 2 students do the work, two are just sittinh there and the others are nowhere, that's where the discussion is all about... (How can we find trics to handle that..no how can we ways to teach them to cope with that situation, their first job will look the same.) The new eWiki cab differentate between class-group-personal constructs a great improvement. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=1161&parent=4667 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=478&parent=5998 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=3101&parent=13958 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=255&parent=18550 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=5623&parent=26950 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=6014&parent=27877 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=1347&parent=6363

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: I understand the short-term appeal of integrating the HTML editor into the wiki module. However, it contradicts the spirit of a wiki, i.e., easy text-oriented markup *without* relying on HTML. Indeed, one of the major innovations of the wiki was it's focus on logical organization over visual formatting (a quick overview of the history of wiki and wiki philosophy can be found on the canonical site, http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?NewUserPages ). From a practical standpoint, avoiding HTML mitigates the gobs of security and parsing issues that tend to arise. I don't have strong aversion to integrating the editor (who would care anyway ), but perhaps a pause to weigh its relative pros and cons is worthwhile?

I think the use of the HTML editor is to help primarily in highlighting primarily for instructors, but probably for students as well.Â  I wonder if the folllowing features can be added via or not via the HTML editor, Ability for the Instructor to turn highlighting on and off for Student Use? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: That is Ok for me, Steve, when I started with Wiki I liked their idea of easy editing. Now I am moving away from that idea, because: every Wiki implementationÂ uses different format rules (HTML is standard, IF you learn it, you can use it elsewhere) All Wiki'sÂ have different tricks for attaching files, insert in line images etc. most users need only a very limited set like bold, italic, bullets, line, NOT USING underline etc... The only thing where most Wikis are easier isÂ when it comes to tables.. WikiÂ formatting is not an educational target on it's own, easy formatting is:Â "how can I make it more easy for a user to put information on a webpage." If you combine these thoughts with the alternative of a built-in html-editor, with tables AND A FUNCTIONALITY THAT RESEMBLES WHAT THEY KNOW: WORD... then I think even Ward Cunningham will agree..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Steve, I was wondering if you teach writing too. What we are looking for is a way to give feedback to those learning to write. Highlighting is one way. Embedding or attaching comments is another way. The key point is that the writer, several classmates and the teacher all need to comment on the document. So some kind of group collaborative document is needed. It could be a forum with non-expiring editing or it could be a wiki. It is a tool we desperately need. I have been teaching writing for 20 years, so it feels like a "long-term" appeal to me. Hi again WP, Yes, definitely the students use the highlighting.Â  For example, I will give them a task to go through a partner's writing and highlight topic sentences in green, supporting examples in yellow, etc.Â  Or give them a grammar task to search and color.Â  They love it.Â  But I don't need to turn on or turn off highlighting.Â  They just use it when I give them a task to do. And Richard, Sounds good to me.Â  I am afraid I don't know what "safe HTML" is. Thanks everyone for your comments!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, I meant Mike and MichaelÂ  (not Richard)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: While I agree that using an HTML editor violates the 'pure' definition of a wiki, I think it still applies to the spirit. The original idea was to make formatting simple, in absence of any easy formatting tools. Tools like HTMLArea allow us to add simple formatting as well. Many web-based wiki tools now offer more sophicticated formatting; the best example being TikiWiki . I think it makes sense to offer the user the option. Wiki formatting will still apply. More importantly, the collaborative nature of wikis will be there, as will the 'create a page by naming it' concept. By the way, pure wikis don't allow for any kind of edit protection either, but we definitely want that. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wiki for Teaching Process Writing Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Many good points regarding the wiki by several folks. I agree the simplicity and familiarity of the html editor is helpful for getting content submitted. Additionally, having a systematic method for feeback and updates is a key component in the pedagogical merit of this module. It seems, however, we are now talking about something other than a wiki. Perhaps I'm just focussing on semantics, but by incorporating the worthwhile features people have asked for, the fundamental tenet of the wiki (a self-evolving, self-correcting, traceable literary free-for-all ) is lost. Again, this is not a necessarily bad thing, but we are talking about a different paradigm than the wiki. Perhaps the system would be something like that used to produce the Zope Book. Take a look at the document and notice how the commentary can be interspersed with the text (be sure the comments are turned on and click on the Preface for a sample. Click on the little bubble to add a comment or turn comments off at top of document to hide commentary) http://zope.org/Documentation/Books/ZopeBook/2_6Edition/ Another source of ideas is the Silva document management system: http://www.infrae.com/products/silva This is complete overkill for what we're discussing here, but there are some interesting capabilities that could be valuable. I think Ger found similar shortcomings as I with the straight text markup. Although, the latest specification for structured text (called ReStructured Text in the python camp) provides astounding flexibility in markup and document generation, asking students to learn its nuances would be frustrating. A quick note to Don in response to his earlier post: I don't teach writing, but rather chemistry. I do have students post answers to questions, both essay and numerical problems (hence my interest in LaTeX markup!). They then critique, annotate, revise each others' answers. It's been an interesting learning experience for all of us as I learn what they buy into and what they don't. I'm getting a bit of on-the-job training in learning psychology! Regards, Steve

By the way, Zope has also a more educational Spin-off: Plone (see http://plone.org/ ) Good usable for collab groups in education.

ResponsesInList.Title: Plans for math or other "special" wiki markup?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, and kudos on this effort. As a longtime fan of the wiki as a pedagogical tool, I'm thrilled to see it become a part of Moodle. Currently, I use Zwiki (a Zope-based wiki...I'm a python guy ) which I hacked to display LaTex math markup. Not having looked at the Erfurtwiki library you're using, I'm curious if it possible to include this feature without too much trouble? Given the that Moodle TeX and algebra filters are already available, how difficult would it be to massage a wiki page for math markup prior to display or storage? Careful regex parsing would be required, and I have no idea how flexible the Erfurt parser is. I'd love the capability of full TeX markup, but even simple symbol/super/subscripts would be valuable. Again, great work, guys!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plans for math or other "special" wiki markup?
